output: Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I apologize once again for my delay.
This year marks the European Year of Intercultural Dialogue.
The involvement of everyone and the perception that education, knowledge, and the intertwining of different cultures with one another is crucial is now an established fact.
Therefore, multiple initiatives associated with this year have been undertaken by the various areas of action and intervention.
In this context, the Erasmus Mundus program also plays its role, and, within this new perspective, the new regulation is already in place.

The Erasmus Mundus programme has made an important contribution to the creation of centres of excellence within the EU, which will, to some extent, help sustain the outward migration of talent from the European Union, as well as representing a noteworthy role in…

in the promotion of European values among nationals of third countries who come here to study and find in the old continent an unparalleled cultural and linguistic diversity, which functions as an attractive and distinct hub from models existing elsewhere in the world.
However, dialogue and interculturality have suffered considerably to survive.

The issue of Erasmus student visas in the world and the frequent difficulties in their acquisition and renewal often lead to a situation of semi-illegality within the European Union, as they are frequently master's students but with tourist visas, and sometimes with expired visas.
I consider the pursuit of a solution that allows for solidity, transparency, and effectiveness in the issuance of student visas to be of the greatest pertinence and urgency.
Also crucial is knowledge of the language that allows for cultural perception and mutual interaction, beyond the strictly academic domain, and this premise we can absolutely guarantee.
To conclude, a word of thanks to Deputy Dessa Arnez for the way she conducted the entire process and for the balanced report she produced.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, the authorization for the granting of State aid to the modernization and renewal of fishing fleets in the outermost regions should only be possible until the end of 2009, or should it remain in force indefinitely?
The specific characteristics of fishing activity in these regions justify the granting of this aid beyond 2009, without any minimal detriment to the marine environment.
State aid for the modernisation and renewal of fleets in ultraperipheral regions for an indefinite period does not mean permanent and eternal aid.
would be immediately suspended if studies and evaluations by the Scientific Council and the Regional Advisory Boards indicated the need for such action.
This is the solution that would best suit the very specific reality of fishing in the outermost regions.

The same reasons that underpin for the fishermen of each RUP an exclusive fishing reserve up to 10 miles also justify a differentiated treatment regarding assistance for the modernization and renewal of the fleet.
Fortunately, within the Fisheries Committee, the best solutions were found that can address the specific characteristics of fishing in the outermost regions. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner Almunia, Mr. President of the Eurogroup, I want to greet not only the rapporteurs, but also the Commission for the initiative of having produced this text, the assessment of the 10 years of the Economic and Monetary Union.
It is a strategic text and this analysis was fundamental.
The euro, as has been stated here today, is an undeniable success.

From Lisbon to Helsinki, from Dublin to Bratislava, the euro has demonstrated resilience and solidity even during the severe turbulence we have witnessed, and it is clearly important that the borders of this club be expanded.
But the times we live in routinely test the solidity of the European project in many other dimensions.
The euro, as I mentioned, is a central instrument in the operation of the financial system.

However, the Commission’s text itself clearly points to the fundamental conclusion that neither the growth of the real economy nor convergence, in either social or spatial terms, accompanied this success.
Conversely, the Commission concludes clearly that disparities have worsened dramatically during the decade of the single currency's operation.
This divergence affects regions of my country in particular, particularly northern Portugal, but also other regions of member states.

The impacts of the single monetary policy, particularly due to the exceedingly high exchange rate, have disproportionately affected regions more exposed to international competition and those with a higher export orientation.
Today, the crisis resulting from the deregulation of financial markets is violently impacting the real economy and further exacerbating the situation for many citizens and numerous regions.

These regions—those exposed to international competition, those reliant on small and medium-sized enterprises, those where access to credit is most vital—are today being victimized by this process and even risk depression.
Commissioner, President of the Eurogroup, the success of the euro depends on the trust that European citizens place in it.
The most powerful European countries have initiated processes to revitalize their national economies.
We have the case, in particular, of initiatives relating to the automotive industry.
But Europe is more than that.
It must be considerably more than the more or less coordinated sum of national policies.
The time has come to transform the euro into a central tool of Europe, supporting both a robust currency and a robust real economy, and to ensure the functioning of the euro.
of mechanisms that guarantee the central objective of achieving social and regional convergence, because it is at the heart, it is the core of the European project.
The debate regarding the coordination of economic policies within the euro area today has a strengthened and undeniable impact and relevance.
But coordinating national policies is not enough.
More is required.

We have a Lisbon strategy that is a summation of national initiatives and a stability and growth pact that differentially tightens the various countries involved and to which one must submit; these are limitations to which is added the limited budget we have at our disposal.
Crises generate opportunities.
The Monetary Union can only be sustained on a convergence of well-being among the member states that comprise it, irrespective of and for their citizens, irrespective of where they were born.
What other way would we have of mobilizing citizens for the single currency?

The Commission must live up to its own diagnosis, and that is why we eagerly await the concrete proposals that the Commission will bring to this plenary on November 26th and present to European citizens.

It is essential that, emerging from this crisis, a new phase of the Union be launched, in which the consolidation and strength of the financial system are accompanied by genuine prosperity built on cohesion and an economic citizenship as well.

Thank you, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. This oral question presented to the European Commission by Gerardo Galiotta on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development of this Parliament is entirely justified and pertinent.

In truth, it is necessary to clarify the reasons leading the Council to block the reform of the Solidarity Fund, given its inability to reach an agreement on a common position that would allow the legislative process to proceed.
It is difficult to discontinue the reasons that may underlie the Council’s position, except perhaps for petty financial considerations.
Doesn’t the Council desire a more agile and immediate response to natural disasters?

I do not wish for the Council to allow this type of celebratory response to be given to other types of catastrophes, such as serious industrial accidents, terrorist attacks, or grievous situations in terms of public health.

It is important that these questions have a clear answer, just as it is also important to clarify the European Commission’s view on this situation and whether it intends to take any measures aimed at unlocking the legislative process.
The value of solidarity must also be fully realized in this area.
citizens would not fully understand if that were not the case.
I wish to state that I wanted to protest against the statement made by Mrs. Luling, which seeks to condition the votes of the deputies in this House, and that conditioning makes no sense.

The interpretation you are offering is one that we do not share, and it is in this sense only that I would like to ask my colleagues who understand what they are dealing with, who know that we are defending other interests – the interests of public health and the interests of citizens and of countries – to actually vote in favor of the report. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, for two months now, the political and media agenda has been dominated by the financial and economic crisis.
The referendum in Ireland or the difficulties in the Czech Republic regarding the Treaty of Lisbon receive scant coverage in the media.

Doesn't it seem that now the Commission's information and communication strategy should be reinforced with the necessity and urgency of the Lisbon Treaty coming into force, also as a political response to confront and overcome the crisis in which we are living?
Madam President in office, Commissioner, dear colleagues, the powers of the world currently have the international financial system in their grasp.
they sought to intervene, and it was not a moment too soon.
And therefore, perhaps it is time to resolve another problem we have heard about for decades.
For decades, we have heard this music of the ignoble plundering of resources, how many times, as now once again in the Congo, over the blood of the populations.

I believe it is also the time to pursue these companies, to pursue this real estate trade, to freeze the accounts through which the profits of shame from this mineral resource exploitation, at the expense of the blood and suffering of the populations, circulate and are deposited.
I don’t understand why these companies are not listed in the same way we have already compiled a blacklist of terrorist organizations.

And I don’t understand why the international community is unable to pursue these businesspeople, who in truth are not businesspeople at all, but genuine bandits that jeopardize regional and global security.
I urge the French presidency and the Commission to support an international initiative to that effect. Thank you very much.
We have heard here today on several occasions that a crisis typically generates an opportunity, and that is indeed the case.
And, if we wish to take advantage of the opportunity that is open to us, the agenda is easy to ascertain.
Firstly, we know, at the European Union level, the need we have to introduce mechanisms of transparency, regulation, and supervision in financial markets.
It is not necessary for Commissioner Macrivi to launch further consultations, nor is it required that the Presidency analyze and invoke additional studies.
more proposals. It is enough to look at the proposals that were promptly made by the socialists and that many of them were subsequently adopted by this Parliament.
Secondly, internationally, Europe cannot exist in the international space passively.

She must be an active agent in the construction of the new international order. She must be the advocate for a new architecture that does not leave black holes in the system, as tax havens do at present.
Thirdly, we heard here today the President of the Commission state that there is a reluctance in coordinating strategies at the level of the different Member States.
It is true that, had we not heard, from many members of the Commission for so long, that markets self-regulate and that the State should remain outside,
that financial markets have no impact on growth or employment, perhaps there would be a more active and effective spirit of solidarity at the level of different countries.
But today the proposal we have in hand is a proposal that amounts to no more than a first step. If we compare it with the programs of China and the United States, on the other hand, it...
does not sufficiently clarify what the objective is, and the objective must be employment, and thirdly, because a European program cannot be a summation of national agendas.
Today is the time for us to demonstrate to the citizens of Europe that Europe is a network of rights, also economic rights, that protect them in terms of crisis and in terms of security.
solidarity, a growth program, and support for small and medium-sized enterprises that, at this moment, are not seeing the results of the interventions carried out at the banking level.
The real economy is precisely that, and we are here as Europeans to show citizens that Europe is here too, and above all, because of them. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, it is with particular satisfaction that I appear before you to present the work that was carried out jointly with everyone in this initiative report.
For me and for all those who collaborated in the unfolding of this process, we can say that we did our work.

To everyone, in particular the shadow rapporteurs from the different political groups who worked tirelessly to reach agreements for the future, to the regional development staff, always available, notably Miguel Tel Cremades and Elisa da Farra,

To the staff of the PSE, to Lila and Petros, to the European Commission, which consistently made itself represented by the many diverse directorates-general that such a comprehensive report requires, followed the work closely and permanently, and exerted considerable effort to ensure its successful completion.
to my office and, in particular, to Joana Benzinho, my sincere thanks to all of you for a more harmonious and structured development of coastal regions and for tourism within the European Union.
The 27 Member States of the European Union collectively possess over 89,000 kilometers of coastline.
This exhibits a variety of very particular characteristics that, depending on their location, are marked either by cosmopolitanism, when speaking of cities like Lisbon, Copenhagen, or Stockholm, or

due to the difficulties of existing in peripheral or ultraperipheral regions, with problems of connectivity to major urban centers or in contexts of accelerated desertification, such as the Algarve, Liguria, the Canary Islands, or Madeira.
One way or another, everyone identifies with the concept of coast and coastal zone and lives daily with the advantages and disadvantages associated with them.
According to available data, by 2010, approximately 75% of humanity will reside in coastal zones.
According to the circuits and relationships between them, we define as the 50 km in a straight line that extends from the coastline to inland areas.
Yes, regions and not detached maritime zones lacking an integrated vision that these matters so desperately need and that our ancestors would also endorse.
Here, this population will concentrate in pursuit of opportunities and economic synergies, and in many cases, with the expectation that these will revolve around tourism.
Thus, the evident need for a pragmatic and integrated vision of the impact of tourism on coastal zones took hold of our minds and led us to take action.

In the current context of financial crisis, in which the impact on the real economy becomes increasingly insurmountable, tourism emerges as a sector with enormous potential to be directly or indirectly affected in a brutal manner.

Regions that, for their development, have an overwhelming or total dependence on this, see their activity threatened and view the future with distrust. Especially because tourism is not, presently, a competence of the European Union.
Nevertheless, articulated measures must be taken, and the spirit imbued in the Treaty of Lisbon reflects this very tendency.
However, waiting until the treaty’s entry into force to begin acting is waiting for the stage at which we will lament spilt milk.
The current political activity surrounding tourism and the fragile reality of the regions that depend on it demand urgent and effective action from us.

The fact that these are structurally tourism-dependent zones, as an employment generator—despite often being seasonal employment—cannot be overlooked in a context of pressure on urban areas and unemployment.

Therefore, this report that we now present to you, which was already of the greatest opportunity and urgency when the Committee on Regional Development of this House decided to promote it, should now be viewed, from this moment forward, as a priority for the European Commission and the European Council.

Priority, yes, to the numerous initiatives that this incorporates, as well as I believe it assumes your expressed support, and which have already been disseminated by other institutions, alongside the measures adopted in the emergency plan.

of the Commission, among which I highlight the review of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in which the issues associated with this sector and the shock it is currently experiencing should, obviously, be encompassed.

It is crucial to ensure the development of new segments of the economy in these coastal zones, guaranteeing their social and environmental sustainability and promoting the real integration of different sectoral policies such as the maritime sector, transportation, and...

energy, the instruments of cohesion already on the ground, the new policy on quality products that the revision of the CAP incorporates with the announcement of the Elsen Scheme and the new tourist products in these coastal zones, taking into account their crucial contribution to the European economy.
The implementation of an appropriate and holistic vision for this policy should soon become a reality within the European Union.

And to conclude, Mr. President, only with a clear articulation of these instruments and swift, effective action involving all partners and stakeholders already on the ground, can we guarantee that we will have in the European Union a sustainable and forward-looking coastal tourism sector. Thank you very much.
Mr. Commissioner and Madam Minister, E-Justice is an important step in accessing the law, justice, and courts.
I would like to congratulate you on this initiative and commend the rapporteur and the French Presidency.

The Ex-Justice project was one of those under discussion, and it falls to Portugal, during its presidency, to lead the development and implementation of the pilot project that will allow all citizens access to services from other Member States in a simpler, cheaper, more comfortable manner, and in their own language.
This multilingual portal should be designed to serve citizens and businesses seeking legal support and basic legal advice regarding legal and cross-border issues.
E-Justice should be coordinated and managed by a responsible unit, which will also coordinate the contributions of the various Member States and their articulation with that responsible unit.
The former Justice will serve the citizen and strengthen our democracy.
I congratulate you on the launch of the portal in December 2009. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Barro, colleagues, I commend the work of Carlos Coelho, from the former Martin Rur headquarters, and of so many former headquarters staff.
In December 2004, the Council adopted the Regulation establishing standards for the security features and biometric data of passports and travel documents issued by Member States.
Now, we needed to take new steps in order to combat the abduction and trafficking of children.
The use of passports by children, in accordance with the principle of one person, one passport, may be the fundamental means of overcoming this difficult and important challenge.

In my country, Portugal, the collection of fingerprints from children aged 6 and above is already an established practice with a long tradition, which perhaps explains why it does not cause me any objection.
As a champion of the European cause, I believe that, in this matter, harmonization is important.
It reassures me to know that Member States, such as Portugal, which have long established six years of age as the minimum for collecting fingerprints, will not have to alter national legislation.
I must emphasize that the security of passports being strengthened today does not solely rely on the existence of the passport itself.

The passport, in and of itself, corresponds to an increase in the level of security, which ranges from the presentation of the necessary documents for passport issuance, followed by the collection of biometric data, to verification and matching at cross-border control points.
This report represents a further step in affirming the rights of the individual and ensuring their safety.
Mr. President, firstly, I would like to welcome the rapporteur, Alexander Lambsdorff, and the shadow rapporteurs, with particular mention of Bárbara Weiler.
Dear colleagues, I believe it is essential that we move forward towards the integration of national defense markets and even the strategic coordination of their productions.

We must proceed, effectively, with the specificities and necessary precautions towards the application of the essential rules of the internal market to the defense industries, increasing transparency in the competitions that are organized and the contracts that are signed, involving Member States of the European Union.
However, at the same time, we must assist in the development of conditions that allow for greater competitiveness of European equipment and products in global markets.

Commissioner Macrifi. It seems important to me that this directive can guarantee progress in the legal framework concerning public procurement in the areas of defence and security, advancing the construction of the market.

internal, respecting, obviously, the interests and rights of the Member States, especially in the field of security, and, notably, of manufacturers of armaments, ammunition and security equipment, such as, for example, my own country.

Mr. President, I would also underscore the provisions that facilitate easier access for small and medium-sized enterprises to this market, notably through the improvement of subcontracting rules and the prospect of thus advancing with greater impact and depth within the sector.

industrial towards the creation of a genuine European market in the defence industries, which may also contribute to reinforcing research and development not only in the defence industries but also in a range of European industries that benefit from the development of the defence industries.
To conclude, it is possible to refer to the obvious articulation between defense industries and the European Union’s foreign policies.
But I would like to cite, regarding the matter, a recent intervention translating a classic Roman saying: If you want peace, prepare for war.

The European Union, as we almost consider a peaceful superpower, refers to these industries as defense industries and not war industries, because we desire peace, not war, and for that reason, we also need defense industries.
Mr. Vice-President Barro, I agree with you; I agree with you regarding the dissatisfaction.
In truth, we must be dissatisfied with the entirety of the measures, which are extensive.
The truth is that irregular immigration continues to Europe, human trafficking continues, there are zones where there is a great deal…
immigration, particularly in the Mediterranean towards Italy. France has advanced with a set of important bilateral cooperations, but other Member States have not done so.
It is necessary that the Commission continue, without losing enthusiasm, in this policy of cooperation and assistance to the Member States.
Madam President, Commissioner, I will attempt to present the issues in a very concise manner.
First point, the matter of the European Union’s special monitoring mechanism for testing, which ended, as stated here, on December 31, 2008.
It is lacking, Madam Commissioner, the timely and routine publication of statistical data on imports, exports, and prices, as occurs in the United States.
Without this data, the European Union is unable to react against potential unfair practices, and the Commission itself becomes incapable of defining its strategy.
I would appreciate your attention to this, similarly to what other colleagues have done.
Secondly, producing within the European Union increasingly requires compliance with safety regulations, social standards, and environmental norms.
The RITS, for example, is a recent initiative that creates further constraints for us.
It is important that the Commission has a clear strategy that is perceptible and capable of monitoring, so that imported products have identical requirements.
In what way are these aspects duly considered in the ongoing free trade agreements?
And as for Maidin, can Maidin actually help resolve this issue?
Third point: The European Union has launched an economic recovery plan to combat the current crisis.
What role will trade policy play in this context?

At this moment, what is the Commission preparing to do when a series of other countries, such as China, begin to proliferate the imposition of increasingly numerous non-tariff barriers to prevent our European imports from accessing Chinese markets?

What proposal do you have regarding the updating or adjustment of the Globalization Fund, as well as the support available within structural funds to improve the immediate situation of the European textile industry?
Final question, last of all, in fact, will the crisis we are experiencing finally make the Commission sensitive to the devastating impact on the European economy of an overvalued euro?
How can the Commissioner, and I conclude here, sensitize her colleagues and the entities dealing with European monetary policy to rebalance? Thank you very much.
It is clear to us that we should applaud the Obama decision, the decision to close Guantánamo, to prohibit the torture of illegal interrogations, and to suspend military proceedings.
However, dear colleague, who is no longer present, Portugal and the Portuguese socialist government feel no sense of guilt.
The Portuguese socialist government did not collaborate with the Bush administration; quite the contrary.

It was precisely during the Portuguese administration, with the Portuguese government, with the initiative of Minister Luís Amado, that the possibility and the duty of the European Union and democratic countries to welcome and receive the detainees without formed guilt in Guantánamo were triggered.

This is what truly matters, this is what should be highlighted as an example to be followed by the remaining Member States of the European Union. How important it is that the resolution be approved tomorrow by all the parties that comprise this Chamber, so that, in unity, the decision may have greater force.
Mr. President, thank you to my colleague Napolitano for the excellent report.

14 years after Barcelona and 5 years after the first Euro-Mediterranean Parliamentary Assembly, we have the Union for the Mediterranean, with economic power, parliamentary power, civil society, and heads of government deciding together.
All eager to do more and better in a territory where 720 million citizens represent potential for development and peace for the world.
To confine them solely to the economic and business sphere is a clear error.

Responding to growth crises naturally requires political action, but responding to humanitarian crises, emergency situations, and military crises, such as the one experienced at the end of 2008 and the beginning of 2009, is crucial.
Politicians and citizens must provide answers to the world's problems.
The world asked for answers, and months later, we citizens and politicians alike, particularly within a forum such as the Union for the Mediterranean, continue to delay in responding.
I hope that, at the very least, this moment has served to learn and progress, for one only learns through mistakes, but progressing in the acceleration of the response is absolutely crucial.
The interest in approving this directive proposal lies essentially in the way it can contribute to stimulating economic activity at the local level and supporting actions at the social level.
This application of a reduced rate is of great importance in the housing sector, both in construction and renovation, allowing Member States to adopt it and reduce the cost for the end user.

The provision of local services, particularly by small businesses, can also benefit from this reduction in the DIVA rate, securing and generating more and better employment through the promotion of the consumption of goods and services, thereby stimulating the economy itself.
The restoration activity, fundamental for the good functioning of local economies and the increase of tourism itself, can significantly benefit at the local level from this reduction in VAT taxation.
These services, dear colleagues, should not circulate within the European internal market, which will help to reduce the reserves of some Member States already verified in the Council’s plan.
Therefore, I cannot agree with the extension of this reduced rate to equipment, whatever the protest.

The prudent manner in which this proposal should be handled in the European Parliament should not give governments with some reservations regarding the European Commission’s proposal the pretext of practically using the right of veto that European legislation still grants them in fiscal matters.
And so here, one must prudently reject alterations lacking substantial merit that only hinder the acceptance of the text.
As has been mentioned previously, not only is the excellent the enemy of the good, but he who wants everything loses everything.
This proposed directive is important not only for strengthening local economies, but also because it aligns with ambitions repeatedly expressed by various Member States.

We therefore support the Commission's proposal as it was presented. Indeed, that was the tenor of the vote, as my agreement, and that of the Internal Market and Consumer Protection Committee, indicates.

Appreciation for the rapporteurs' work and an appeal for the approval of this proposal in its exact terms as presented by the Commission and as voted on by the Parliamentary Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. Thank you very much.
The word to disagree with my colleague Edith Estrela, and indeed that was what motivated me to speak. When she caricatured the intentions of the Czech Presidency.
No one wants to send women home. The problem is that there are women who want or would like to stay at home.
Even associations seek to defend them, women who are ignored, disdained, discriminated against, because they want to dedicate themselves to their families, and we do not hear them.
And that is a matter of freedom, a matter of freedom of choice that the left so often likes to invoke, but which they forget here.
It concerns respecting or not the freedom of orientation of couples.
It is about being able to provide those who wish to do so with a higher quality of life, and more quality parenting – both fatherhood and motherhood.
That is what our society also needs to do.
We will not go there; we will not resolve the problems of birth rates and people's happiness with prejudices.
We address challenges with policies tailored to reality and people’s genuine aspirations.
Let us not go there with an obsession with the State and the market.
Let's proceed with a fair look at the family.
Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, the difficult situation at Quimonda was exacerbated by the emergence of the financial and economic crisis.
The Portuguese government has done everything it considers appropriate and useful to help resolve the situation.
We would also like the Bavarian Government to know that it, too, must act with a great sense of responsibility in this area.
Saving the Munich facilities will have a decisive impact on the Vila do Conde and Dresden units.

The Portuguese minister himself, Manuel Pinho, affirmed the great interest in making this company viable, a company so important for Portugal and for Europe, stating that Quimonda could be a competitive company on a global level.
Mr. President, the Government of Portugal will maintain its efforts toward a solution that guarantees the company’s viability.
We hope that German governments, at both the federal and state levels, will genuinely commit to resolving this issue.
As for me, I would like to reiterate the strategic importance of maintaining this type of industry within European territory.
that no national or state executive commit the error of allowing this company to close facilities and liquidate jobs within the Union’s territory.

Dear colleagues, we understand the need to assist in the restructuring of large automotive industry groups, but the Union's funds and the European Commission’s efforts cannot be exhausted in these forms of assistance.

Dear Commissioner, committing the Commission to supporting Quimonda, overcoming potential communication shortcomings, is the appeal we make to Commissioner Vladimir Spidla, to whom we are bound by ties of work and political solidarity, and to President Barroso, who will never forget that he is our compatriot and of a significant portion of Quimonda's workers.

We must emphasize, before concluding, that the Portuguese president Cavaco Silva, in Germany, recently stated that there was new hope regarding Quimonda. And it remains to be mentioned the importance, as colleagues have already pointed out, of the very economic sector in which Quimonda operates.
We take note that the Portuguese government has stated its willingness to support Quimonda with whatever is necessary, considering the country’s economic dimensions.
Ladies and gentlemen, let us help save Quimonda? Time is of the essence.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we have been discussing the Lisbon Strategy for years, and the times we are living through may not be the most opportune for talking about the Lisbon Strategy, but undoubtedly we need a strategy.
in a strategy that responds to the difficulties and challenges that the current crisis places before us.
And that is what we also expect from the Commission.

It is essential that the Commission does not deviate from this matter and, instead, has the capacity to coordinate actions with the governments of Portugal, the governments of Germany, and German lenders.

It is essential to bear in mind that this is an industry, as has already been stated here, that interests Europe due to its quality and value, the research it develops, and also the environmental quality associated with it, and it is indispensable that the Commission does not deviate.
I second the invitation extended by my colleague, Pineda, for the Commissioner and the Commission to travel to Portugal.

It is essential that the Commission bear in mind that, at this moment, Europeans are looking to Europe and expect answers from European authorities. They need to feel that European authorities are close.

European citizens do not understand a Europe that washes its hands of responsibility. Rather, they want a Europe that has the audacity to get its hands dirty and set to work, helping them overcome difficulties. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, thank you very much. I too join the tributes to Jamonet, but I requested the floor to commend Mr. President for the statement he made regarding European Day in Memory of the Victims of Terrorism.
It was at my proposal that, five years ago, we adopted this approach that the Council enshrined at a meeting on March 25th, following the tragic attacks in Madrid.
but my intervention was an appeal.

Parliament has always remained faithful to the celebration of this date, but, unfortunately, this date has not yet, across the European institutions and the Member States, received the projection it deserves.
I believe that the celebration of this date is one of the most important instruments we have to honor the victims, as the President did, but also to raise the level of public awareness.
I am aware that there are some celebrations in Madrid today, but little else.
Therefore, the appeal I make to the Commission, to the Czech Presidency, is that all Member States commemorate this date with dignity in the future. Thank you very much.
And my dear colleagues, the crisis is deeper than we expected, and unemployment will be higher than we predicted.
There are good reasons to assume that the planned European stimulus is insufficient, but it is already clear that it is taking too long to reach citizens.
The Parliament's position is strong and clear. It has been and I hope it will continue to be so.
Our objective is to maintain employment and to create new jobs, with cohesion, with solidarity, both territorial and social.
And at this moment of crisis, citizens cannot resign themselves to a Europe that does not respond to them, to a Europe that is powerless in the face of the problems they are experiencing.
What will the Parliament request of the Commission?

It naturally requests, through these reports, that you coordinate national interventions. It asks you to utilize all means currently at your disposal to intervene and provides you, as a budgetary entity, with all conditions to facilitate this.

It asks him to launch a clear European employment initiative and tells him that it is important to have a calendar-based agenda for implementing measures regulating the financial market, as well as bringing credit to the real economy.
But what does the Council expect?
The Council is requested to, above all, rediscover the political will that lies at the heart of the construction of the European project.
The European Union is competition, but it is equally cohesion and solidarity.
And there can be no single market without that guarantee, solidarity, and cohesion.
That is precisely why we all delegated, at the European level, the national autonomies we had before joining this project. Thank you very much.

Madam President, Commissioner, anyone visiting sub-Saharan Africa readily recognizes in most countries the enormous weakness of their healthcare systems and the extremely negative impact that this weakness has on the lives and health of the populations those services should serve.
The internationally disseminated indicators consistently confirm this.

And, in that sense, it is profoundly disturbing to consider that simple gestures and even relatively uncomplicated practices, not particularly expensive either, could be sufficient to save many lives.

European financial support can be crucial in this regard, and we must always bear in mind how cooperation in the field of health is truly strategic and directly addresses not only one of the Millennium Development Goals, but many of them.

Now, the Court of Accounts considered that, I quote, community funding for the health sector has not increased since 2000 in proportion to its total development aid, despite the commitments undertaken by the Commission regarding the Millennium Development Goals and the health crisis in sub-Saharan Africa.
Do it.

And it recognized, I quote again, that the Commission contributed significantly, through its funding, to the establishment of the Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria, but did not grant the same attention to strengthening health systems, which was expected to be one of its priorities.
Finis, citation.

According to the Court, this occurred, I cite again, because the Commission lacked sufficient experience in health matters to ensure that the funding of the aid it granted to this sector was utilized in the best possible way.
Feign.
This is, therefore, a strong challenge that the Court of Auditors is directly issuing to the European Commission, and one that I support.
On our side, I want to reiterate that same challenge, now grounded in the objectivity of this data and this assessment.
Healthcare services are already part of our development assistance priorities, but they should increasingly be so, deserving of increased funding.

Optimizing the manner in which assistance is provided, mindful of the seemingly antagonistic needs of coordination in its management and proximity to beneficiary populations, is to deliver a service that can save many lives.
The European Commission cannot fail to respond positively to this challenge, and it is in that spirit that I urge it.
Colleague Bowies, just now, gave a moving presentation here and was able to put faces, human faces, on the stark dryness of these figures from the Court of Accounts.
The challenge for us, Madam Commissioner, is for our cooperation to be capable of placing a look of joy and hope in those very faces.
And for that, Madam Commissioner, it is essential that different figures are used in the health area within our cooperation.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues, once again, for sad reasons, we are discussing here the situation in Guinea-Bissau, which is a truly lamentable situation.
It is a country that has lived with chronic instability for many years, which charted a path to democracy in the early 1990s.

Nothing went well; there was a coup d'état, a minor internal conflict, and the country exists in significant political and military instability, marked by tensions, deep rivalries, and now, recently, also the increasingly concerning and evident presence, for all observers, of drug trafficking interests.

We strongly condemn these attacks, the bombing death of the Chief of the General Staff Tagume Naoué, and also the assassination, in particularly barbaric terms, to say nothing of savage, of President Nineviera.
Regardless of your past, we express our solidarity with your families, the people of Guinea-Bissau, and deeply regret and strongly condemn these attacks.
We wish for a return to normality and the lesson I draw and would like to underscore in the resolution is that impunity is not a remedy.
In the past, concerning the murder of Asuman Mané and the newspaper Verissim Siabra, how did [someone/it] turn a blind eye to ensuring that the perpetrators were not found and brought before justice?
Clearly, I sought new sources.

And therefore, we must make it clear to the State of Guinea-Bissau that those responsible must be found, the guilty must be brought before justice, and we must provide all the assistance that is necessary.

I would also like to draw attention, to conclude, to the concern with which we hear of the presence of drug trafficking throughout the region, the risk this represents also for the European Union, and the shocking presence, given its evident nature, in Guinea-Bissau.
I would also like to appeal for us to address, within this context, the relationship with Cape Verde.

We have established a special partnership with Cabo Verde. Cabo Verde has very close relations with Guinea, a significant knowledge base, but is also very vulnerable, which is essential for our own European security as well.
Therefore, the intensification of the special partnership with Cabo Verde is also very important in this context. Thank you very much.
Madam President, esteemed colleagues, I would first of all like to thank everyone for the work celebrated.

The three lines defined in the Green Book, concentration, interconnection, and cooperation, can provide solutions to some obstacles to the harmonious development of the Union, notably the negative effects associated with…

concentration of economic activity, to inequalities in access to markets and services resulting from distance and the divisions imposed, whether by borders between Member States, particularly those most disadvantaged, but also between regions.
We must, therefore, promote the improvement of synergies between these policies with effective methods for evaluating their territorial impact.

Therefore, I have always advocated for the definition of supplementary qualitative indicators with the objective of improving the conception and execution of the corresponding policies on the ground, taking into account the different territorial specificities.
For the time being, GDP remains the sole eligibility criterion for receiving support from the structural funds.

However, this definition of supplementary indicators and the undertaking of territorial assessments should not be the origin of further bureaucracy or delays, but rather of simplification in the application of new policies and support actions for territorial cohesion.

The fifth interim report, and to conclude, Mr. President, makes a specific reference to the transition regions situated between the convergence regions and the regions of competitiveness and employment.
It is necessary to note that these regions require a clearer status, with greater security and stability for their development. Thank you very much.

Madam Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, within the context of this major debate on territorial cohesion and the future of economic and social cohesion policy, I could not fail to mention the very specific challenges facing ultra-peripheral regions.

regions that, due to the combination and persistence of a series of geographical factors, exhibit significant economic and social vulnerability, particularly felt within a context of a severe international crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing.
I would therefore like to appeal to the European Commission and, in particular, to Commissioner Hübner, to pay very close attention to the effects of the current crisis on the outermost regions.

An assessment of these effects in each of the outermost regions, particularly in tourism, construction, and the rise in unemployment, would be important to enable a European response specifically tailored to these regions.

Therefore, I challenge the European Commission to prepare a European response to the crisis for the outermost regions that goes beyond the measures already announced under the economic and social cohesion policy for all European regions.
a specific European response to the crisis for the outermost regions.

President, esteemed colleagues, in response to the global financial crisis, the European Economic Recovery Plan states that cohesion policy contributes significantly to public investment by Member States and regions, and should act as a means of recovery from the current crisis.
It specifically suggests the adoption of actions in priority areas of Lisbon's strategy, in order to achieve growth and employment.
All operating instruments seek to achieve this purpose and accelerate the attainment of results.

In this context, the broadening of the scope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund and the streamlining of the European Social Fund, in particular, bear the responsibility of responding to the multiple social and economic emergency situations that require support.
I am certain, today as in the past, that your action will be all the more effective the more complementary your actions and scopes are.

However, as the allocation of new funding or new lines of action has not been foreseen, it is particularly important that the European Social Fund be used to its full potential in combating unemployment and the rapid increase in competitive pressure on the European economy, resulting from the current financial crisis and economic slowdown.

I would like to emphasize that the Regional Committee has repeatedly identified simplification as essential for improving the management and implementation of structural funds, as the European Commission now proposes.

We were requested to expedite matters, however, in this instance. And in the adoption of this regulatory package, we took it into consideration. And this cause never shied away from assuming its political responsibilities.

Therefore, despite numerous serious considerations raised by the specific nature of the moment, in the interest of ensuring the process's expediency and the actual benefit to citizens that the proposal intends to provide, we refrain, for the time being, from presenting new proposals and alterations.

However, we would like to alert you to the need to initiate, from now on, an evaluation process of this fund with a view to a complementary revision to be carried out as soon as possible. Thank you very much.
Madam President, the crisis, among other aspects, allowed for the highlighting of significant imbalances between the countries of the Eurozone, perhaps the primary...
conclusion of the Economic and Monetary Union report 10, but, above all, the extreme vulnerability of countries that, belonging to the European Union, do not belong to the euro zone.

Therefore, strengthening the resources available at the European level to support balance of payments crises is absolutely essential, and therefore we welcome the increase from 12 to 25 and then to 50 million euros in necessary funds.
However, more important is to address the root causes of problems and not merely their most evident manifestations.
Today, the expanded Europe and the euro area must reinterpret the meaning of European solidarity and the objectives of cohesion and genuine convergence.
It is necessary to examine the capacity of European horizontal policies, but it is also necessary to revisit new financing instruments, such as eurobonds.
Financial assistance to balance of payments is necessary, but falls far short of being sufficient to guarantee the sustainability of the European project and the single European currency.
Mr. Chairman of the Committee, Mr. Justice President, we are in an unprecedented crisis.

It was, in fact, not the time to discuss internally how we should organize ourselves. Therefore, my hope is that the Treaty of Lisbon will be rapidly ratified so that we can face the world united and in solidarity as Europeans.

Regarding the economic crisis, in the report of which I was the author and which this Parliament largely approved, it was acknowledged that the recovery plan, subsequently presented by the Commission, was insufficient.
Today, we are certain that he is not sufficient.
A crisis that began financially extends to the real economy, then to employment, and subsequently becomes social.
He is insufficient and unfocused.

Each crisis holds an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission to respond to the genuine problems of Europeans, through serious financial regulation and not through the most superficial piecemeal measures.

possible, as it is underway. Not composed of national and individualistic plans, but of a genuine European initiative. Not through scattered means, but by concentrating on the real challenge that is employment.

In every crisis there is an opportunity. This is the opportunity for the Commission and for Europe to respond to the genuine problems of European citizens. And I hope that this happens through a new approach to the recovery plan. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, I merely wished to express, not only on behalf of the EPP, as many deputies have already done, but particularly on behalf of the Portuguese deputies of the EPP, the great satisfaction with the result of the referendum in Ireland.
We believe that this clearly reinforces the prospects of development and devolution within the European Union, creating conditions for a new stage.

We naturally wished to greet all those who contributed to the Treaty of Lisbon, in particular the Commission and the Vice-President Commissioner present here, and also, naturally, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union.

It played a very important role here, and therefore we also want to say that it is with pleasure that we note that, despite all these vicissitudes and while still awaiting the position of the Czech Republic, the Portuguese will see with great joy the name of their capital linked.

at a decisive step in the evolution of the European Union and I wanted to say that we can also count, from this perspective, on another flag that will also be a flag always of the Portuguese MEPs from the PPE, which is the flag of National Parliaments.
We believe that the Treaty of Lisbon represents a decisive step towards incorporating the presence of national Parliaments into European democracy as well.

And therefore we believe that this dimension, which is the most important dimension of democracy, which is the representative dimension, and not, as we sometimes hear in this Chamber, the referendary dimension, that which is…

A fundamental and essential element of democracy is representation, not direct voting; furthermore, the Treaty of Lisbon represents a significant step towards increasing the participation of national representative democracies in the European process.
Therefore, we are very pleased with this decision of the Irish people.

Mr. President, Madam Minister, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. A brief intervention to welcome the historic and extensive result of the referendum in Ireland and to highlight the decisive role that Fine Gael and its leader and incoming Prime Minister of Ireland, Enda Kenny, played in assuming leadership of this process.
a process in which the need to bring the European Union much closer to its citizens became strikingly clear.
We are they, we are all of us, the primary recipients of all Union action.
It is essential that everyone be aware of the impact and benefits that Europe has daily on our lives.
Europe is our Lebensraum.
What is good for Europe is good for each Member State, is good for its citizens.
It is certainly the case of the Treaty of Lisbon.
With this treaty, it becomes much more evident that one can be, simultaneously, a proud and committed national citizen and a staunch defender of the European project.

And the European Union, concluding a protracted debate on its organization and functioning, can now focus much more effectively and with considerably more effective instruments on the genuine problems facing Europeans: competitiveness, growth, and employment.
I conclude, Mr. President, Madam Minister, with a proposal aimed at future generations.

Considering the deficit of information regarding the values, competencies, objectives, and mode of operation of the European Union, the European Parliament should propose, at the end of compulsory schooling in each Member State, a new, compulsory subject of European studies.
Objectively, truthfully, and concretely, young Europeans will genuinely learn our principles, who we are, what we do, and where we want to go.

It is through the knowledge of these young people that they will understand throughout their lives the potential and the enormous utility of the European identity of this unique project of voluntary sharing of sovereignty on a continental scale.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. Chairman of the Committee, I begin by greeting you in this first debate regarding what this new instrument of political control means for the advancement and development of parliamentary democracy in Europe.
It is European citizens, through their representatives, who stand to gain.

Considering the most recent developments, the Irish referendum, Polish ratification, and the latest statements by the President of the Czech Republic, I would like to know your assessment of the process of entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon.
Due diligence was undertaken by the President of the Commission.
and what is its prediction regarding a potential date of entry into force of the Treaty, and on the other hand, to ascertain whether, at this moment and in light of that prediction, the Commission

Some transitional arrangements regarding treaties have already been undertaken, transitioning from the Treaty of Nice to the Treaty of Lisbon, or if it is still in, let’s say, a phase of expectancy, therefore a phase of waiting to see.

Mr. Chairman of the Commission, having heard that, I would like to know the following. At this stage, when everyone is awaiting the formation of the Commission, what, fundamentally, is the perspective that you, Mr. Chairman, have?

is whether we will now, until that moment of final ratification by the Czech Republic, have a management commission or whether they will proceed with the nomination procedures for the new Commissioners.

Thank you, Mr. President. It is fundamental that the primary objective of establishing the European External Action Service embodies the effort of European institutions, ensuring the creation of an effective service capable of articulating, formulating, and implementing a European response to today's international challenges.
It must also represent more than the sum of its parts. It should be a value added relative to the current efforts of the Member States and the European Union.
In this sense, it seems essential to me that what defines the specificity of the Union be at the center of this new reality. And that specificity is the Community method.
That is why I give my full support to the Brok report, which defends and safeguards a close coordination between the Commission and the future Service.

I would like to highlight two aspects in this regard. The importance of close coordination between the President of the Commission and the High Representative, who is also Vice-President of the Commission, to ensure its effectiveness and proper functioning.
Finally, the need for an alliance between the Parliament and the Commission to combat the looming intergovernmental drift that could compromise the effective functioning of the Service.
Parliament must, therefore, remain vigilant and ensure that the European Union Diplomatic Service will be a center of excellence representative of the best expertise in external policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Mr. Commissioner. First and foremost, I want to underscore the importance of the issue raised by Deputy Golarenksy, because it is a matter of the most fundamental justice.

We are all perfectly aware that in a situation of an influenza A pandemic, it will be the countries of the South that will suffer the most from this problem and from the consequences of the virus's proliferation, and not the countries of the North.

And we witness every year, with total passivity, the death of millions of citizens as a result of pandemics that have either been eradicated or have treatments in Northern countries. An immense list: malaria, dengue fever, yellow fever, tuberculosis.
We have no limits for this list and we passively observe this problem.

We effectively utilize the Southern countries as free providers of samples of new viral strains so that we can improve treatment in Northern countries, but nevertheless remain without an effective response to these problems. And therefore, to the questions that were raised, I would only like to add a few more.
We want to effectively treat this problem as a public health issue or as a business.
Because, if it is viewed as a public health problem, we must ensure equal access to treatment in all regions of the world and, to achieve this, efforts must be more effective.
On the other hand, I would like to ask—and I hope this is not the case—whether we are anticipating that, ultimately, vaccine stocks in Europe will become excessively abundant.
that the side effects prove so negative in this instance, and only then do we have an act of generosity and suddenly begin sending the necessary vaccines to Southern countries.

Finally, I would simply like to ask whether the European Union, whether we Europeans, whether the Commission feels comfortable with a system or a model where countries in the North manage pandemics through a prevention model, and in countries in the South it is treated as palliative care or merely with leftovers.

Thank you, Mr. President. Firstly, I want to express my full support regarding the issue raised by Mr. Royal, and above all, to highlight the underlying political matter at stake here, which concerns precisely the joint programming of research.

What transpired regarding the joint programming on neurodegenerative diseases and, in particular, on Alzheimer's, was that, during the process, the rules changed; we ceased to have a report and moved to a resolution, therefore, our ability to co-decide in this area was eliminated; we ceased to be members of parliament and became consultants.
And therefore, I would like to know whether at least what we recommend will be considered or not.
The programming of research activities, regardless of the subject matter, is a political choice, not a technical one. And in this sense, the role of Parliament should be valued and strengthened.
It seems to me that defining priorities that are political means that they should be scrutinized, that they should be transparent, and that they should be democratic.
What transpired with the process concerning the joint decision-making and joint planning of the Alzheimer investigation is a process that should not be repeated.

Please repeat, and ensure timely notification. I therefore hope that the last thing that could happen to us is that the decisions and recommendations presented by Parliament on this matter are not considered.
In the last month, the regions of Europe have been particularly prominent.
European Week of Regions and Cities solidified the position of regions as a fundamental part of the solution in Europe’s response to global challenges.
Thus they concluded, leaving no room for doubt, President Durão Barroso, Commissioner Samezki, and the hundreds of debates that took place.

At the most specific level, the holding of the significant meeting of the Conference of Presidents of Europe’s Ultraperipheral Regions, which for the first time included the participation of Members of the European Parliament, constitutes a milestone in regional policy promoting European integration.
Global challenges and European responses present an excellent opportunity for a new strategy for ERP systems.

These regions, such as the Azores, beyond the permanent constraints that everyone is accustomed to hearing about, present a set of potential advantages that offer clear opportunities to achieve our progress and give a distinct advantage to Europe in new domains essential to addressing global challenges.

Therefore, it is imperative that the President of the Commission bring a definitive end to the palace coup indicated by the Commission’s no-paper, which was being prepared while we, members of parliament and European citizens, were advocating for the ratification of the Treaty of Lisbon and its importance in defending the cohesion of European territory.

Firstly, I would like to greet the rapporteurs, particularly Mr. Martin and also Mr. Corbett, and to say that, as a member of the EPP Group, I essentially identify with the proposed amendments to the Rules of Procedure.
I would, essentially, like to highlight the point that seems important to me and which has not yet been brought up here this evening, namely, the point of National Parliaments.

The democratic strengthening of the European Parliament undoubtedly results from this Rules of Procedure and the Treaty of Lisbon, but European democracy also results from the link to National Parliaments.
And what this Bylaws, this proposal, now seeks to do is precisely to create these two democratic legitimacies, to reinforce democracy.

On the one hand, the democracy resulting from the instruments of the European Parliament, from its control mechanisms, and from its legislative capacity; on the other hand, the democratic collaboration of National Parliaments through various instruments.
And therefore, here I am, let’s say, entirely in agreement with the proposals put forth.
I disagree with colleague Duff when he suggests that we should postpone the introduction of mechanisms for engagement with National Parliaments.
I believe we can do so immediately in light of the Treaty of Lisbon, and that this is very important.
I would also like to state that I support the proposal put forward by my colleagues Sayer and Brock regarding representation in the COSAC, and finally, that I do.
fully in agreement with the observations made here by colleague Brock and other colleagues regarding the primacy of Parliament and its members relative to the services of Parliament.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I congratulate the rapporteur colleague on the work developed in this report and on her intervention just now.
This new microfinance instrument will enable the granting of microcredit to small businesses and to individuals who have lost their employment and wish to create their own business and their own job.
This is very important at a time when the economic crisis is predicted to result in the loss of three and a half million jobs alone in the European Union.

As a consequence of the economic slowdown, banks have ceased to grant loans for job creation and business startups, and access to credit has become more difficult at a time when it should be more accessible.
Now, this new microfinancing mechanism will counteract the current trend of restricted access to credit, facilitating the acquisition of funds necessary for the launch of new businesses and new jobs.
The European Commission's proposal aims to reallocate €100 million from the Progress Programme’s budget to this financing instrument.
We cannot agree with this proposal.
The financial and economic crisis is equally a social crisis.
Thus, the reallocation of Progress funds, targeting the most vulnerable groups, is not at all the most suitable solution.
For this reason, the creation of a separate budget line to finance this instrument is supported, as well as an increase in the allocation to 150 million euros.

We also agree on the need to clarify within the legislation itself that the target group consists of vulnerable populations who have difficulty entering or re-entering the labor market and who face the threat of social exclusion.
Thus, the reference to specific groups should be suppressed.
Finally, we emphasize that it is essential for people to have financial support and also appropriate training. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin by greeting the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, Prime Minister Reinfeldt, both on behalf of the EPP and on behalf of the Portuguese Delegation of the EPP.
Our assessment of the Swedish Presidency is of an almost complete success, essentially in four fundamental areas.
The first in the institutional sphere, the Swedish Presidency's contribution to the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, and to the highly successful election of the President of the Commission.
For, notably, all matters related to the ratification process, it was extremely professional and met the standards expected, reflecting best practices of the European Union.
Naturally, for a country like Portugal, which played a decisive role in the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, this contribution from the Swedish Presidency is invaluable.
A second point is the climate agenda, where, naturally, the Commission’s work was also extremely important.
We must say that, from my point of view and from the point of view of many EPP deputies, it is in the area of climate change that the European Union has had the greatest success.
it is on the true front line at a global level, and this is due to the effort, both of the Swedish Presidency and, in particular, also of the Commission Presidency.
considers this balance to be very positive.
A third point is that of financial regulation, which, especially with this latest Council, took a step that we consider decisive and that may have a very significant impact on exiting the crisis.
And therefore, I would also like to congratulate you on reaching an agreement in that area.
And finally, I would like to say a word about an area that is personally very important to me, which is the Stockholm Programme and, therefore, the area of security, justice, and freedom.

I believe that I, having followed both the Tempere process and, in particular, the subsequent process in The Hague, consider this Stockholm program absolutely essential and wished to congratulate the Swedish presidency and Prime Minister Reinfeldt for it.

Thank you, Mr. President. For the recognition of professional qualifications, which has been consolidated into a single legislative act, as we know, 15 directives, leading to various practical problems in their application in the different Member States.

The difficulties are well known, and the Commission should inventory the critical points and conduct an analysis of the problematic areas that arise in the application of this important internal market instrument.
Protectionist measures, manifesting at various levels, constitute an impediment not only to the free movement of people but also to the internal market and the single market.
We should attempt to identify the ambiguous points so that the effectiveness of the directive is not undermined by distrust.
The Union is not being asked to do what the Member States should do, but there is a facilitation effort to be undertaken that helps to dismantle professional corporatism.
An improvement in the application of this directive should involve the dissemination of recognition of qualifications within the Solvit network and the EURES network, by encouraging…
common platforms, the implementation of effective contact points, and, no less importantly, should provide for the articulation of this directive with the Services Directive. Thank you.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen Members of Parliament. It is urgent that a debate be promoted regarding the Community budget and how, in the future, one can contribute to its sustainability and transparency.

The post-2013 financial framework should be built on the foundations of solidarity and territorial cohesion, values crucial for regions like Madeira, which face persistent challenges and, therefore, require ongoing support.
I would like to share with you some ideas that I believe should always be present when considering and constructing cohesion policy.

The Commission has repeatedly highlighted several aspects that seem essential to me, such as the need for greater flexibility, simplicity, efficiency, and a stronger focus on results in the definition and implementation of this policy.
But there are questions that give me some concern, especially considering the needs of the outermost regions.
In this matter, permit me three brief notes. Firstly, the current approach in terms of regions should prevail over alternative guidelines, such as, for example, value-added sectors.

A reorientation of this kind could jeopardize Objective 2, which currently benefits approximately two-thirds of European regions, and may also prove counterproductive in regions with distinct economic profiles and competitive advantages. Secondly, it seems to me that maintaining the proximity criterion in cohesion policy is vital.

It should continue to prioritize an allocation and management of structural funds from a regional perspective, rather than a national or even centralized one at the European level. Thirdly and finally, but no less importantly, I would like to recall and underscore Article 349.
349 The Treaty of Lisbon provides for special treatment of the outermost regions with regard to access to structural funds, precisely due to their economic and social situation.

Exacerbated by conditional factors and unique characteristics of a lasting nature, which manifest in these persistent difficulties and therefore necessitate the requested permanent assistance. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Given the urgency, what we witnessed in Copenhagen were several steps backward.

It is true that Copenhagen mobilized more heads of state than others, but it also created more divisions. And as a result, what happened was that we entered a situation of each for themselves, where each state can define its own goals and, furthermore, on a voluntary basis.
It should be noted that having a two-degree Celsius target or targets for funding without any clarification cannot serve as consolation to us either.
And therefore, what I think is that we must act in terms of the future. And acting in terms of the future is moving away from rhetoric and toward action.
The European Union has always wanted to be a leader, it has always stated so.
but when we arrived in Copenhagen, he ultimately hesitated, failing to define or defend the goals he had previously stated to be his goals and which he would not apply.

Therefore, what I ask is whether we will not be more just in the future, whether we will continue to allow, at the expense of this failure and the decisions of some over others, the poorest to continue bearing the heaviest cost.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I wished to denounce here what is currently happening in Portugal, where it is clear that the media
brought to light a government plan to control newspapers, to control television stations, to control radio stations, which challenges freedom of expression.
Earlier this week, a well-known journalist, Mário Crespo, had an opinion piece censored, reportedly at the suggestion, or apparent suggestion, of the Prime Minister.

In light of this, Prime Minister José Sócrates must provide substantial explanations to the country; he must explain that he is not dominating, curtailing, or censoring freedom of expression in Portugal.

The way things are going, Portugal is no longer a State of Law, but a Formal State of Law, where the Prime Minister is limited to formalities, procedures, and formalism, and is unwilling to give substantive explanations.
For Portugal, we want a substantive rule of law.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. The Green Paper on the Reform of the Common Fisheries Policy, reported on by my colleague from the Azores, Maria do Céu Patrão Neves, is a unique opportunity for a debate concerning a sector that assumes considerable importance in the balance of local development within outermost regions.

Madeira follows the current discussion with particular interest and considers it imperative that a differentiation be proposed between artisanal and industrial fleets, which should benefit from different fishing regimes.
It is fundamental to defend a principle of positive discrimination regarding limiting access to territorial waters within the exclusive economic zone to local artisanal fleets only.
In Madeira, support for the modernization of vessels is a priority, as is management that ensures the long-term conservation of a broad range of species.
Only in this way will we be able to avoid unsustainable situations for economic, environmental, and social equilibrium.
Finally, we will strive for permanent, non-time-bound support for fishing in the outermost regions.
This report concerning the European Regional Development Fund aims to broaden the eligibility of interventions in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities within our Member States.
To date, this support has applied solely to marginalized communities residing in the urban areas of the new Member States.
That is to say, given that the vast majority of these communities live in rural areas and in shelters, these communities could not benefit from support to replace substandard housing.
Essentially, this involves filling a gap and providing Member States and their regions with greater possibilities in the policy of mitigating the specific difficulties faced by these communities.

Health also extends to equal treatment for all Member States, as marginalized communities with needs for support and integration deserve our concern, regardless of the Member State to which they belong.

Upon initial reading of this important report in the fight against poverty and for human dignity, its rapid implementation within the scope of the economic recovery plan is also achieved, responding swiftly to the crisis affecting us.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. Please allow me to begin by highlighting the rapporteur’s role, Mr. Van Nistelrooy, for his work in seeking consensus on this matter and also for the availability he consistently demonstrated in incorporating other contributions into his report.
Tomorrow, we will vote on amendments to the FEDER Regulations, which assume particular importance for the so-called former Member States and also for Portugal.

These changes will allow for the extension of the use of the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) in the housing sector to benefit marginalized communities, as currently this fund can only be allocated to urban development operations.

The changes I proposed alongside other colleagues and which were approved by a large majority in the Regional Development Committee will allow former member states, and not just the new ones, as originally envisioned in the proposal, to also benefit from this financing possibility.

With this, I attempted to prevent the establishment of a precedent that I consider dangerous and which would exclude all former Member States from this and, likely, other additional uses of Community assistance.
which would make no sense, given that housing-related issues, particularly among marginalized communities, exist in both new and established Member States.

I would like to reiterate that the length of membership in the European Union should not be a criterion for the allocation of structural funds, and that this criterion should be abandoned without delay.

The negotiation of the post-2013 cohesion policy should be based on solidarity, aiming for territorial cohesion, and should be oriented towards rewarding, rather than penalizing, regions that have demonstrated exemplary performance in the utilization of Community funds.

I would like, at this moment, to essentially underscore for the Commission and the President of the Commission the manner in which they have worked with this Parliament over these months of investiture.

There is no body in the world with both executive and legislative power that is subject to the presentation of a program by its President before Parliament, and its subsequent hearing with all parliamentary groups.

parliamentarians, to a vote by an absolute and substantial majority, to bring here all the commissioners to be heard one by one with their own programs, with 3 to 4 hours of direct questioning, of questions with answers.
Someone has agreed to negotiate with Parliament a framework agreement in which they accepted, firstly, to justify and expand Parliament's powers within the scope of legislative initiative.

that accepted the principle of total access to information, whether in legislative and political action, or in international negotiations, that accepted taking into account the Parliament's opinion regarding the Commissioners, regarding the restructuring of the Commissioners.
This means, once and for all, and from my perspective, that the Commission has demonstrated, from July until now, that it is willing to have a close relationship with Parliament.

He demonstrated clearly, evidently, and unequivocally that the strategic alliance of the Treaty of Lisbon for the community method of which colleague Sariusz Wolski spoke is the alliance between the Parliament and the Commission.
