And therefore, the Commission and the Framework Agreement deserve the full support of the EPP.
Mr. President, five years after the Orange Revolution, Ukrainians appear to view this period as a missed opportunity.
and the blame isn't solely with your political elites.
It is true that these were consumed too much in power and influence struggles.
that many reforms remained unfulfilled, many never progressed beyond the paper they were written on.
It is inconceivable that, in any democracy, electoral laws should be altered between the two rounds of an election.
It does not signify who proposed them, who voted for them, or who promulgated them.
and translates the unpraiseworthy and undesirable intentions in its agenda.
Much remains to be changed given the lack of judicial independence, subject to excessive influence not only from political power but also from economic agents.
Without a free and independent judiciary, there is no rule of law, human rights are not guaranteed, there is no foreign investment, and there is no progress.
But the blame for this disillusionment also rests with this Parliament and, essentially, with many Member States.
I would like you to, for a few moments, put yourselves in the shoes of a citizen of a European country that, due to historical circumstances, is not yet a member of the European Union.
What would we expect from the Union?
solidarity.

But many chanceries, with the sole concern of not inconveniencing or displeaseing Moscow, exploited and abused the persistent internal struggles in Kiev to avoid unequivocally affirming that Ukraine is an independent and sovereign country.
As such, if that is the freely expressed will of its people and provided that the established criteria are met, Ukraine may aspire to be a member of the European Union in the future.
I would like to highlight that in island regions, air transport is sometimes the only access possibility and that operational conditions are contingent on the size of their passenger and cargo flows.

If there are island regions where the abundance of these hubs is advantageous for many airlines, attracting competition and low transport prices, thus improving accessibility, others exist, such as the Azores, where these hubs are still reduced and therefore not attractive to operators.

Consequently, airfares are higher, constituting an obstacle to population mobility and a deterrent to attracting tourists that would allow this enormous potential for development and diversification of its economic base to flourish and consolidate.
That picture is particularly disheartening in times of crisis such as the one we are experiencing.

It is therefore fundamental to provide temporary support that encourages increased flows so that the market can function, while also including these regions of high tourist potential among the objectives of the trans-European networks in bringing the European peripheries closer.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. I take the floor today in this Chamber, my voice choked with the consternation of one who lived and personally witnessed the tragedy that struck Madeira last Saturday.

My words are, of course, to associate myself with the feeling of pain and mourning that has struck the families of the deceased, currently numbering 42, to whom I offer my tribute and respect for their losses.

The true scale of this catastrophe remains to be revealed, as search and rescue teams, working tirelessly since Saturday in a Herculean effort which I commend, are only now beginning to reach the most isolated populations.
and there is concern that the number of casualties may increase.

The scene is one of widespread destruction, with significant material damage to access roads, highways, and completely devastated areas, as well as to essential services such as water and electricity supply.
Approximately 600 people are displaced, having lost their homes and personal belongings.
The economic and social impact of this catastrophe prevents people from resuming a normal course of life.
But it is now necessary to look forward.
It is also necessary to convey a message of solidarity, hope, and confidence to the people.

It is necessary to help. And it is in this chapter that the European Union and the Parliament in particular have a role to play. They are fundamental to the mobilization process of the Solidarity Fund.
And when we are called to intervene, we must do so swiftly, because we cannot ask people to wait, especially when they need us most.

I appeal here to the Commission and its President Durão Barroso, particularly to the Commissioner for Regional Development and Hannes Hahn, and I welcome your initiative to visit Madeira in the shortest possible time.

requesting that he also be a bearer of this message of hope, of aid, and of support for the reconstruction. Because now is the time to rebuild what nature, unfortunately, once again, has taken from us.
But I am certain that we will, because, as the anthem of Madeira taught me, the Madeiran people are humble, stoic, and valiant.
It is the people who, through relentless toil, brought the land to life, heroes of labor in the Monte Agreste.
Through wood, it will honor its history and in the path of work, it will strive and achieve its well-being and glory.
We begin today’s plenary session with a minute of silence.

It was a minute of silence with two meanings: one of solidarity for the victims of this catastrophe that struck Madeira and their families, and one of tribute to all the workers who have been providing assistance to these victims tirelessly.
But a minute of silence should make us reflect and should also lead to a reflection that extends beyond the one we are undertaking here.
What we saw in Madeira is a phenomenon that will repeat itself with increasing frequency.
Climate change is causing extreme weather events to repeat, and we must have responses to them.
We cannot avoid natural disasters, but neither should we be resigned to the fact that they must always have such dramatic effects on people's lives.
That is why we must advocate for planning and land use policies that are oriented toward the public good.

But I want to conclude, Mr. President, with what is most important and what brought us here, which is that the European Commission, the European Parliament, the European institutions must have the capacity to respond urgently to an emergency situation. And for that, the necessary financial resources are needed, and the necessary speed is required.
A tribute of solidarity to the families and friends of the victims of Saturday’s tragic events on the island of Madeira.

As a Sicilian, as a Portuguese person, and as a European, I cannot fail to appeal to the Parliament and to the Union for their demonstration of active solidarity in favor of the autonomous region of Madeira and its populations.
It is in the regions that the presence of the Union needs to be felt, and it is precisely at these moments when its solidarity is most needed that it is also most important for it to make sense.

Mr. President, I too wish to express my solidarity with the pain of the people of Madeira and to repeatedly urge the European institutions, and in particular, the Commission, to unlock all available resources, all resources within their reach, to provide that assistance.
I would also like to emphasize that, when a disaster of this kind occurs, it is much more difficult to address its consequences when it happens in poor countries and impoverished regions.

However, in the case of Madeira, we must also consider that Madeira’s economic base is directly affected by the fact that, being dependent on tourism, it experiences a twofold consequence when its natural beauty, its accessibility, and its quality of life are all destroyed.

Therefore, there is indeed a different situation when we have problems of this magnitude in poor countries and in poor regions, and in particular, in mountainous and tourist regions, as is the case with Madeira.
Therefore, it is absolutely essential that all adaptations that were foreseen and requested, and that were recalled here concerning the Solidarity Fund, do not await any further delay.

that they enter into function immediately, because due to climate change, these processes, unfortunately, will repeat themselves, especially in the poorest regions of Europe, which are those experiencing torrential rains and extreme drought during the summer. Thank you very much again, Mr. President.
Commissioner and Council, we are here discussing the reinvention of the energy system at the European scale through investment in low-carbon technologies.
I believe it is one of the very important challenges, as is mentioned, indeed, in the communication that is made.
And it is one of the challenges we must face centrally. But there is no clarification here, and hence the importance of raising these questions and requesting clarification.
It appears that not only is clarification of the funding lacking, but political clarification is also absent.
There is discussion of energy efficiency, carbon capture, nuclear power, biofuels, and solar energy; there is even discussion of energy efficiency as a more affordable way to reduce emissions.
It surprises me that there are far cheaper ways to reduce carbon emissions that are not even mentioned in this communication, such as, for instance, reducing consumption itself.
energetic, microgeneration, distribution, and different forms of distribution and different projects that do not have to pass solely through large structures and access to energy.
I believe that there, we would certainly be contributing to greater financial clarity, thereby making the plan more affordable.

And therefore, within this political clarification and within this financial clarification, there remains the need to discuss what appears to me to be an absolutely important point, namely the emphasis that is perpetually placed on public-private partnerships as if they were the solution to everything.
When asked where the money comes from, they tell us from the Commission that it comes from where it is.
I confess that I am not made any clearer by being told that the money will come from where it is without being told exactly where it is.

Therefore, this emphasis on public-private partnerships, which is consistently employed when discussing low-carbon technologies, leaves us with a certainty. It is that, not knowing where the money comes from and knowing that these are public or private partnerships, we initially know who will pay.
Ultimately, it is the taxpayers who will pay—initially, and the consumers who, incidentally, are also taxpayers in the end.

and we know that, initially, it is the institutions and private organizations that pay less, organizations that make the investment, are remunerated for it, but ultimately end up monopolizing the profits.
And without this clarification, it appears to me that, once again, we are systematically passing on the bill for Europe's energy model transition to future generations.

Thank you, Madam President. The European Union recently celebrated, within the framework of the World Trade Organization, an agreement with the countries of Latin America, in which it committed to substantially and progressively reduce tariffs on banana imports from those countries.

I draw your attention to the fact that such an agreement has directly negative effects on European banana producers, particularly on banana producers in Madeira, Portugal, but also, and even more intensely, on the Canary Islands in Spain.

I reiterate that the situation of producers in these regions is already seriously complicated by the physical and orographic characteristics of the islands and the size of their holdings, which leads them to face persistent difficulties that hamper their development.

Therefore, it is urgent to take measures in defense of banana, timber, and Canary Islands producers, considering the serious and immediate impact that the new Geneva Agreement will have on the European market for imports and, consequently, on the production and marketing of bananas originating from these outermost regions.
Mr. President, esteemed colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, as rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, I would like to begin by...
To congratulate Deputy Krielov, even in his forced absence, and to highlight the manner in which he was able to develop this important report, facilitating the primary objective.
I would also like to commend Deputy Creel for the presentation she gave us.

This primary objective is, without further delay, to simplify procedures and accelerate the implementation of programs funded by the Cohesion Fund, the Structural Funds, and the Regional Development Fund.
Within the context of the current financial, economic, and social crisis, the pressure on national financial resources has been increasing.
This pressure will diminish with better utilization of community funding, and with the faster arrival of these resources to those most affected by the economic downturn.
More than 20 million Europeans are unemployed, that is, 4 million more than a year ago, and, regrettably, the trend is expected to increase.

This situation demands ensuring the proper implementation of cohesion programs, as they represent the most powerful and relevant lever for supporting the real economy, particularly in small and medium-sized enterprises and employment.
SMEs are the engine of the European economy and the drivers of sustainable growth, generating jobs in both quantity and quality.

The continued simplification and clarification of the rules governing cohesion policy will undoubtedly have a positive impact on the pace of program implementation, particularly because it will already be

national, regional, and local authorities the possibility of resorting to clearer and less bureaucratic rules that will allow for greater flexibility in adapting programs to new challenges. Thank you.
Thank you, Mr. President. Of course, this crisis was an unforeseen crisis, and of course, the principle of precaution had to take priority.
but there are lessons to be drawn, and the first is that, over five days, no sufficiently strong and politically responsible European voice was heard.
And that voice was missed with respect to the defense of passenger interests, the clarification of their rights, the pursuit of transportation alternatives, and the coordination of solutions.

A second conclusion is that the exit from the crisis must not appear, to the average citizen, to be a game of forces between those who want to avoid losses and those who want to uphold the principle of precaution.
There must be clear transparency and clear objectivity regarding the conditions under which one exits a situation of total closure of the European space.
And therefore, the improvement of scientific tests and coordination also at the level…

Thank you, Mr. President. I also want to begin by congratulating my colleague Tikal on their work and persistence regarding this very important dossier, and for the work they did to improve the energy performance of buildings and towards a more sustainable Europe.
Energy expenditure in the European Union, as we know, is far above what is acceptable, and that is why moving forward with proposals of this nature is so important.
It is more than time for us to have an ambitious policy in European terms and to add to this ambitious policy complementary measures, especially in the crisis situation we are experiencing.
The construction sector is considered one of the sectors, one of the markets with the greatest potential in terms of energy economics, but it's not just that.
And it's not just that, and therefore it is a sector par excellence for the implementation of public policies. And it is in this sense that I would like to conclude, Mr. President.
We must, therefore, seize this opportunity afforded by investments in improving the energy efficiency of buildings and their potential to create millions of jobs in the coming years.
And it’s not just in the construction of new buildings, but also in the rehabilitation and recovery of existing buildings, degraded or unsuitable.

Let us, therefore, use this legislation as a fundamental contribution to the revitalization of the European economy, and we must not continue to squander the investment that can and should be strategic for recovery from the crisis. We hope there will be investment from the Commission, and that Member States will know how to leverage this investment. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Manders on the work developed in this report, as well as thanking those colleagues who collaborated with him on this dossier.

In truth, the very fact that this proposal simplifies and improves the existing regulatory framework, bringing together in a single regulation all existing legislation, the three foundational directives on the naming and labelling of products, is itself a significant fact.

But, beyond this, this proposal will have a positive impact on private agents and public authorities, and it will also allow for the framework of newly developed fibers, thereby encouraging innovation in the textile and clothing sector.
This review will also intensify the transparency of the process for adding new fibers to the list of harmonized fiber denominations.
It appears there is little doubt that the agents involved will benefit from this regulation.
Let us see, the textile industry will benefit from administrative cost savings and the possibility of marketing new fibers sooner.
For their part, the authorities of the Member States will not need to transpose the changes into national legislation, which will enable a significant cost saving for those Member States.
And consumers will have the assurance that the fibers designated meet specific characteristics, also benefiting from the fact that the new fibers will reach the market sooner.
For the European industry, the introduction of these new fibers is important as a way to promote innovation, also increasing the level of information provided to consumers.
Within the current context of a globalized world, emerging economies, with increasingly expansive markets in which millions of products circulate, produced by millions of companies,
Betting on innovation and the speed with which that innovation reaches consumers is absolutely crucial for companies, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.
that the application of this regulation may enhance its competitiveness.
These small and medium-sized enterprises will certainly gain market share with this new regulation, and through this, they will contribute to increased employment in Europe.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Minister, Mr. Commissioner. The scarcity of organs for transplant is a greater problem.

It has been mentioned here on several occasions, and it is a larger problem that poses questions both of public health and associated issues such as the reinforcement of the black market and organ trafficking, which in no way enhances our healthcare systems or our citizens.

And therefore, we must combat this crime and combat it through legislation with proposals such as those we are discussing here. It is a form, it seems to me, more than important and more than relevant, and for that reason, I want to focus on the most important dimensions and issues raised by these two proposals.
because the system we have so far, and without these two proposals, is a system of enormous inequalities.
inequalities among Member States, inequalities among existing systems, inequalities of access to bodies, inequalities among citizens which, it seems to me, we cannot sustain.
Therefore, it is important to emphasize that these inequalities are diminishing. And these proposals aim to combat precisely that.
I believe that a European system which, nevertheless, retains some specificities of certain countries so that they are not obliged to have more restrictive systems is the answer to this problem.
And the work developed by the rapporteurs, Mr. Mikolasik and Mr. Perello Rodrigues, is work of extreme importance and a contribution to this problem we face.
If we are discussing proposals that are based on and supported by issues such as altruism, volunteering, free access, confidentiality, and data protection,

Traceability, accountability, and here I believe it is important, on the part of the Parliament, that extends to the recovery of the patient and not only to the donation and cooperation between Member States; I think we are on the right track.
I must only mention, however, and in relation to concepts among the living, that I am pleased with the inclusion and expansion, this expansion being achieved with rights.

Obviously guaranteeing all rights and all conditions, but it is very important to have gone beyond the restricted cycle of the conventional family, because otherwise it would be just another way of having other forms of equality.

Therefore, promoting data as the main point of transplants and protecting patient data and security seems to me to be more than sufficient reasons for us all to be together tomorrow and to vote favorably on these two proposals of extreme importance to the European Union.

Mr. President, Minister, and Commissioner, the ability to replace deteriorated human organs with those of another person, preventing their rejection, is one of the great successes of contemporary medicine.

European benchmarking reveals differences, revealing that mid-sized countries like Portugal perform very well in such comparisons and larger countries like Spain are now recognized as organizational leaders and exemplars of best practices.
certain principles and practices to safeguard.

Firstly, the reinforcement of scientific knowledge and information that increasingly leads donors to living donation and to the generalization of post-mortem donation. Secondly, the prohibition of the commercialization of…

gift, not only within member states but also outside of them, preventing transplant tourism and combating organ trafficking. Thirdly, the proactive promotion of donation in hospitals as a means of overcoming scarcity.

Finally, Madam President, ensuring equal access to transplantation for all those who need it and qualify for it according to harmonized clinical criteria, adhering to the principle of universal access to healthcare, a paradigm of the social Europe we are proud of.
I commend the rapporteurs for their work.
I would like to emphasize that it is with great, let’s say, satisfaction that the European People’s Party and the Portuguese deputies of the European Party…
European, this process of accession, of accessing the European Union to the European Convention on Human Rights, begins.

We, a country like Portugal, which has always been at the forefront of human rights, with the abolition of slavery in Portugal itself in 1761, and with pioneering work in the abolition of the death penalty, can only be, evidently, interested in and supportive of this accession process.

I would, however, like to draw attention to the fact that we consider it very important that the European Parliament follows, step by step, the entire negotiation of the European Union’s accession to the European Convention on Human Rights.

We consider this aspect, from a technical, legal, and political perspective, to be fundamental because Parliament itself is a House of Human Rights and a place where human rights have great significance. And I would now like to simply note what we consider to be very important.

For us, members of the European Parliament, who are in contact with many states outside the European Union, it is very important—it is a very positive signal that we give to the members of the Council of Europe, regarding the entry of the European Union, to the members of the Council of Europe who are not members of the European Union.
For these members of the Council of Europe, it is a sign of strengthened commitment from the European Union to its situation and to the levels of democracy and respect for fundamental rights.
Madam President and Commissioner, social housing is an economic service of general interest with an important role in the market, creating positive externalities to the benefit of society as a whole.
According to Protocol 26 annexed to the Treaty of Lisbon, the execution and organization of this type of service falls to national, regional, and local authorities.
Hence, this restriction of the target audience to families with incomes below 33,000 euros is scarcely comprehensible.

This concerns a measurement of poverty that is conducted in absolute and purely financial terms, failing to account for the diversity of the 27 Member States, and reducing itself to a simple argument of solvency.

Now, social housing addresses cultural, social, proximity-to-workplace issues, the significant redefinition of women's roles in the labor market, and the mobility of workers within the European space.
The struggle that the European Union is undertaking to overcome the current crisis involves economic growth, which entails an increase in immigration and ethnic minorities.
economically and culturally, and by the necessity of their integration, even with the risks of ghettoization associated with it, which we must combat with just balance.
Is the Commission not encroaching on the competence of the Member States?

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, allow me, Madam President, to point out the fact that we are debating the first report from the Committee on Agriculture, subject to the new ordinary legislative procedure provided for by the Treaty of Lisbon.

This concerns a historic moment that, should this Chamber confirm the sense of the vote I propose, will initiate in the best possible way this new period of sharing competencies in agricultural matters within the European Union.
I am speaking precisely about legislating on your outermost regions in a practical demonstration of the will to build a Union strengthened by cohesion.
in the spirit of active solidarity, with respect for the specificities and differences of its parts, as the only viable path towards the construction of our common European project.
I also introduce fundamental regulation to enable the already century-old sugar sector in the Azores, the region from which I hail; therefore, I am particularly pleased, thereby contributing to a…
Healthy diversification of agriculture in a region where the dairy sector occupies, as we know, a unique dimension on a national scale, irreplaceable, which we must sustain and consolidate.
Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Ciolos and the senior officials of the Commission with whom we have worked and negotiated for the openness and flexibility demonstrated.
The Spanish presidency of the Council also exerted itself to the utmost to ensure that our party’s desire to reach an agreement at first reading became a reality.

This acknowledgement is, of course, extendable to the Shadows of the other political groups, as well as to the excellent staff of the Secretariat of the Committee on Agriculture of this Parliament, whose collaboration allowed us to reach a result that I consider very positive.

I would also like to emphasize the decisive contribution made by the Açores Farmers’ Federation and by the regional and Republic governments in the way they engaged and committed themselves to achieving a solution for Azorean sugar.

The presentation of the Council’s proposed regulation, on 2 October, before the Committee on Agriculture occurred at a time when there were no prospects for the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, which continued to await ratification by all Member States.
In this context, the initial idea of the Commission and the Council was that the proposal would be approved in a simplified procedure, without any amendments, to take effect as of 1 January 2010.

With the entry into operation of the Treaty of Lisbon, and despite, at the time, holding sway over opinion among other political groups, as well as the Council and the Commission, for the proposal to remain in simplified procedure, because they understood that...

The proposal did not require alterations and should enter into force rapidly. Despite prevailing in that opinion, I, together with the Socialist and Democratic Group, believe that the Parliament should pronounce itself already within the scope of the Treaty of Lisbon, assuming its role as co-legislator.

It’s fortunate we did it, because from that point onward new possibilities opened, first with the contribution of the Regional Development Commission and the opinion of my colleague Nunta Cheira, whom I take this opportunity to…

To congratulate and thank you for the constant cooperation provided throughout this process, and subsequently for my report introducing new possibilities for sugar in the Azores, as well as for the contribution and support of the colleagues from the Agriculture Commission.

I would like to say, finally, in this first intervention, that concerning the amendments proposed by the REG Committee and voted on in the AGRI Committee, and which I supported, we were unable to secure acceptance of the commitment reached in the trilogue.

It was essential to secure a first reading commitment, thereby safeguarding the improvements already achieved and the need for effective entry to avoid compromising its retroactivity from January of this year.
However, with the Commission already preparing a review document for POSEI, we will certainly have the opportunity to debate it again soon.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues. We are facing an acceleration of a global change that has devastating consequences for our economic, political, and social systems, and, consequently, for all our citizens.
We are witnessing today an unprecedented weakening of the capacity of states to respond.
The European Union must, therefore, identify common causes and allies and act clearly and unitedly on the world stage.
Extraordinary situations demand clear-headed collaborative action.

If we do not take the collective measures of rigor and accountability that are required, Europe will be consigned to marginalization and impoverishment. And only a strong Europe, one that respects its common rules, can provide an adequate response to the new times.
Fragile and indebted states lack the capacity to protect their citizens.
Consequently, we need to be able to regain the trust of citizens, win the battles of stability, budgetary rigor, job creation, stability of the Monetary Union, globalization, and strategic choices.
Otherwise, our future will be compromised.
and the future is won by investing in social cohesion, ensuring peace, and building a new model based on values of freedom, social justice, and responsibility.
Thus, the Europe 2020 Strategy and the integrated Europe 2020 guidelines constitute essential instruments for a new cycle of growth and employment in Europe.
For correct implementation and achievement, it is necessary to define quantifiable and clear objectives in employment, education, and poverty reduction.

It is also decisive for the success of the strategy that everything be done to facilitate the transposition by Member States of their national objectives and to ensure the proper implementation of this strategy. Thank you very much.
When the Economic and Monetary Union celebrated its 10th anniversary, the Commission considered the euro the Union’s most successful project.
Today, we would have difficulty affirming it without limitations, because the crisis demonstrated unequivocally that the Economic and Monetary Union is an unfinished project.
Minimal measures of salvation were taken amidst a climate of emergency, but let us not be deceived. The conditions of pressure, the direct interests of the major players.
member states. The painful nature of the decisions, their slowness, have weakened the image of the euro and of the European Union in the eyes of citizens and of the world.
We must face the facts.
The European Union and the euro are a process of integration, not merely cooperation between countries.
they are an unfinished process that at this moment either strengthens itself or runs serious risks of disappearing.
There are three themes that must be addressed. First, it is important to consolidate the instruments that were launched in this emergency context. It is necessary to create a monetary fund.

European, it is necessary to move forward with Eurobonds, it is necessary to move forward with the European supervisory and regulatory architecture, and it is necessary to move forward with a European dimension in the management of banking crises.
Second dimension, it is important to understand that there is no strong currency if the economy is weak. The projected 1% growth for the European Union is unsustainable in terms...
Whether concerning its demographic composition or in terms of combating unemployment, the 2020 Strategy is nothing more than a collection of good ideas that lack the means of implementation.

Third dimension, Mr. Commissioner Lirenne, fiscal consolidation is important, but it cannot coexist with increasing divergences among the Member States that comprise the Union. The convergence policy must be urgently revisited. Thank you, Mr. President.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Several colleagues here from the EPP have already provided a very comprehensive picture of the situation.
I judge that it will now be necessary to demand and to make a reference to the role of nation-states.
De facto, national governments also have a role here in imposing within their States the requirements
and the conditions for the single currency to be strengthened and for this project of monetary and economic integration to move forward.
And here I wanted to say that our party, the party linked to the EPP, which is PSD in Portugal, is supporting the government in the austerity measures, because we consider

that the errors the socialist government committed over these fifteen years in Portugal and that today, unfortunately, are evident to all, these errors need to be remedied and will have the PSD’s support for their remedy.

But we are supporting austerity measures, we also criticize the Portuguese government, and it's a good example for other analogous cases because it is not reducing spending. And what is fundamental is not only...

Increase taxes to reduce the deficit, but it is reducing expenditure, it is demanding that the government have the courage to take measures that reduce expenditure, that alleviate the deficit, that alleviate public debt.

This applies to Portugal and applies to other States that are today in a difficult situation. And we, as Members of the European Parliament, have the responsibility of doing so in our own countries as well.
an advocacy of the measures necessary for the euro to emerge strengthened and for this space of integration and this dream, which is a dream of the PPE and a dream of us all, to be realized.
Therefore, we criticize those governments that lack the courage to take the necessary measures within their own states.

Dear colleagues, I would like to begin by stating that the report on the evaluation of the results of the 2006-2010 roadmap for gender equality, and which aims to influence strategy on this matter for the future, could, in our opinion, have been more assertive and less contentious.

In truth, the manner of approaching various ethically sensitive issues, notably the issue of women’s sexual and reproductive health, should have been distinct if the objective was genuinely to achieve the greatest possible consensus.

Having said that, I would like to emphasize that in times of so-called normal economic growth, concern for women's rights, particularly the disparity between the situation of men and women in the workplace, in society, and within the family, is significant. However, these problems are profoundly exacerbated by economic and social crises such as the one we are experiencing.
Hence the need for a strengthened strategic commitment from the Member States, at the level of local and regional entities and Community institutions, with regard to protection.

To say, along the lines of what President Dole and colleague Werner Langen stated, it is fundamental that there be an economic government of the Union, but that this economic government be centered on the Commission.
This is the first point I wanted to emphasize. And having said that, stating that we shouldn't merely, as has been done throughout this morning, focus our debate on immediate issues, but…
also in those that are within the Strategy 2020. And I would underline, in particular, the issue of education and training of the youngest, the issue of innovation, research, and development.

because those are the niches that will allow Europe to be competitive in the global space. And today I must say that, regrettably, the European education model has failed, and it has failed, because when compared with the model of emerging countries,

Like India, like China, like Brazil, it is today a less demanding and less rigorous model. And for this reason, I also ask that in the boldness of this idea of innovation, development, research, and education, there be rigor and demand within the context of European educational systems.
Only with this rigor and demandingness will we prepare our young people to compete in the global market.

We cannot think only of this year’s crisis or that of the next two or three years; we must think of the strategy for Europe over the next 10 to 20 years, and it depends on an educational system of rigor and demanding standards.
Mr. Commissioner, never until today has the European project, built with so much effort over the last 50 years, been so threatened.
European citizens' frustration is immense. The financial system that should have served them destroyed their savings, their pensions, their investment plans, their jobs—in short, their future.
Regarding the necessary strengthening of the entire financial services market—banking, insurance, securities—the path forward is clear and lies in the architecture we are discussing today.
We do, in fact, need a robust European supervisory architecture, covering all products and actors, endowed with methodologies and instruments of…
effective interventions that are capable of responding to the reality of a market that, particularly within the European context, does not recognize national borders.

Risk cannot and should not be eliminated from the financial market, but we need regulation that makes this risk more transparent and that prevents the accumulation of bubbles whose bursting affects the entire system and spreads to the real economy.

But if, despite these safeguards, new crises occur in the future, it is crucial to have mechanisms that limit contagion, particularly with regard to the banking system, because it is vital for the functioning of the economy and the custodian of citizens' savings.

Here, precisely within the powers and competencies of the Banking Authority, lies the capacity to implement a new strategy regarding the management of cross-border banking crises, a subject to which my report refers.
It is not within our power to prevent the bankruptcy of banks, but rather to ensure that their reorganization or eventual liquidation are carried out...
in an orderly manner, limiting collateral effects on the rest of the system and, above all, preventing the taxpayer from bearing the costs of the crises they generate.

To that end, a set of new instruments is required. It is necessary to adopt rules, definitions, methodologies, instruments, and terminology common to all stakeholders in restructuring, reorganization, or liquidation operations.
It is necessary to harmonize the relevant national legal frameworks for crisis management, notably bankruptcy and liquidation laws.
It is necessary to assign supervisors expanded intervention powers.
It is necessary to define clear criteria, not only quantitative but also qualitative, that allow for the initiation of interventions in a struggling institution.
Contingency plans must be prepared.
All of that process, for 27 Member States, requires time.
Meanwhile, approximately 50 banks of the 12,000 operating in Europe represent 70% of the assets.
Now, this signifies a considerable concentration of risk, but also an opportunity to intervene with priority over them.

Therefore, conditions exist to propose a special and urgent process for resolving banks, which, being cross-border, due to their size, relationships with other banks, have a potential systemic impact on the financial system.
Now, for these banks, it is possible to anticipate special supervision by the new European Banking Authority, although operating within the Council of National Supervisors.
It is possible and urgent that they, in light of the risk they generate, begin to make contributions to a fund that finances potential interventions.
that are necessary, and it is important that the Banking Authority create a specialized unit that coordinates interventions in the event of difficulties in these banks.
Overall, the proposed elements ensure that interventions in transnational banks of systemic importance are consistent and coherent among themselves.
different countries and, above all, that a principle so dear to Europe be upheld: that the costs of pollution caused by these banks be borne by the polluter themselves.
This proposal fits perfectly within what we are discussing, particularly regarding the competencies of the Banking Authority. I would even say that it is the most evident test of its effectiveness.
In the case of the vote in the Economic and Monetary Committee, there was an overwhelming majority of support for this proposal, 87% of the votes.

We also count here in this plenary session on the massive vote of this institution, in order to, by massively supporting this proposal, which is visionary, which is realistic, but which is pragmatic, we…
Let us undertake an action that is urgent and necessary to rekindle the hope of Europeans in Europe, in its financial system, and, in particular, in the banking system. Thank you very much.
Thank you. Briefly, to emphasize only four points.
The first of these is that it was an extraordinary experience to work in such a collaborative manner with my colleagues from other political forces.
Thank you very much for including me in the supervision package, and in particular, thank you to Mr. Garcia Margalho for all the collaboration that was possible.

Secondly, I would like to express my gratitude to my personal collaborators and also to colleagues who made contributions to the specific report entrusted to me, which allowed me to incorporate 90% of their proposals.
A special word for the Secretariat, for Susana Vravova, and for the services of the Commission.

Finally, my word of thanks to the Commissioner, to his services, and the very clear expression of hope that, indeed, on the basis of the report I expect to be approved tomorrow, it will be possible to build a solid foundation, a truly European foundation that protects citizens.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I would also like to begin by thanking the rapporteurs for this excellent work.

Deforestation, as we know, is one of the primary environmental and social problems on the planet, and each year we lose 13 million hectares of forest, thus contributing to 20% of the globe’s carbon emissions and constituting a significant threat to biodiversity.

The contribution of deforestation to climate change is unacceptable and, as such, is largely responsible for the occurrence of extreme weather events, flooding, or even desertification of vast areas of the planet.
Deforestation places all of humanity at risk, but this risk and this impact are not shared equally among us.
Communities with fewer resources and those that depend most on the forest and nature for survival are the most affected.
Deforestation pertains to our collective existence, the scarcity of natural resources, their distribution, the rights of local and Indigenous communities, and social justice.
The primary cause of deforestation is the illegal logging of timber, which accounts for 20% to 40% of global industrial wood production.
Therefore, we are also discussing the transfer of wealth from the timber-producing countries to the consumer countries of that same wood.
This illegal practice jeopardizes the sustainable exploitation of timber and the companies that engage in it.
Beautiful words are not enough.
This Parliament should adopt strong and consequential measures in this fight.
This report takes a very significant step in that direction by defining the prohibition of timber trade.
It is not enough with good intentions either.
Effective measures are needed, notably sanctions that, in this case, may be of three types.

First, fines that effectively remove the economic benefit from the illegal practice, increased with recidivism. Second, confiscation of the wood of the products in question. And third, immediate suspension of the authorization to carry out a commercial activity.

And so it is because whoever exploits or commercializes a natural resource must be socially responsible. And so it is also because whoever places timber or timber products for the first time in the European Union must be subject to due diligence to ensure that it is timber exploited legally.
That is why all subsequent operators should provide basic information about that wood, namely its provenance and destination.
The population must also have the right, and I conclude here, Mr. President, the right of access to information regarding who complies and who does not. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Europe needs to renew trust and hope.
In a crisis not yet overcome, we had the firefighters, as Jacques Delors said.
We hope that the Belgian Presidency will bring the architects.
The first test, naturally, will be, as early as September, the Council's convergence with the Parliament's proposals regarding the financial architecture.

But today, one of the greatest European challenges is ensuring that the European currency does not collapse, whether due to a lack of supporting instruments, a lack of growth within the Eurozone, or, above all, the increasing divergences and internal tensions caused by the economies that comprise it.

Cutting structural funds today, as proposed by the Commission—funds created to stimulate convergence in economies that diverge—appears to be like firefighters stoking a fire that is not yet extinguished.
We clearly need architects.
Finally, I would like to know the external dimension of the European Union's action, and in particular, to learn a little more about what the Belgian Presidency proposes for Cancún and for Doha.

Thank you, President. This initiative report that we have debated today, the responsibility of José Bové, whom I congratulate on the way he led it and on its excellent final result, in which I had the privilege of being a shadow and negotiating the 17 commitments obtained, is absolutely essential at a time when...

Agricultural policies are increasingly market-oriented, and farmers in Europe are facing very low income levels, while millions of consumers, as a result of the crisis affecting everyone, find themselves in the urgent need to keep food affordable.

That is why, if farmers' incomes are to increasingly depend on the values generated in markets and the price of food on its proper functioning, then improving the functioning of the food supply chain...

becomes absolutely necessary for a more equitable sharing of value generated, from agricultural producers to final consumers, ensuring fair incomes for the former and appropriate prices for the latter.

To achieve this, it is necessary to rebalance the relationships established along the food supply chain, ensuring their transparency and guaranteeing the existence of a framework of fair and competitive best practices.
In this regard, we appeal to the Commission to consider the widely supported proposals within the Committee on Agriculture.
A few days ago, in Aroca, Portugal, all the workers at a footwear company were dismissed via a simple mobile phone message, without further explanation.
I bring this case here because it is, unfortunately, a blatant example of abuses of collective dismissals in Europe.
It runs counter to all European norms and violates any standard of common sense, respect, and dignity.
Europe has gained 8 million new unemployed since the crisis began, bringing the total to 25 million. How many have been dismissed in such a disgraceful manner?
I would say it more and more, unfortunately.
The European Union boasts a long tradition of safeguarding workers’ rights.
However, current legislation has not been effective.
So, what additional measures will the Commission take?
That is why this question is so pertinent.
There is no justification for dismissals such as that of Arocaba.
Firing someone via SMS will be an innovation, but it is not a good innovation; it is a terrible one, certainly. Thank you very much.
The environmental catastrophe currently under debate, although occurring outside the geographical space of the Union, concerns us all, European citizens.

The notion of sustainable development we believe in is a concept that possesses no administrative boundaries, nor is it influenced by religious convictions, and that views the planet as a whole, and not as the sum of its constituent parts.
The River Jordan is, therefore, a problem for all of humanity and not solely for the populations or communities directly affected by water scarcity or its low quality.
Water. Think globally, act locally, as common sense dictates.
That is what we are here today to do, to think globally.
As the European Union, we must assist in acting locally as a means of minimizing and reversing this persistent degradation of the flow and quality of the waters of the Jordan River.
And to act or assist in acting, the Union already possesses a legislative framework, institutional structure, and instruments at its disposal.
I am referring to the Union for the Mediterranean, its Secretariat, and FEMIP, managed by the European Investment Bank.
This is, obviously, a topic that the Delegation of this Parliament, which I preside, regarding relations with the Mashreq countries, will follow attentively.

It is obvious that the action leading to the resolution of this environmental tragedy should, first and foremost, be undertaken by the States and local authorities whose populations directly benefit from it.
Within this context, I would like to highlight two ideas present in the Resolution.
First, the creation of a commission for the management of the entire Jordan River basin, composed of representatives of the States or authorities that utilize those waters.
And here Europe can help, by sharing, for example, the experience of the International Commission for the Protection of the Rhine.
Secondly, the support and dissemination of good practices regarding joint community projects, involving Jordanian, Israeli, and Palestinian citizens,
namely, those promoted by Friends of the Middle East Earth, which the colleague of Ross just invoked, regarding the efficient and correct management of water resources in the Jordan Valley basin.
Finally, Mr. President, and within an even broader scope, to highlight the example of cooperation and peaceful coexistence that this design embodies.

At the moment when, albeit regretting the absence of the European Union in the process, we welcome and encourage the resumption of the new direct dialogue process between Israel and the Palestinian Authority, we wish to commend this direct involvement of the two parties.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Commissioner, the coordination of efforts during the European Semester, which yesterday was the subject of analysis at the Ecofin, is in itself positive, but it is only part of the reality.
It is necessary that growth and employment function as priorities alongside the fulfillment of the Stability and Growth Pact.
It is important that the European Monetary Fund be created.
It is necessary to treat sovereign debt alongside all other obligations required for participation in a monetary area.

I trust that the evolution of this work will not proceed in the direction of the dangerous idea of sanctions, and I rely on Mr. Commissioner Barnier and his experience to help the Commission move forward in that regard.
A second note to sincerely congratulate you on the work performed in financial oversight.
I believe that Commissioner Barnier, in particular, together with this Parliament and the Belgian Presidency, have managed to reach a good agreement, an agreement that we can be proud of.
and that defends the interests of European citizens. And my hope is that the remaining agenda follows the same methodology and that we achieve the same success.

Thirdly, and particularly, I would like to say that I sincerely hope that, with regard to the resolution of banking crises, especially those of systemically important and cross-border banks, progress will, in this regard, emphasize the European dimension.
Finally, Commissioner, it is very important to revisit our agenda for the G20, particularly if we do not wish to abandon the fight against fraud and tax evasion.
fiscal, unless we wish to abandon the fight against tax havens, and if we still want a more robust contribution from banks and financial services to function effectively.

Thank you, Madam President. We are discussing here today yet another human rights violation, that of the imprisonment of the Syrian activist Aytan Al-Malé, an 80-year-old lawyer, accused of allegedly spreading false and exaggerated news that weakens his country's national sentiment.

Beyond the violation of numerous international treaties and conventions, the imprisonment of this human rights defender is also contrary to the country’s own legislation, which stipulates that military courts should not have jurisdiction to try civilians.

The decision that was made concerning this man and concerning other Syrian prisoners detained for similar reasons, the various detentions, the restrictions on freedom of movement, and the arbitrary measures taken by this man,

by Syrian authorities are practices that contradict the important role of Syria throughout the region and do not reflect the efforts that have been made in this country to improve the social situation.
I repeat, today we discussed yet another situation of human rights violation.
It is not possible to separate it from the various discussions we had here this week.
I highlight two. The first, the rejection of the death sentence by stoning imposed on Sakineh Ashtiani.
Many voices have united, and there have already been some results.

It is not yet time to claim victory, but far less is it time for us to remain silent. Today, we approved a significant resolution against the abuses imposed by the Sarkozy government on Romanian and Bulgarian citizens.
The defense of human rights knows no borders and is not a struggle that can be waged only abroad.
Today, we provided a good example of how deadlock can also occur behind closed doors.
The unjust imprisonment of Aitán Al-Malé unites us all here today.
She is a human rights advocate.
Human rights defenders must be free people, and that is what we demand of Syrian authorities.
We, also human rights defenders, will not leave him alone. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the fact that the safety profile of new medications tends to become fully known only after their entry into the market imposes the necessity of a pharmacovigilance system more effective than the one currently in place.
We are facing a typical risk management problem, but at a macro and supranational level. We have brought it closer to the citizens. Now,
New medications have played a fundamental role in public health and advancements in healthcare over the past decades.
Adverse drug reactions remain the fifth leading cause of in-hospital mortality.
The proposals presented reinforce the contribution of medicines to modern public health through a community-based pharmacovigilance system, improving coordination and transparency.
aims to monitor, detect early, communicate, and evaluate adverse reactions.
The new medications will have a graphic symbol indicating that they are still under scrutiny.

User participation in control is encouraged, studies of efficacy at the national level are promoted, a new sensitivity to environmental consequences is fostered, and the community control institutions, the PRAC, are improved.
It is for this reason that I congratulate you, Mr. President, on the proposals.
I congratulate the rapporteur and also the Commission on their spirit of cooperation, as well as the Spanish Presidency.
And therefore, with the proposals presented in this legislative package, welcoming with pleasure the final document that will be voted on tomorrow. Thank you, Mr. President.
Mr. President, I would like, first of all, to begin by thanking and congratulating the rapporteur, as well as all colleagues who were involved in this process.
We know that adverse drug reactions are the fifth leading cause of hospital mortality—it is never too much to repeat this—and a robust and transparent drug surveillance system is essential.
We now have the opportunity to reinforce the safety of medicines already available and to go beyond laboratory tests, which do not always anticipate problems.

If concrete examples were needed to justify the importance of a new system, consider what happened with the H1N1 influenza vaccine. Speed in placing the vaccine on the market and negligence in investigating the adverse effects that were detected, which continue to delay a complete investigation.
It is therefore necessary that we continue to deepen that path.
This directive ensures the more active involvement of healthcare professionals and patients in identifying difficulties.
In fact, cooperation between countries and the Union can be a positive-sum game.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, a Europe without economic, social, and territorial cohesion is not a Union.
Mountainous regions, islands, and areas with low population density have their own, particularly difficult challenges that must be overcome in the name of a Europe of the people.
But we must move beyond statements of intent, otherwise, we have the opposite effect, that is, we reinforce inequalities.
These regions are enormous reservoirs of important resources.
Biodiversity, forests, wetlands, and green areas provide an essential service for everyone and, nonetheless, suffer from consequent limitations to their economy.
to reciprocate.
The populations of these regions should be supported in a spirit of solidarity by all.
Submit your proposals.
First, the potential contribution to science and to development.
Many of these regions are veritable open-air laboratories, given their richness, but lack equitable access to research resources.
Why not, then, endow them with centers of excellence in research, generating quality employment and revitalizing their economies?
A second proposal concerns energy.
These regions can and should serve as the foundation for projects demonstrating the potential of self-sufficiency and energy sustainability, particularly through microgeneration from local sources.
Dependence lessened, equality increased, and job creation grew.
Finally, I want to state that using GDP as the sole or primary indicator for the allocation of funds and aid can only result in further injustice.
It is therefore very important to use complementary data, notably that which portrays the social and economic reality of these regions.
I must make a special reference here to the peoples of the Azores, Madeira, the mountainous regions, and the depopulated inland areas of Portugal.
With your efforts, you contribute significantly to development and the quality of life for all Europeans.
These and all regions have their context.
Social, economic, and territorial cohesion should not be viewed as an act of charity.
This is where it is decided whether or not we want a genuine European redistribution policy.
Considering all of this, I regard this resolution as an important, but initial step. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the objective of territorial cohesion, now enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon, embodies the value of European solidarity and the commitment of Member States and the Union to reduce the disparities existing between the various regions.
It is not enough, however, to express in the texts of the treaties the objectives to be achieved.
There are regions within the Union that have persistent constraints which strongly condition their economic and social development.

It is therefore necessary to implement specific programs that allow for the effective and tangible overcoming of the delays in these regions by promoting an adaptation of their development model to their potential and resources and contributing to achieving the objectives of the EU 2020 Strategy.

This incentive for these regions should result not only from the instruments of regional policy, through its structural adjustment mechanisms—such as the Cohesion Fund and the four Structural Funds—but also from its structural adjustment instruments.
also stems from a different utilization of various sectoral policies that have a significant territorial impact in each region and can, therefore, have a stimulating effect on their economies.
For the determination of European assistance to these regions, it is certainly the case that we should maintain GDP as the primary indicator of eligibility.

Nevertheless, and considering its inherent disadvantages, it becomes pertinent to resort to other measurable criteria capable of providing a more realistic picture of its level of development, such as the unemployment rate, population density, or the level of education.
Only in this way will it be possible to have a more complete picture of the complex reality of the most disadvantaged regions.

Recall the effect of the case of the outermost regions, whose status is recognized by the new treaty and which are a group of regions of the European Union that have specific characteristics and also deserve special treatment.
The regions of the ultra-periphery, united by their particular characteristics, also diverge in their levels of development.

Similarly, in relation to these [entities], complementary indicators to GDP should be utilized, capable of providing a more comprehensive description of their specific reality and thus contributing to a more accurate determination of their level of development. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. Health to this motion for a resolution that calls for the necessity of an European strategy that makes it possible to translate the principle of cohesion.
territorial gained with the Treaty of Lisbon in opportunities for the populations of territories suffering from various permanent natural constraints to participate in the European project.

I come from a region, the Azores, where these constraints accumulate and intensify, as in other regions designated as outermost regions of Europe, under the terms of Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
Following the Commission’s communication, “Regions and Territories in the European Union: An EU Ultra-peripheral Regions Asset in 2008,” and subsequent extensive debate involving the RUPs themselves.
Actively, we also now await our version of this strategy, which will need to take into account not only our constraints, but above all our potential.
Therefore, I appeal to the Commission to be swift in its presentation, so that we may establish the best strategy before the debate on the new perspectives.

financial, because we must first define the content of policies before allocating the necessary means for their implementation, as has indeed been the case with Community policies currently under review.

Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Commissioners, dear colleagues, after four consecutive years of declining unemployment rates from 2004 to 2008, the current economic crisis has nullified much of the progress achieved.
Unemployment rates in the European Union have experienced a significant increase. For example, in Portugal, we have reached the unfortunate record level of an unemployment rate of 11%.
Another negative phenomenon is youth unemployment in the European Union.
Europe is thus traversing a period of transformation and faces immense challenges.
The crisis nullified years of economic and social progress and exposed the vulnerabilities of its member states' economies and, consequently, of the European Union itself.
Strategy 2020 outlines the way forward.
The European Union must intensify all its efforts to promote employment and social inclusion, as an integral part of its strategy to combat the economic and social crisis.
Thus, we welcome the proposal for a resolution concerning the future of the Social Fund, currently under debate, as this fund plays a crucial role in achieving the goals of the 2020 Strategy.

In fact, this fund is the primary financial instrument that enables the European Union to achieve the strategic objectives of its employment policy, improving the levels of education and qualification of its citizens.
The ESF should be strengthened as the primary driver of the 2020 Strategy and should be used by Member States to invest in skills, employment, training, and professional retraining.

Finally, I would like to emphasize that the reform of the European Social Fund, to be carried out in conjunction with that of the other structural funds, should facilitate and simplify its management and...
to reinforce transparency, as well as to concentrate funds on achieving results and realizing objectives that are effectively felt by citizens in their daily life. Thank you very much.
The European Social Fund is likely the most structuring instrument of cohesion.
Therefore, it must have significant coordination with the Regional Development Fund.
A local approach to the issues to be resolved is fundamental, that is, a global perspective for a local action.

Local and regional authorities are the entities most familiar with their realities, their investment needs, and the creation of employment, as well as which measures are most appropriate for promoting employment in their regions.
We must take into account the positive experiences of the regions.
In the Azores, an ultraperipheral region where unemployment typically reaches record levels, the unemployment rate stands at 6.5%, the lowest in Portugal.

This is largely due to the prospective planning strategy employed for employment, defining factors to act upon, how to achieve the desired Focusur, and also the utilization of the European Social Fund as an operational instrument of this strategy, acting on education, training, and the promotion of employment.
The horizontality of the cohesion policy is the only way to ensure the success of the strategy.
Cohesion policy is a key pillar of European solidarity.
It is through cohesion that the objective of reducing disparities between regions is achieved and the harmonious development of the entire European Union is encouraged.
In the next period, from 2014 to 2020, we must define a framework capable of strengthening the effectiveness of regional policy.

Governance at various levels should be encouraged with greater involvement and participation of regional and local entities, respecting the principle of subsidiarity and as foreseen in the new Treaty of Lisbon.
The special situation of the outermost regions must not be forgotten.
This group of regions faces significant challenges and should continue to benefit in the future from specific provisions in the implementation of European policies.
GDP should continue to be the primary eligibility criterion, but we must consider other indicators that can provide a more complete picture of regional realities.
aged and with extremely low birth rates.
These factors represent enormous challenges for the European Union, to which we must provide concrete responses.
This finding has been universally agreed upon during this debate among us, despite the differing viewpoints that this discussion has revealed.
In Portugal, for example, the birth rate does not ensure the renewal of generations and reveals a reality that compromises the future.
This situation occurs in my country, as it does in most of the Member States of the European Union.
I am confident that more flexible policies regarding maternity leave could help to reverse these trends.
We must send families a consistent message of support for motherhood, with concrete measures for a better reconciliation of professional, private, and family life.
Women should be protected so that they can choose to have children without having to leave the workforce.
Achieving this challenge is essential if we want to reach the economic and social objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy and combat demographic aging.
In Portugal, for example, maternity leave is already fully paid for 120 days, in an effort to counteract the birth rate decline we are experiencing.
I therefore argue that women’s salaries should be guaranteed during maternity leave as outlined in the report under discussion.
Allowing each Member State, by 2020, to establish the conditions that ensure the objective of full salary payment during maternity leave appears to be a sensible procedure.
Finally, I commend the rapporteur Edith Estrela for her perseverance in advocating for measures aimed at protecting families, while simultaneously contributing to counteracting population aging.

First, regarding these two reports, I would like to commend and give here public testimony—testimony I previously gave to the Committee on Constitutional Affairs—regarding the remarkable work done by...
colleagues Lena, Svoboda, Ror Berendt, Diana Wallis, and Rebeca Harms, who were members of the Parliament's delegation that negotiated this framework agreement with the Commission.

I also wanted to record the great openness and highly constructive spirit of collaboration of the Commission President, and subsequently, the interested new Commission of Commissioner Shevchovich and their teams.
I believe a remarkable piece of work has been achieved, leading to a historic agreement, an agreement that represents the first Framework Agreement following the signing of the Treaty.
Lisbon is the first Framework Agreement that has a direct basis, a basis expressed in the treaties, specifically in Article 295 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

I wish to state that this agreement, in fact, establishes a relationship of great transparency and considerable dynamism, even a degree of intimacy in the relationship between Parliament and the European Union.
Parliament and the Commission and essentially represents a compromise, a balance between the two institutions’ vision of the new role each of them will have following the Treaty of Lisbon.

I believe that our negotiating team's work was, in fact, very positive because it managed to translate within this framework agreement those which are the new competencies and that which is the strengthening of powers resulting from the Treaty of Lisbon.
This applies to the legislative procedure and to programming or planning, specifically, for example, just to give two examples, in the involvement of Parliament in...
work program of the Commission or, for example, in issues related to the use of soft law in those which are legislative competencies of the Parliament by the Commission.

On a second line, a very important aspect is the strengthening of the Parliament's control and scrutiny powers, whether concerning the detailing and specification of the rules for the election of the President and the Board of Commissioners, or, for example,

Regarding the Parliament’s involvement in matters such as restructuring, or the potential departure of a commissioner, for example, or the hearing of directors from regulatory agencies, as well as the monitoring of international negotiations.
In all these dimensions, there was, in fact, a vesting of powers, powers that result from the Treaty of Lisbon.
It is also very important to have access to information, and in particular, access to classified information or information as such.
confidential and, furthermore, the exchange of information and the exchange of viewpoints between Parliament officials and Commission officials.

For example, we know that today it is already possible for the Commissioner responsible for institutional affairs and the President of the Commission to participate in the relevant parts of the Conference of Presidents.

or, for example, that there are several platforms for dialogue between the Conference of Presidents, the Conference of Committee Chairs, the President of Parliament, the President of the Commission, and the College of Commissioners, all of them clearly articulated.
Even the presence of the Commission in Parliament was strengthened, notably through the application of Question Hour not only to the President of the Commission but also to the Commissioners.
I would therefore say that, with deep respect for the Treaty of Lisbon and its new balance of powers, and with deep respect for the idea of the separation of powers,
We have here a clarifying agreement that comes to bring, comes to update, comes to revitalize, comes to make applicable the Treaty of Lisbon.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, I begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her work, as well as acknowledging all those who collaborated with her on this report, which enabled us to achieve this agreement at first reading.

This directive, which restates the previous directive—more than 10 years old—intends, as has been recognized by all, to bring an end to a widespread problem for the European Union regarding payment transactions.
These delays, in some Member States, are unreasonably long when involving public administration.

The negative effects of this practice on the economic life are enormous, both at the level of small and medium-sized enterprises and at the level of the domestic market. And these negative effects can no longer be tolerated, especially as we are living through an economic and financial crisis like the one we are experiencing.
This legislative amendment serves to provide coherence and meaning to the European economic recovery plan and its implementation.
Business Act. It is confidently expected that this directive will improve the liquidity of companies.
Creators will now have an effective and efficient instrument at their disposal to exercise their rights against defaulting payers.
With this directive, the censored practice of public entities will be the exception.
Public administration bodies should set an example of good citizenship and settle invoices for goods and services within one month.
It will now be up to the involved institutions, the Council, and the Member States to ensure that the transposition of this directive is carried out as swiftly as possible.
There is currently, in many Member States, a significant disparity regarding payment terms to businesses, particularly when the State, SMEs, and large companies are involved.

We who have come from businesses know that in this situation of economic crisis and increased financing difficulties, companies are increasingly struggling with liquidity problems, and are even, in many Member States, exposed to an increased risk of bankruptcy.
It appears clear that the current directive, which attempted to regulate this matter, had limited effects; therefore, the proposal we are now analyzing represents an important step in fulfilling
Payment terms, not only in relations between companies and public entities, but also, and this is essential, in the relations that companies establish with each other.

We now have legislation that provides us with greater added value, featuring a clear system of sanctions for payment delays and that also brings about an effective improvement in the balance of abuse of dominant positions established by the State and large companies.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. Allow me to speak about what remains unsaid.

Madam Commissioner, I listened very attentively, and from what I observed, it seems to me – I feel compelled to say – that, to date, the most effective action, whether from national or European authorities, has been the management of silence.
Industrial accidents can and should be avoided. This is also the purpose of European legislation, and it seems obvious that the law has been violated.
There was ineffectiveness, delayed response, and abandonment of those affected, particularly the most vulnerable.
People have died, and many continue today under the threat of what may happen to their health.
It is impossible to calculate the total costs, and it is immoral not to care for the victims.
How is it possible, I ask you, Madam Commissioner, that we learn of news through reports reaching us from Hungarian citizens and the authorities see or tell us nothing?
That is why I would like to raise some questions.
How is it permissible for banks to pressure citizens with mortgaged homes in the affected area, demanding they fulfill their obligations when their homes have lost value?
How can the telephone operators be permitted to sever the sole means of contact for those in the disaster zone?
How is it that the company responsible for this catastrophe has already resumed operations?
And, finally, Commissioner, you spoke of mitigating the effects of tear gas deployment.
I ask you what the reasons are for continuing to mitigate the true magnitude of this human tragedy.
It's that it seems as though we are always starting from scratch.

Thank you, Mr. President. Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues, we all recognize that control of macroeconomic variables, both in the short and long term, has failed within the European Union, notably concerning budgetary frameworks and accumulated national debt.
The crisis served to accentuate the need to strengthen the single market, taking into account the Monti and Greco proposals.

It is essential to develop e-commerce and cross-border trade, simplify online payment processes, standardize products and services, and harmonize fiscal instruments, in order to foster consumer trust and invigorate the economy.
The Union must emerge from the crisis in a sustainable manner, ensuring robust growth and responsible budgets, but also employment objectives.
Indicators such as the unemployment rate and the employment rate of the active population must be compulsorily included in the supervisory system.
The indicators that will measure the progress of the 2020 Strategy must not be overlooked either.
The feasibility study on the issuance of common European bonds could constitute an opportunity to deepen and implement financial instruments for defense against speculation.
We wish we could have gone further than a simple study.
