The creation of the European Monetary Fund deserves our support and we see it not only as an instrument of discipline, but, above all, as a means of reducing speculative manipulation of sovereign debt markets.
Collaboration with Rapporteur Feio was productive, and a comprehensive, balanced, and substantive text was achieved.
Thank you, Mr. President. Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking Deputy Feio for the work of reconciliation and the spirit of compromise with which he imbued his report.
But the conclusion we reached was that Parliament, in certain dossiers, and this also occurred in financial supervision,
capable of uniting and is capable of taking a strong position that defends the interests of the citizen, and that strong position must be recognized by the Commission and the Council.
This aspect is particularly relevant at a time when a legislative package of six extraordinarily sensitive proposals is being initiated, in many of which this Parliament has powers of co-decision.
We will also be active, but without concessions.
Our spirit is one of dialogue, but not of overstepping the objectives we intend to defend.
And, in this respect, the Feio report highlights certain framing aspects.
One of them is that economic governance is more than a package of sanctions.
Growth and employment require their own initiatives.
Initiatives are needed to combat the growing internal divisions within the European Union.
Concrete proposals regarding the European Monetary Fund are needed.
Stable solutions for sovereign debt are needed.
We are at a moment when trust depends on the Commission’s and the Council’s ability to respond to the genuine aspirations of citizens and to the management of unemployment, growth, and cohesion.
Mrs. BRS and all those who collaborated to produce the report that is currently under discussion.

Within the scope of this report, the Commission's work has produced a thematic contribution highlighting the crucial role of small and medium-sized enterprises as a driving force for the recovery of the European Union and future growth and well-being.
In fact, there are over 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises in the European Union.
Thus, if each of them could create a job, that would signify a reduction equivalent to unemployment.
This document highlights recommendations as key economic strategies for exiting the crisis.
The first is the need to strengthen the social market economy, avoiding restrictions on competition and ensuring access to credit for small and medium-sized enterprises.
the granting of tax incentives and even subsidies to SMEs to maintain and create jobs.
the creation of a new Small Business Act endowed with a stronger social dimension.
the establishment of a European network of landscape consultants to disseminate their knowledge.
Innovation as the most powerful engine of economic growth and, as such, the essentiality of an organic link between industry and innovation.

the establishment of new partnerships between industry and academia, and finally, the creation of an education system suited to the needs of the labor market, but also the need to create new qualifications for new jobs.
Mr. President, smart growth, as advocated in the 2020 Strategy, can only be achieved if we intelligently mobilize the different potentials contained within European diversity.
25 million square kilometers of exclusive zone grant the European Union the world’s largest EEZ.

320 thousand kilometers of coastline, where one-third of our population resides, generating 40% of our gross domestic product and 95% of our foreign trade, are figures that should alert the Commission.
and the Council to act, emphasizing that they cannot forgo an integrated European maritime policy in achieving the smart growth essential to the success of the 2020 Strategy.

It draws particular attention to the potential biogenetic and mineral wealth contained within our deep sea and seabed, which are still poorly understood today, and to the need to increase our research and development efforts in these areas.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating Mr. Commissioner Barnier on the presentation of this important document.

As diagnosed, the impact of the crisis we are witnessing is being felt across all sectors of society and our economy, provoking disillusionment and distrust among our citizens regarding the single market.
but it is precisely this single market that is one of the assets Europe possesses to combat the current crisis.
Therefore, we warmly welcome this communication, which represents a new ambition for the policies of the single market, allowing us to regain confidence in our model of social market economy.
In the current situation, the European Union must give particular attention to its 20 million small and medium-sized enterprises.
In this regard, one of the Union's priorities should be the creation of mechanisms that resolve the issue of access to credit for these companies.

We also highlight the Commission's proposal to evaluate the Small Business Act by the end of 2010, in order to facilitate the operations of these businesses, particularly through bureaucratic and fiscal simplification, as well as the promotion of social responsibility.

We hope that these 50 measures now presented will contribute to deepening the internal market, fully leveraging its potential, which could represent supplementary growth for the European economy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. We are here today to discuss what has been presented as one of the European Commission’s highest priorities: innovation policy.
to finally take shape, notably through European partnerships for innovation and with this pilot project that we are discussing today regarding active and healthy aging.
However, there are many aspects that still need to be defined, particularly regarding clarification, the definition of future projects, and the establishment of priorities.
Who, ultimately, will define the priorities and based on what criteria?
I believe these are the answers we should receive.
But I would like to offer some concrete and specific notes in relation to this first project on active and healthy aging, which was the one presented to us.

These notes are, from the outset, a positive note because it seems to me positive to focus on a sector of the population that is particularly vulnerable in a Europe that is increasingly aged and increasingly disadvantaged.
However, I would like to add even more questions to these, because it seems contradictory to present a project in this area when, simultaneously, we have no means to sustain this innovation.
How are we going to sustain it?
Who are you?

Is there any viable innovation within a context like the one we are witnessing, where there is a persistent and systematic assault on the Welfare State, on the reduction of access to healthcare, on systematic cuts to services provided, and on continued disinvestment in this area?
The title of the communication that was presented, A Union of Innovation, More Employment, Improved Lives, Better Society, is ambitious.
I would even say that I would have no problem personally endorsing it, but let’s agree that it is contradictory to what has been the practice in Member States, with the cuts and austerity measures.

I believe that sustainable innovation can only occur if there are rigorous, sustainable, and demanding public policies. Otherwise, it’s a fleeting spark, leaving little behind and offering few answers to these populations. Thank you very much.
Dear colleagues, we commend the Commission’s efforts to place research and innovation at the forefront of the political agenda.
We are presented with an integrated strategy to make the European innovation ecosystem more effective and productive in service of a sustainable economy.
European innovation partnerships emerge as an instrument, and the significant challenges they address are sufficiently broad as to avoid controversy.
However, it is not yet clear how the sub-thematic priorities will be defined, nor how the prevalence of each discipline within them will be determined.
What level of transparency will be expected for stakeholders to participate? How should conflicting interests be arbitrated?
What is the respective role of the Commission, the Member States, and the regions?
How to ensure accountability within a complex structure?
What financial dimension will these partnerships have?
The Commission and the Council, Mr. President, must ensure excellence in implementation, which is not guaranteed by the scant months of pilot testing foreseen for the first partnership.

The International Trade Commission is currently reviewing the Comprehensive Banana Agreement reached within the World Trade Organization, and shortly this Chamber’s plenary session will be called upon to deliberate on the reduction of customs duties on bananas imported from Latin American countries.

Let it be abundantly clear that none of the outermost regions, whether Madeira, from which I hail, or any of the other eight, particularly the Canary Islands, which are by far the most affected, are opposed to the conclusion of these types of agreements.
What these regions intend, solely and exclusively, is to demand of others the same phytosanitary hygiene conditions and respect for the rights of citizens.
workers, which are required of them to access the market, which is a matter of fundamental fairness, and that these [workers] are compensated exactly to the extent of the detriment caused to them.

Alternatively, if that is not the case, that there be an unwavering frankness in telling them directly that they will have to change their lives and seek another occupation, because it is certain that under the conditions that are anticipated for the future, they will not be able to survive and will have to abandon their activity.
It is true that in these agreements there are winners and winners, let us then care for the winners because winners do not need [assistance].
campo. We are here discussing a very
concrete assistance in achieving economic recovery, and in this case, within a central domain—the energy sector.
In the current context of the crisis we are experiencing, it is fundamental that proposals like this one help to create jobs.
There is no possibility of economic reconversion if we do not prioritize job creation above all else.
This report delivers a very positive signal when it highlights the way to respond to this level in the plan and at the local domain, responding in a concrete way to local needs.
We are in a period in which we debate and will continue to debate a range of legislative proposals in the field of energy, and often we tend to…
we concentrate excessively on what constitute the large projects, on what constitute the large networks, and forget other scales of intervention where it is absolutely fundamental to intervene.

And that is why I believe this report can help us invest not only in energy efficiency and renewable energies, which is very important, but also in bringing concrete benefits to local populations, which naturally translates into concrete benefits for the European population as a whole.
And that is why I want to conclude, Mr. President, with two final points. It is important not to forget that energy efficiency is often achieved, in part, through energy reduction in projects.
micro-generation, as presented here, and the final note that it was a significant gain for this Parliament to ensure a concrete definition of the amount of funding to be applied to these projects.
It is not what we aspired to; we needed much more, and therefore, I ask the Commissioner what he intends to do and aims to do to ensure these needs are met.
Dear President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Dali, the patient must have the right to acknowledge, to know as much as possible about their illness and the available medications for treatment.
But how to distinguish information from advertising?
Where and how to gather objective and unbiased information?
There exist different interpretations of the existing texts. It is necessary to harmonize them, reinforcing the sovereignty of the citizen.
Information must be reliable, validated by authorities, independent, accessible, and geared toward a general, non-specialized audience.
The aim is to foster a more informed and responsible citizenship on the part of the end-user.
The deadline given to the European Agency for tacit approval should be extended from 60 to 120 days.
The requirement of justification strengthens the adversarial process and balances the final outcome.
The EMEA has an essential role as a privileged source of objective information.

And I would like to conclude by greeting Rapporteur Fielner for the work he has developed and congratulating myself on the fact that he accepted almost the entirety of the proposals I presented in the Internal Market Committee as rapporteur. Thank you.

Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, bee mortality is increasing and the number of beekeepers is declining. A problematic situation for agriculture and biodiversity, as has been stated here, given the enormous implications for food production and plant species that depend on their pollination.
The life of a worker bee is very short, approximately six weeks, and highly susceptible to external environmental changes.

Therefore, honey production has also been affected not only by the increasingly uncertain duration and stability of the seasons, but also by the increase in external aggressions that may result from the use of pesticides, mites, or other factors.

and concerning which the highest level of research could contribute to obtaining better applied answers and more accurate reinforcement of measures in favor of biodiversity and the reduction of the effects of climatic instability.
Current programs, Mr. Commissioner, must undoubtedly be strengthened within the framework of the new CAP, so that we can also achieve, at this level, a more effective level of response.
Mr. President, let us be clear, the solidarity mechanism for sovereign debt did not work, and it does not work. The price of Greek debt has not decreased, and Ireland is…

The economic convolution and contagion were not contained. The process that was created was created late, is intergovernmental, and should have existed in a different format from the beginning of the euro's creation.
The President of the Commission now proposes a consolidation of this system.
However, in the third of the instruments he proposes to use, he suggests involving private entities.
We had already heard that proposal to Chancellor Merkel, and it was as a consequence of that premature and inopportune announcement that the markets surged.
Parliament will fully utilize its powers and with the utmost responsibility and spirit of cooperation in the co-decision process accompanying the package.
legislative action on economic governance, but not by sacrificing deliberation, speed, or quality.

Therefore, let us be clear: Parliament will participate actively, but a matter as serious as the resolution of sovereign debt cannot be decided on the periphery and without the knowledge of European citizens and their representatives. The two elements are intrinsically linked.
Finally, we, Europeans, need a clear European vision at this moment of crisis.

A European mechanism for sovereign debt consolidation is needed, the issuance of eurobonds is needed, and the euro area must be sustainably protected through European, rather than intergovernmental, systems.

It is necessary to reinforce the European budget; we cannot continue with one at the current level. It is essential to place real growth and convergence at the center of European political priorities.
This is the agenda that the Commission and the new President must uphold.
And the President of the Commission cannot be an emanation of the Ecofin Council.
This is what we need to present to European citizens.
Mr. President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, I naturally want to say that the EPP’s position is clear. It is a position in the sense of...
that the resolution of this crisis, this serious crisis facing Europe and the European Union, can only be achieved through a deepening of economic governance and the Community method.

For us, there is no doubt whatsoever that only with greater community method, only with economic governance, only with the appropriate instruments of a true single currency within the euro area is it possible to confront and address this crisis.
But this means that each of the institutions—the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament—accept responsibility before the European citizens.
It should be stated here that it is clear, at the very least, that the largest groups in the European Parliament are willing to cooperate evidently in order to increase.
the community method, of introducing economic governance, of giving the single currency the necessary conditions to triumph in the context of the European crisis.

It is also evident today that the same applies to the Commission and to the President of the Commission, who, contrary to what socialists and Deputy Elisa Ferreira claim, has demonstrated that it is neither an emanation of the Council nor an emanation of Parliament, but an emanation of European interest.
It remains for the Council, now in December, to assume its responsibilities.
It is with this that we count and with your manifest adherence to the European ideal, President Van Rompuy.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin by congratulating my colleagues, Luan and Manescu, on the remarkable work they have done in their respective reports.
Both constitute an important contribution to the ongoing discussion concerning the new cohesion policy for the 2014-2020 period.
Today, more than ever, the achievement of economic, social, and territorial cohesion is essential for affirming the competitiveness of the European Union on a global scale.
This goal will only be achieved if we are aware that only by reinforcing and developing the regional dimension can we have a cohesive Europe internally and a competitive one externally.

In this regard, I would highlight three points that I consider crucial. Firstly, decentralization, ensuring that local and regional authorities, particularly those with legislative powers, participate more and contribute to a better implementation of the cohesion policy.

Member states are to invite regional and local authorities to participate in negotiations on the future of structural funds on an equal footing with national authorities and representatives. And, finally, the strengthening of the role of regional authorities in the preparation, management, and implementation of programmes.
Only in this way, with the most significant involvement of these authorities throughout the entire process, will the principle of subsidiarity be fulfilled.

Another aspect that I consider crucial is the request for a simpler architecture for post-2013 funds, not as a consequence of the economic crisis, but rather as a general principle of future cohesion policy, in order to facilitate the absorption of the funds.
The primary concern underlying the Treaty of Lisbon was to bring Europe closer to its citizens.
Let us then not only do that, but also make your life easier, avoiding unnecessary administrative burdens that discourage your participation.
Only in this way will we be able to realize the objective of genuine territorial cohesion.
Only in this way will we see a reduction in disparities within the European Union, currently markedly contrasting and with a vast gulf between wealthy and impoverished regions.

Greater participation also means greater responsibility. And it is this responsibility that should be assumed and shared by all, doing more and better with the aim of having a stronger and more competitive Europe.
Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues. I would like to begin by congratulating colleagues Edith Bauer and Anne Ed for the excellent work carried out in this report.
Human trafficking dishonors our society and demands a strong and coordinated response from all.
Organized crime behind sexual exploitation, forced labor, human organ trafficking, and other abhorrent practices must be effectively combatted, but primarily prevented.
What is at stake is the defense of human rights and the protection of the most vulnerable individuals, particularly women and children.
The experience demonstrated that the existing legal framework was not sufficiently effective and that the European Union must make greater efforts.
It is essential to have greater cross-border cooperation, including effective information sharing and the exchange of best practices.
It is noteworthy in this proposal, and rightly so, a victim-centered approach.
Policies in this domain should encompass aspects related to social matters and social inclusion, such as the social rehabilitation of the victim. Thank you very much.
The NATO Summit took place in Lisbon, and therefore, allow me to say a few words about what happened in my country in connection with this Summit.
At that time, Portuguese authorities would prohibit the entry into the country of European citizens, and only for one reason: these citizens were carrying critical texts of the Alliance.
During those days, the least we can say is that an arbitrary regime prevailed in Portugal, an authentic police of the mind.
a regime so special that led the Portuguese government to purchase anti-riot equipment valued at 5 million euros, which did not even arrive in time for the summit.
And these are, after all, the priorities of a government facing a massive social crisis.
In the Europe we dream of, freedom of expression is a fundamental value.
The Europe we dream of does not bow to military organizations that write their history with blood.
The NATO summit resulted in the legitimization of its military intervention worldwide.
Also emerged the subordination of the European Union to the military strategy and interests of the United States.
Thirdly, the militarization of access to energy sources solidified.
Lastly, the military defense of a development model that generates environmental imbalances and disrupts the social crisis was established.
Therefore, Madam President, I want to say that, in my opinion, with this summit we have lost in democracy, we have lost in freedom, and we have lost so that some may profit from war.

I now yield the floor to Mr. Rangel. You have a minute and a half. Thank you, Madam President. The first point I wanted to make clear here and that it is important to reinforce in this Parliament is that...
It is that, contrary to what is sometimes read in the press and in the statements of some European leaders, the euro, as a currency, has been fundamental in responding to the current crisis.

Without the euro, we would be in an extremely difficult situation, with the currencies of the more fragile countries experiencing enormous devaluation and with a potential German mark appreciating to an impossible level, unable to sustain the German economy and the European economy.
And therefore, the euro was a factor of stability, especially not only for the countries that are in the eurozone, but also for the currencies of the countries that did not wish to join the eurozone.

And precisely because we must defend this community that has managed to respond to the crisis like no other and, as we will see in the future, for example, what will happen to the dollar and the United States of America, we will see how the euro genuinely has advantages.

We now have the responsibility in this Council to do everything to defend the euro, specifically to establish a stabilization fund that follows the community method and is capable of introducing accountability into...

countries that are in the most precarious situation and solidarity with those that have fulfilled their obligations and have not always demonstrated, at least in their external declarations, a willingness to be supportive within the Eurozone context.

I wish to extend my sincere congratulations to my colleague Sarbu for the excellence of the report produced, strongly advising that the Commission take it into consideration, particularly in those aspects where the complex dimension of agricultural issues significantly exceeds the strict dimension of…

agriculture requires the involvement of other areas, such as competition, the internal market, and financial regulation, as well as requiring their treatment at other extra-community forums, such as the G20 or the WTO.

The issues absolutely determining the future of agriculture, of farmers, and of the availability in sufficient quantity and quality of food to the populations of Europe and the world can only, in fact, be addressed if they are tackled across all their dimensions.

and the ambitious objectives of the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy can only be achieved if the reform transcends the strict boundaries of agriculture and its objectives are also taken into account in the necessary interventions of other policy areas and in other global-character organizations.
This report made it very clear, and I commend it for that.

Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, and dear colleagues. I want to begin by thanking you for all the words expressed regarding the report that Parliament is presenting on Alzheimer's disease and other dementias.
We all know that the situation we are experiencing is substantially dramatic and remains significantly underdiagnosed. This was stated here.
and I simply want to refer to a question that was transversal to all the interventions, but likely not so emphasized, which is the question of the dignity of patients, of their rights,
and not only of the patients, but also of their families and those who care for them, whether formal or informal caregivers, and the professionals associated with this type of illness.

I am genuinely pleased, frankly pleased, with the Commissioner's words when he states that he shares the same concerns as the European Parliament and that the European Commission views all the recommendations of the report presented by the Parliament very positively and will do everything within its power to implement them.
We know that each passing day is later than the last in this matter, given the urgency of what we have at hand.
And therefore, we also know that tomorrow Parliament will pronounce itself on this matter.
We will await the result of the vote, but we know, Mr. Commissioner, that European citizens expect much more from us than solidarity and moral comfort.

They expect concrete and appropriate actions from us. I sincerely hope, Mr. Commissioner, that you will put them into practice and that the Commission, which has the initiative – an initiative which, unfortunately, this Parliament does not – will put them into practice.

All this priority that is promised to be given to this area and that transforms it into legislative initiative, so that citizens and their families see their rights respected and are treated with equality and dignity as they deserve. Thank you very much.

Firstly, I would like to say that this Parliament, on a day when we are discussing the Hungarian presidency, without prejudice to its ability to address all the topics it wishes to, should focus on the problems of the European Union, which it is not doing here.

And to focus on the problems of the European Union, one should read attentively and discuss here whether one agrees or disagrees with the priorities of the Hungarian presidency, instead of discussing points.

or aspects that are aspects of Hungary’s internal life and that, at most, could be regulated in a healthy and normal relationship between the European Commission, the Hungarian Government, and the Hungarian Parliament.

I wanted, therefore, to say here that, beyond the priority that, naturally, the Hungarian Presidency will give to economic and financial matters on the agenda, I see with great satisfaction that it is
The Hungarian agenda for this semester is remarkably lucid and highly ambitious, focusing and prioritizing three subjects that will be essential for the future of Europe.

Food, which is entering a serious global crisis, energy, which is essential for our security and our economic sustainability, and water, about which few have spoken, but which will be the next challenge for Europeans, following food.
I wish you achieve your objectives.

Thank you, Madam President. I believe that these two countries, like others in this region, show us how, in recent years, European leaders have frequently sided with business interests over democracy, and with dictators over the poor.
I am frankly concerned about the current situation in Egypt and today's developments, and that is why I believe we should not be complacent but should demonstrate solidarity.
Solidarity with the millions of Egyptian citizens who are in Cairo and throughout the country, fed up with hunger, fed up with oppression, fed up with unemployment.

And that is why, after today’s Mubarak speech, after the regime’s dogs have been unleashed, after having created a clear and unobstructed path for violence, we must say that we must stand alongside these people.
We cannot allow a fear strategy to be created so that they return home.
Thirty-six years ago, in Portugal, we would have returned home had we heeded that advice.
It’s fortunate that we didn’t return, as we thereby achieved a democratic revolution.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would also like to say that I believe this issue is too important to continue living in the deception we have been experiencing in Europe.
either a deception or a false promise, as you wish to call it, because we have been operating, particularly in the area of stem cell collection from umbilical cords, based on misleading information.
And we know, as has been mentioned, that in Europe, the collection of stem cells from umbilical cord blood does not reach one percent.

And yet, we also know that its possibilities for the treatment of diseases can be inexhaustible, diseases such as those already mentioned, cancer, as well as Alzheimer's diseases and rare diseases; the possibilities are immense.

But what we allowed to happen was the establishment of a set of private cell preservation banks, telling parents that they could store their children's cells, and from that point on, at the time of birth, and from that point on, cure them in the future, if necessary.
I believe we should be more accountable than that, because the probability of that occurring is very low, as we know.
And that false promise is sold to parents at a cost.
In Portugal, for example, that false promise costs three and a half minimum wages.
The solution clearly involves creating public stem cell banks, because only with public banks can we guarantee equal utilization and equal access.
and an effective medical treatment and further research that is equal for all, and not merely utilizing master stem cells as merchandise or a business that is growing, but one that is only for a few.
Therefore, I believe solidarity, common sense, and impartial information are not, in the end, things that can be considered an added requirement.
We do not have the power to impose, we have the power to promote.
This falls within our competencies; I think we should do it in the name of equality. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. The price of food has reached a historic high and this is the seventh consecutive increase.
And there are several factors that can explain this increase, the first being a short-term factor.
has to do with the coincidence of adverse weather conditions in some countries, such as Russia and Argentina.
but there are two factors that are structuring factors, of a structuring order, and that is why I bring these two factors up here.
The first concerns the fact that some food producers and consumers who were previously exporters have become importers, as is the case with China.
And the second has to do with the fact that the weight of some large multinational corporations can manipulate prices to their advantage.
And the example of cereals is very clear at this level. It is dominated by six large multinationals.
This situation therefore places farmers in enormous uncertainty regarding food prices.
Europe must, therefore, return to doing what it ceased to do some time ago, namely, protecting its producers and consumers.
In a world where everyone resorts to forms of protection and where multinational corporations manipulate prices, we cannot continue to be naive. Thank you very much.
I congratulate the colleague rapporteur Marisa Matias and commend all those who collaborated with her.
Regrettably, over the past few years, we have witnessed an increase in pharmaceutical counterfeiting across Europe.
According to data from the European Union, one and a half million boxes of counterfeit medications are sold annually through the legal supply chain.
This is a criminal activity that represents a serious threat to European patients and to the European industry.
The objective of this directive is to prevent the introduction of falsified medicinal products into the supply chain and, thereby, to protect public health.

I would like to highlight, in the opinion I prepared, the following key points. The introduction of the definition of counterfeit medicine, clearly emphasizing consumer protection. The application of devices...

the safety of prescription medications, the accountability of all stakeholders in the distribution chain, and finally, the application by Member States of effective sanctions to deter this criminal activity.
Mr. President, I want, of course, to thank all the comments that were made by all colleagues.
I will not comment on them individually; that is not the intention.
I believe that if there were any doubts about what the word commitment means, it has become very clear here what it means.

We do not all have the perfect proposal, but far more important than knowing if it is the perfect proposal is knowing that we have an instrument in our hands that will allow us to not further delay the protection of patients' health.
and we have an obligation not to delay its adaptation either, we have an obligation not to delay real action, and we can only do that together.
I must also say, personally, and the Commissioner mentioned the issue of inspections; in my initial proposal, I presented an amendment for mandatory inspections in third countries.
The commitment is precisely that, and yet, one gains in some things, loses in others.
We were informed by the Commission that obtaining this would be impossible.
I would also like to make another note regarding this commitment.
I believe we all see ourselves reflected in the commitment, but I also think and am aware that we will all be demanding that it be fulfilled, because otherwise it will not be effective.

And it is within this commitment that safeguards are ensured, allowing us to follow the process, evaluate, and systematically obtain information that enables us to verify whether it is being implemented or not, properly or improperly, and whether adjustments are needed.

I would therefore like to conclude by thanking the European Commission for its collaboration, in particular the Spanish and Belgian Presidencies, with whom we have worked together over the past six months.
There are no perfect proposals, no perfect interventions; there are shortcomings, but I believe we have a strong and robust commitment that allows us to combat and defend the health of patients.
And as my intervention is also full of shortcomings, I failed to thank colleagues Regina Bastos and Amalia Sartori, from the partners of the other commissions.
Thank you also for your support.
Mr. President, Commissioner, it is hardly necessary to reiterate that the current moment represents the most serious test of the euro’s survival, and therefore, of Europe’s.
The Polimata report opens constructive solutions, and for that reason, I also want to congratulate our colleague on the ideas she puts forward.

The gravity of the moment does not stem from the fact that the Eurozone as a whole has an excessive deficit or external debt. Rather, it stems from the fact that the economies composing it persistently and gravely diverge under the impact of the common policy.
We lack instruments that allow for the convergence between these economies, that allow Europe to regain balance, that allow Europe to grow.
Let us be clear, the Eurozone and the European Union cannot survive with the current level of integration and the diversity of the economies they comprise with a budget of 1% of collective wealth.
In practice, after the crisis, the only solution we were able to construct was the recipe of austerity, and it is workers and companies who pay today.
the deficits generated by the speculative crisis in the financial sector, in whose rescue 26% of the wealth of the European Union was committed.
The tax on financial transactions, levied at a very low rate, for example, 0.05%, on transactions involving high-risk, highly speculative products, is indeed to be paid by their consumers.
But why should they not pay if common citizens pay VAT on bread, on milk, and on the most basic products?
The tax burden must be redistributed to affect workers and businesses less and to be shared more equitably by the financial sectors, particularly those engaged in speculative activities.
And, Mr. Commissioner, I believe that the Commission cannot, at this moment, refuse or shy away from the clear message that this Parliament is giving it, politically.
The public consultation cannot exclude the analysis of the financial transactions tax; on the contrary, it must be analyzed with the highest priority.
We know very well what happened with the A flu, and this should serve as a lesson for us all.
And I don’t know if you all remember well how all this began, but the truth is it started one way and then the response was completely disproportionate to the scale of the problem.
That is why the report that was voted on here today is so important, because we must learn from what was done so that what was done is not repeated.
We have the right to know who made the decisions, how the entire history unfolded, and who decided for it to have transpired in that way.
We have a right to know which countries responded in a certain way, why they responded without transparency, and without allowing us to remain…

To minimize doubts, because we maintained all the doubts as to whether or not a business deal occurred. We must ensure that no residue remains, whether or not a business deal related to this influenza transpired.
And that is why, Madam President, I understand that all threats to public health must be confronted, but it is not irrelevant how they are confronted nor who pays for them.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. We are here to discuss proposals regarding salaries and proposals regarding the retirement age, and the least we can say in relation to these proposals is that they are frankly unfair.
they are unfair and insist on recipes that have already proven to be flawed on more than one occasion.

What is happening in Ireland, Greece, Portugal, Spain, Italy, and goodness knows how many more countries—because this is an endless cycle—are different situations in each of these countries, but there are some commonalities.
One of the things we have in common is a hitherto unprecedented transfer of value from labor to financial capital.
We cannot accept this.
The other thing we have in common is that those paying for this crisis are workers, retirees, and pensioners. And an entire generation of precarious workers is also paying for it...

There is no guarantee in the society in which we live. And it is for this reason that I would like to conclude by saying, Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner, we cannot continue to condemn people to poverty.
I sincerely hope.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by saying that I fully support what my colleague has said.

The prevention of natural and man-made disasters is of enormous importance and increasingly so, and the European Commission systematically presents us with a number of procedural intentions and timelines.
but there is a very complex problem, as has already been mentioned.
The Solidarity Fund is an instrument that typically responds to these situations, but responds in a very, very prolonged timeframe, nine months to a year, and this after the catastrophe.

As has already been mentioned, and I repeat, and we will repeat as many times as necessary, there is the case of Madeira. It suffered a massive catastrophe a year ago and has yet to receive any support.
And I ask this, and reinforce this question: is it not the moment for the Commission to review the procedure of the fund itself and the financing model itself?
How can we maintain an exceptional fund to deal with situations that are increasingly chronic?
We do not know where it will happen, but we know that it will happen, and climate change is there to prove it.
Therefore, an exception can never respond to a situation of regularity. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, the concerns raised here regarding disaster prevention and response are a matter of great sensitivity and of the utmost importance to our populations, and should not and cannot be overlooked.

We are discussing very sensitive situations, which affect the safety of people and their possessions, often moving everyone emotionally due to the loss of lives, the devastation of families, and the ruin of entire working lives.

But all our expressions are of little value when confronted with the dramas that, through media, impress and sensitize everyone, if we then fall asleep on the work we must do to ensure those situations can be avoided, minimized, or better assisted.
Commissioner, the matter is very well focused here by my colleagues.

It is an area where the European Union can best demonstrate its presence among its citizens, assisting them in disaster prevention, especially when these events occur, and standing by them in moments when they need it most and are most vulnerable.
I will gladly respond, although I did not wish to transform a debate in the European Parliament into a debate about Portuguese politics.

Incidentally, if Deputy Edith Estrela wishes to debate Portuguese policy, she has a simple solution. We should hold elections, with candidates for the Portuguese Parliament, and she will have the opportunity, in the opposition, to debate with the PSD government the policies she envisions for Portugal.
I say only this: we can no longer endure a government that has failed four times over two years.
It is impossible, it is unsustainable, it is not credible to the markets, there are no further solutions with the socialist government.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, dear colleagues. I begin by congratulating my colleague Schwab on the negotiating persistence that led to this important commitment and I also commend everyone who collaborated with him on this report.

We aim not only to ensure a high level of protection for European consumers, but also to enable European companies, whatever their size, to supply goods and services to consumers in the 27 Member States without unnecessary legal obstacles.

This new directive will eliminate the legislative fragmentation that has been hindering the participation of our companies in the cross-border market and will provide a significant boost to the internal market.
I highlight the new provisions relating to the information to be provided to the consumer, requiring that this information be clear, comprehensible, and made available in a timely manner.
It is also important to note that the burden of proof regarding compliance with information requirements now falls upon the merchant.
Regarding contracts concluded remotely, particularly those completed by telephone or over the internet, their rules should be defined and the consumer protected by simple and effective mechanisms.

We are certain that, at the end of the institutional negotiations, the new directive will contribute to making the European Union more competitive and dynamic, as is required in a global economy. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Chairman of the Council, and Mr. President of the Commission. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate you on the results of the Council of 24 and 25 March, notably for the consolidation of the semester.

European, but much more than that, whether through the institutionalization of the European Stability Mechanism, or through the, let's say, finalization of the Euro Plus Pact, which already stemmed from the Eurozone Summit of March 11th.
I believe these are very positive results for Europe, and it is unfortunate that this process was not fully concluded on March 24th and 25th.
I believe that if we had given that signal, if the States had given that signal in the Council, completely closing this reform package of the fund, we would be in a position today.
stronger to face the 3, 4 months. In part, we would have mitigated the effects of the crisis that my country, Portugal, is currently experiencing, and on which I also do not wish to remain silent.
to say that, in the case of PSD, fully integrated within the PPE, there is absolute and total availability to fulfill the requirements and obligations of integration within the European space.
That is what we have been doing, even now, at this very moment, despite difficulties regarding short-term financing.
Unlike what the Socialist Government has done, the Social Democratic Party has demonstrated a total willingness to provide Europe with the guarantees necessary in the context of this crisis.

And with this, I want to give this signal, without bringing domestic politics into the European Parliament, of fulfillment, commitment, and the total guarantee of the Social Democratic Party regarding the rigorous agenda that the country will have to undertake after its June 5th elections.
Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner Stefan Fule. The historic moment we are living through demands firm and resolute action.
As many of you, we observe the unfolding events in the Mediterranean Basin with a mixture of hope, concern, and anticipation.

I am, however, satisfied with the proactive position the Parliament is preparing to adopt with regard to the review of the European Neighbourhood Policy South, which I hope will lead to a greater presence of the Union in this region, not only as a payer, but equally as a committed partner.
From the outset by affirming the absolute necessity of defending our founding values in relations with neighboring countries.
We can no longer compromise on the defense of democracy, nor on the defense of human rights, and even less so on the defense of social justice.

We can no longer prioritize short-term stability at the expense of the superior interests of citizens and their unwavering defense, their individual and collective freedom, with particular attention to the rights of women.
In the future, the Union must prioritize a bottom-up approach in its neighbourhood policy.
It is essential that this occur.
Only greater involvement of local communities and civil society will guarantee maximum effectiveness in its implementation.

But I cannot fail to express a frustration. I regret that this Parliament and the Commission do not wish to seize this opportunity to definitively differentiate the Eastern Neighbourhood policy from the policy for countries that may potentially become, in the future, our partners within the Union, and the Southern Neighbourhood policy.
I also challenge the Commission to demonstrate, in its review process of April 20th, the ambition that the current moment demands, a neighborhood policy.

Taylor Made, tailored to each State, with clear benchmarks and a careful assessment that allows for the progression towards a future Mediterranean economic space with the new democracies of the South.

To conclude, Mr. Commissioner, we trust that the positive atmosphere and cooperation that have characterized the work on this topic will lead to the permanent involvement of the European Parliament in the planning and evaluation of this policy. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The reports we have debated, and whose rapporteurs I congratulate, reinforce a set of initiatives aimed at revitalizing the internal market.
I would like to highlight the commitment of the European Commission, particularly that of Mr. Commissioner Barnier, whom I welcome, and the positive reception of this Parliament through…
Committee on the Protection of Consumers and the Internal Market, to prioritise competitiveness and dynamism of the market, a fundamental pillar of the 2020 Strategy.
Citizens and businesses expect effective measures to ensure Europe’s economic growth returns, anticipate increased employment, and aspire to the creation of greater prosperity.

And, as the Commissioner highlighted, opening markets to our companies, eliminating obstacles and difficulties, will provide a very special boost and an unparalleled opportunity that will allow them to continue their mission as a driving force of our economy.

The measures aimed at reducing the administrative and bureaucratic burden on SMEs and their access to credit and the services market, the European patent, and the recognition of qualifications are essential.
The relevance of e-commerce development in reinforcing consumer and business confidence in this type of commerce, the investment in innovation.
essential for strong and sustainable growth. Social entrepreneurship is indispensable for creating innovative business projects for social inclusion.
These are some measures that will ensure this ambitious project of completing, deepening, and taking full advantage of the single market for the benefit of European citizens.
Finally, the important recommendation is for Member States to redouble their efforts to improve the transposition and implementation of the internal market rules. Thank you very much.
I also wish to add my voice to those who have expressed concerns here regarding the low incomes of fishermen, exacerbated by historically high fuel prices, particularly in recent months.
As has been very well stated here, fuel costs have a very high impact on the survival of our small and medium-sized shipowners, exacerbating, in particular, the precariousness of fishing incomes.
This remarkable price increase is also bringing us profound negative effects. Reduced outings to sea, meager incomes for fishermen exacerbated by the low prices paid at the initial sale.

increases in imports of aquaculture and fishery products from third countries to the European market and a subsequent abandonment of the activity due to financial difficulties, leading to further job losses.
In this context, to prevent the continuation of the worsening crisis, it is necessary to act, and to act with severity and depth regarding the problems of fishing.

The Commission must, therefore, provide positive responses with short- and long-term measures to address the adversities facing the sector and the serious income losses being experienced by our fishermen.
Mr. Mário, rapporteur, first of all, I want to congratulate, in particular, the work of our EPP colleague, Mário David, whom I represent today because he is absolutely…
I am pleased to be able to attend this plenary session and would like to state that we have always considered support for the victims of the floods in Pakistan to be an ethical and moral imperative.
And therefore, we strongly support all measures that have been taken towards traditional humanitarian aid.
We even consider that work should continue in the effort to help stabilize the situation of so many millions of affected people.
What we cannot accept is that the European Union’s trade policy is now considered a suitable instrument for humanitarian aid.

The truth is that this brings two detrimental consequences. One consequence within the European Union, especially for the Southern countries and their textile and clothing industry, currently highly weakened by an economic, social, and financial crisis unprecedented since…

entry into the Union. And secondly, at the global level, in WTO negotiations, where this openness of the largest trading bloc in the world, which is the European Union, to these potential Pakistani exports, could completely disrupt the negotiations.
It is no accident that they find themselves in the impasse they are in.

It is, therefore, natural that, faced with a situation like this, we have to say, regarding the history of this regulation and the difficulty it encountered during these eight months of intense negotiations.

which we collaborate on the most constructive proposals, we will, unfortunately, have to take a position, a position in the sense of supporting the amendment that, essentially, foresees the end of this proposed regulation, as we know it.
We will have to do so at this moment, not for lack of solidarity with Pakistan, but because we believe that humanitarian aid should be given in the appropriate place and in the appropriate manner.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I would like to begin by saying that, naturally, I believe that the agreement reached for Portugal is a balanced agreement.
It is a very difficult agreement for the populations, but one that places its fundamental point on structural reforms to increase growth and competitiveness.
And I believe that is very positive.

I do not adopt the stance of those who believe that countries like Greece, Ireland, and Portugal did everything correctly, made no mistakes, did not overreach, and acted entirely appropriately, with the international crisis being the sole cause of their problems.
No, our governments made mistakes and pursued flawed policies. But that does not mean there isn’t now an opportunity within the context of the Union to regain the right path and the correct course.

And therefore, it is important to remember here that, in fact, it is necessary to tell public opinions that are against supporting countries in difficulty that they are not giving money to those countries, they are only lending money to those countries.
but they are lending them out at very high interest rates and, therefore, are making a deal that is positive for their budgets and for their populations.

But I also say here that perhaps it is time to have a global European response with the admission of eurobonds, with the admission of the possibility of selling in the primary market to respond to international markets.

It would perhaps be the time for the European Commission, the Fund, and the IMF to review interest rates, in order to provide the possibility of sustained growth for these countries currently facing difficulties, by lowering those rates.

Thank you. I yield the floor for a minute to Mr. Correia de Campos. Many thanks, Mr. President, Commissioner, and Rapporteur. This strategy is important for all European countries, especially those whose economies lack greater competitiveness.
is essential for the creation of small and medium-sized enterprises.
Today, the active generation of new jobs is paramount.
It is essential for universities and laboratories whose relationship with productive sectors depends, in part, on their survival.
It is essential for the financial system, which will have, in innovation, a new market as the classic manufacturing model runs its course.

Innovation is at the top of the European agenda and, being a pillar of the EU 2020 Strategy, will need to be supported by new financial instruments to avoid succumbing to circumstantial budgetary limitations.
I would finally like to commend Judith Merckx for her significant contribution to a more innovative Europe and an economy more grounded in knowledge. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, I would like to begin by congratulating my colleague Odi on his excellent report.

The interim assessment, although belated, allowed for highlighting the critical aspects of the seventh program: its excessive bureaucracy, the industry's lack of interest, the number and complexity of the new instruments, and the slow pace of disbursements.
There remains a greater risk of substantial transfers of funds from the current program framework to large-scale programs of questionable added value.

but also allowed for highlighting positive aspects, greater articulation and international cooperation among scientific groups in common projects, some success stories, including the European Research Council, and a greater gender balance.
There are priorities that must be developed. First, simplification. Second, promoting scientific excellence, not in some countries, but throughout Europe. A closer link of…

Programme Framework for Innovation, with instruments directed at small and medium-sized enterprises and entrepreneurship, the most successful of which is the Eurostars programme, which should be expanded. Thank you.

Madam President, Commissioner, I address you directly regarding the proposal you brought here today to Parliament and I say to you with complete candor that I believe some of us—men and women—have the right to be disappointed with this proposal, because the proposal presented is not only weak but also has countless shortcomings.
I believe this is a European issue, not one of states that have nuclear industry and those that do not; it is a matter for the entirety of Europe, and Europe desperately needs good news.
And I, frankly, must say that one of the good news items is assuring citizens that we are taking care of their safety.
Now, when these tests are carried out as Commissioner presents, that is, a first phase is conducted by the interested parties themselves, a second phase is carried out by the Member States...

These interests are defended by those involved. A third phase is then carried out by peers who are genuinely interested, and I wonder if the outcome will not be to say, ultimately, that all nuclear power plants are in very good health and are recommended.

We know that is not the case, and therefore, I sincerely hope there will be serious consequences and that we can tell our citizens that we are taking care of their safety and not merely pretending to do so. Thank you very much.
I expect this European Council, especially given the climate that has prevailed in recent weeks, to make a decision of great responsibility.
and of greater responsibility than that which occurred in the last Council, where an effort was made to postpone a problem for three months solely due to electoral calendars.

I expect from this decision of responsibility, essentially, that it be recognized that economic and financial issues are crucial and decisive for Europe, but that economic and financial issues are instrumental to what is Europe’s principal purpose, which is the purpose of maintaining peace.
if an approach is made to problems that serves only to cause states to distrust one another, to instill distrust among different states.
To create and stoke differences and rivalries between Southern and Northern states, between central and peripheral states. What we will be led to is the decline of the European Union.

I believe that what is at stake in this European Council, regardless of the technical solutions, regardless of the political disagreements, is to determine whether we do or do not want the European project to continue as a valid strategy for peace in Europe.
Choke—that’s what’s at stake.
What I observe in many speeches by leaders, both those from countries facing difficulties and those from countries that are donor countries.
contributors, it is an irresponsible discourse, which often even appeals to some characteristics of nationalities that are extremely negative.
Therefore, I appeal solely for this, to the sense of responsibility of European government leaders to find solutions that lead Europe to an exit and a resolution.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. My first words are to commend the work undertaken by the rapporteur, my colleague Giorgio Stavrakakis, who has done an extraordinary job in identifying future synergies for enhanced effectiveness between the various structural funds.

Your report also fits within this joint debate on cohesion policy, a debate that assumes the greatest importance not only due to the substance of the topic, but also and above all due to the timeliness of its discussion.
Indeed, we are currently on the verge of learning the Commission’s proposal, both regarding the new financial perspectives and the future cohesion policy post-2013.
Cohesion policy is a fundamental policy for the European Union.

It is a horizontal policy that, through its quintessential instruments, the Structural Funds, finances projects and programs in member states, seeking to reduce disparities between the levels of development of the various regions.
However, experience has shown us the difficulties in terms of efficiency and results that arise from the fragmentation and complexity of this policy.

Therefore, a single strategic framework for the various funds, with an integrated and results-oriented approach, is the starting point for greater and improved synergies among the different instruments and for strengthening their effectiveness.
It is also essential for improved coordination between various sectoral policies and for greater efficiency in the allocation of resources.
We must leverage the danger of crisis to seek new alternatives.

It is certain that all these reports, which are currently under discussion, will pose enormous challenges. And that we know that to respond to these challenges, we also need a sound budget. But we must make a clear distinction between budgetary aspects and political objectives.
Political objectives are well known, and indeed, it is only by asserting these political objectives that we can offer a future to the regions.

And if that is the case, then we must put the budget at the service of the future of the regions and the citizens, and not the citizens and the regions at the service of the budget. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, cohesion policy is the key policy for the future of the European project.
The construction of a common space, with an internal market and a single currency, requires a certain level of convergence among its member states and its regions in order to function.
Current competitiveness disparities and development asymmetries have inevitably led to the weakening of the European space and the crisis affecting the Eurozone.
That is why this vital need for convergence absolutely requires a robust cohesion budget that cannot be weakened to finance other policies.
The European Union, to do more, must be more. And that is achieved by growing its budget, not reducing, even skillfully, the cohesion budget.

Therefore, I ask the Commissioner, whether the creation of the Fund for Infrastructure and New Innovation Policies, which will be coordinated with cohesion and regional development, should it not be possible to achieve this without an increase in the Community budget, could it not be transformed into a Trojan horse introduced into the cohesion budget?

Modernization and the renewal of energy infrastructure are essential factors for the sustainable and intelligent growth objectives we seek with the 2020 Strategy and for our energy security that we need.
It is essential to involve all regions in this challenge.

To this end, the incentives outlined in regulatory systems should be improved, particularly those applicable to higher-risk projects and more innovative projects, such as those being developed in the Azores Islands in renewable energies.

Regions should be associated with the conceptual and implementation phases of projects, in defining priorities, in their development and execution, because this ensures better results and, consequently, a stronger defense of European interests.

The current economic climate further underscores the need to adopt an innovative and integrated approach to energy issues, ensuring that all economic, environmental, and social aspects are taken into consideration.
It is essential not to lose sight of its medium- and long-term effects, seeking to ensure all European citizens have secure, sustainable, and affordable energy.

The report we debated is of particular importance, considering the influence that general interest social services have on the daily lives of European citizens, as well as on social cohesion, job creation, and economic growth.

Collaboration with the Rapporteur for Rural Areas was highly beneficial and enlightening, as the Rapporteur himself just stated, enabling the adoption of several commitments within the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.
Given the outcome we have here today and which we have debated, I commend and congratulate the rapporteur.
In truth, from our side, the principal concern was to make clear that the competencies in this matter belong to the Member States.
National authorities are the holders of the competencies to define, organize, and finance social services of general interest.
Thus, the creation of harmonizing legislation at the European level is unnecessary, given the considerable diversity of these general interest social services in the 27 Member States.

Simply attempting to access health services, social security, employment services, or social housing demonstrates that proximity and knowledge of the context are fundamental to the proper and more equitable provision of these services. Thank you very much.

Madam President, as rapporteur for the REGI Committee’s opinion on the future of general interest services, I would like to congratulate the colleague from Roça, emphasizing the fact that we are dealing with an essential pillar of the social market economy model we defend for Europe and in which general interest services play a fundamental role in its cohesion.

Social cohesion at the European Union level advises against neglecting the existence of minimum protection levels in all Member States, without prejudice to the respect for the competencies of their national, regional, and local authorities.

European regions play a vital role in delivering these services to the populations, and their opinion should be taken into account, given the specific nature of their constraints, to ensure their provision to the populations.

At a time of crisis such as the one we are currently experiencing, general interest social services constitute a social protection network for the most disadvantaged or for those whose income does not allow them access to private services.

Yes, it is important to ensure that Member States decentralizing powers do so accompanied by the corresponding financial resources, so that regional and local authorities can effectively deliver services to the populations.
Mrs. Ashton, I begin by saying that it is obvious that we must continue to support the democratic revolutions that are taking place in these countries.
I don't have much time and, therefore, I only want to leave a few notes.
First, we must not forget that the conditions for negotiation, viewed in light of a democratic transition and not civil war, must be defined by the peoples of these countries.
The situation in Syria is dire, this applies to Syria, but also to Yemen and Bahrain.

If we want to avoid civil war, the last thing these countries need is for Europe to misunderstand their internal affairs and, above all, and very particularly, through the presentation of military or paramilitary solutions.
And if I say this, I say it because we must utterly repudiate what is happening in Libya.
NATO and the United Nations have superseded all resolutions, even those voted for by the United Nations Security Council.
And it is this silence regarding Libya, this repudiation that we must make, and it is because it is not included in this resolution that I cannot subscribe to it. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. President of the Commission, Mr. Prime Minister. Firstly, I would naturally like to congratulate the Polish Presidency on the ambitious program it has brought here and, in particular, to congratulate them on…

neighbourhood policy, not only to the east, but also on the southern border, where I believe a challenge is currently unfolding—perhaps a more demanding one than the one we have to the east, which is more of a long-term and less of a short-term concern.

But, having said that, I would like to ask the Prime Minister and the Polish Presidency to pay special attention to economic integration policies, economic governance, and the supervision of financial markets.

I judge that at this moment, however ambitious our goals may be in the realm of, let us say, defense, energy, food security, the environment, agriculture, and multiannual financial frameworks, if we do not…

To resolve the problem of the debt crisis in the European context in a clear and solid manner before global markets, we will not have a Europe strong enough to deal with these challenges that the Polish presidency has set out to address.

And for that reason, I was emphasizing the importance of convincing the remaining heads of state and heads of government that it is necessary to provide greater economic integration and more economic governance to the European Union.

Without that, what will happen is that we, instead of being the drivers, or at least the representatives of our peoples, whether in the Council, or in Parliament, or in the European Interest Commission, instead of being that, we will be merely…
Mr. President, as President of the Mach Req Delegation, I would like to offer a sentence about each of my, obviously, four countries.
Beginning with Syria and reiterating what some colleagues have also said, it is regrettable that, in the eyes of the public, the international community appears to apply double standards.

It is necessary to denounce, if need be, the countries that, in the Security Council—and I am obviously referring to Russia and China, among others, but with veto power—have prevented the international community from adopting a more cohesive position aligned with the values we share.
Regarding Egypt, I believe there is an urgent need to raise awareness among Egyptian authorities regarding the postponement of elections, as has already been done in Tunisia.
Regarding Lebanon, I believe that a very clear message must emerge from this debate for the new Lebanese government.
so that they are aware that they will be judged based on their conduct with respect to the charges brought by the Special Tribunal for Lebanon.

Regarding Jordan, it serves as an example of how a peaceful transition is possible, and there may be only a need, at this stage, to raise awareness and encourage the authorities to accelerate the reform process.
We cannot forget, obviously, in a debate of this kind, the peace process in the Middle East and reiterate our hope that the meeting of the Quartet next Monday may.
Indeed, to be productive and to reaffirm that this House would certainly like to see a much greater involvement of the European Union throughout this process.

I have no doubts that there will be a new round of negotiations before the United Nations General Assembly in September, but I hope that this round of negotiations will be productive and conducted in good faith.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur and everyone who contributed to achieving this work.
There is no doubt that this report constitutes and will constitute a reference point with regard to recommendations and solid, coordinated responses to the challenges of the crisis.
If the conclusion to be drawn is that the crisis we are experiencing will only be overcome with a deepening of European integration.

In a time of severe financial, economic, and social difficulties, and of painful austerity measures in some Member States, as in my country, Portugal, there is a temptation to seek refuge in a protectionist and nationalist attitude.
But I know a mistake.

The European response to the crisis involves a genuine European economic governance that pursues sustainable growth, promotes job creation, and develops the social market economy, providing long-term answers with defined objectives that Member States can identify with.
The strategy for exiting the crisis needs to be financed with a sufficiently ambitious community budget.
To avoid another sovereign debt and euro crisis, closer coordination on budgetary policies is necessary, as well as the creation of a system for issuing bonds, public debt, and euro-bonds.
I conclude by emphasizing that during this difficult period, it is also necessary to maintain social protection levels, particularly for the most vulnerable citizens. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, Presiding Nation, it is customary to say that crises help strengthen Europe.
Historically, this was the case, but today I am not so certain that this continues to be true.

The slow, improvised, reactive manner in which the Union is responding to the Greek crisis exacerbates the situation daily and spreads contagion and a lack of confidence in the Union and its currency in a frightening way.
This is despite the problems of the eurozone resulting from obvious flaws in the construction of the single currency, which today are concentrated in its most vulnerable links.

For the current crisis to result in the strengthening of the Union, a strategic vision is needed, as existed in the past, and which, unfortunately, neither the Commission nor the Council have been able to impart to the European programme and project.
This parliamentary report, however, provides us with this perspective. More Europe, not less, is the solution.
Parliament recalls that the market and the single currency generate intolerable divergences between economies and must be countered by specific policies.

It recognizes that the functioning of the euro requires a reinforced European budget financed by own resources, requires a European agency for the joint issuance of debt, capable of protecting Member States from market speculation.

and to provide them with credit at reasonable prices and terms. It also recognizes that diplomas and the transferability of workers between countries require mutual recognition of social rights and pensions.
Parliament has united to send clear messages. Let us hope that the Commission and the Council will heed them.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed rapporteur, first and foremost, I would naturally like to congratulate the rapporteur for considering this report extremely useful and, indeed, enabling us to take new steps in the area of mediation.
The report presents an overview, a range of solutions adopted by the various Member States in the implementation, the application of…
Directive 2852/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 21 May 2008, currently relating to mediation in civil and commercial matters.
Now, we all know the advantages of mediation.
On one hand, it is an extrajudicial method of conflict resolution, contributing to the decongestion of the courts, to the rationalization of the justice system, and simultaneously providing
providing the parties simultaneously with the possibility of obtaining an amicable, faster, and less costly solution, less burdensome than the dispute in which they were embroiled.

It is therefore essential to reaffirm the objective of Article 1 of the Directive when it calls for the adoption of measures to encourage the use of alternative dispute resolution methods and, in particular, mediation.
Promoting access to and utilization of extrajudicial conflict resolution mechanisms contributes to improving, simplifying, and making our justice system more accessible.

It is, therefore, a very important challenge for the European Union and for the establishment of the area of freedom, security and justice, I would say, for the idea of the rule of law within the European Union.
And it is for this reason that, within this context of crisis as well, I consider it very important that, as stated in the report, public opinion and stakeholders can be made aware.
judicial bodies on this topic and appeal here to the Commission and to the Commissioner to present a legislative proposal on alternative dispute resolution as quickly as possible.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Commissioner, I also want to refer to the fundamental importance of this report regarding the transparency of the European energy market.
And I simply want to say that this is a central domain of cooperation in European terms, provided we safeguard some of the dimensions that are fundamental. Among them, avoiding that the...

ensure that liberalization does not translate into increased energy prices for citizens, guarantee equal access, and exercise caution regarding sanctions, as numerous colleagues have already mentioned.
And precisely because this is a central domain of European cooperation, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I cannot fail to mention and to question you, and to ask you directly, Commissioner.
I would like to offer you the opportunity to explain yourself regarding the recent statements you made concerning Greece, Ireland, and Portugal, as these are also matters of European cooperation.
Symbolic measures such as raising flags, Mr. Commissioner, serve only to reinforce the shame of citizens who are worthy and who fight for a Europe.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Shevkovich, Commissioners, Members of the Council, Polish Presidency. Firstly, I would like to clarify that I will be intervening here in a dual capacity. On the one hand, substituting the rapporteur for the Committee on Affairs.

constitutional matters, my colleague Messer Schmidt, Danish, who is absent due to the ongoing election process in Denmark at this time and, therefore, I am representing him as a member of the Africa group, but also as a member of the Jury, as the rapporteur shadow on the Jury of this report.

The first point I wanted to make is that in the crisis we are experiencing, the economic and financial crisis, the question of intelligent regulation, of smart regulation, of better legislation is a central one.

There is no doubt that, in the so-called structural reforms that can drive the economic and financial recovery of the European space, improvements in legislation and regulation are also absolutely essential.

It is evident that a Europe which aspires, on the one hand, to be dynamic and competitive must have simple and accessible regulation for businesses and, obviously, for citizens as well. And therefore, it must be oriented towards their needs.
The truth is that, in this sense, it is essential today that, first and foremost, the program of reducing administrative burdens be achieved, and that all efforts be made in the direction of...

to facilitate consultations with market agents, representative citizens' and businesses' associations, and to assess the impact of the legislation itself; this is also extremely important, so that the…
