the decision-making process could essentially be based, let's say, precisely on the opinion of those who are the recipients of the legislation, and be carried out without administrative burdens and with fewer economic and financial costs.

It is important to note that, for the Committee on Constitutional Affairs in particular, the idea of the principle of proportionality and subsidiarity is relevant—this idea that European intervention should be an appropriate intervention and not one that promotes the complexity of the system.

legal and regulatory system. And therefore, we have given special attention, in our opinion, to the strengthened role that National Parliaments have in this dynamic, precisely due to the principle of proportionality and the principle of subsidiarity.

It is therefore essential that, at the level of Smart Regulation and at the level of legislative improvement, we now involve the National Parliaments so that, whether at the European level or at the national level, both legislation and regulation are developed.

Let us be more agile, more intelligent, more efficient. And therefore, this is a good moment to put into practice what we announce every day: a more competitive Europe and a more agile Europe through smarter regulation.
Mr. President, the number of homeless people, as well as those living below the poverty threshold, has continued to increase in recent years in several Member States.
The economic, financial, and social crisis, and the rise in unemployment, have exacerbated this problem, as everyone has already diagnosed.
We also all agree that this phenomenon is a negation of important values of the European Union, respect for human dignity and respect for fundamental rights.

In my country, for example, which is subject to a significant austerity measure, the concept of homelessness, according to the National Plan, encompasses individuals who seek assistance to obtain a meal.
and the number of people seeking assistance with eating has increased by more than 20% since 2008.
A greater increase is observed in families and individuals in need whose living situations have been altered by unemployment and also by bank indebtedness.
This is merely an example that demonstrates the gravity of this situation.
Last year, the European Parliament approved a written declaration on a European Union strategy for people experiencing homelessness.

With this declaration, this Parliament highlighted the need for the European Union to equip itself with a strategy underpinned by national and regional strategies, with the long-term objective of eliminating situations of people sleeping rough and prolonged homelessness.

National strategies should focus on preventive measures, but also on concrete actions to improve the quality of services provided to people experiencing homelessness and the provision of affordable housing.
It is also evident that this European strategy must be compatible with the social housing policy of the Member States.
We took good note of the Commissioner’s words and recorded the state of affairs that was presented to us.

I conclude by urging the European Commission to provide a strong impetus for coordinating the action of Member States and regional authorities in order to combat this social injustice. Thank you very much.
Mr. President, we have debated the peace process in the Middle East, but is there some process underway that has escaped me?
Unfortunately, no.

The European Union repeatedly states, as does the majority of the international community, in favor of the existence of two peoples and two states, sharing the space between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean, which have the right to aspire to live in peace and security.
But without dialogue between the parties, entrenched in an escalating tide of hatreds and misunderstandings that has persisted for 63 years, only extremism and frustration are fueled.

It is fundamental that Europe and the Arab League become much more involved in seeking a negotiated solution for the borders, based on those existing in 1967, with exchanges that allow the majority of Jewish settlements to remain in Israel.

May the question of Jerusalem, a holy city, future capital of two states, be clarified and mutually accepted as a symbol of peaceful coexistence between two peoples who have the obligation to fulfill Isaiah's prophecy that it is the land of milk and honey.

that all countries of the Union participate in the resolution of the question of Palestinian refugees and that the international community, and in particular the Arab nations, participate in the necessary financial compensation.

It is also absolutely essential that a military force under the aegis of the UN and the participation, among others, of American and Islamic forces be deployed on the ground as a guarantor of peace maintenance.
Thus, let there be courage and political will.

Thank you, Mr. President. Commissioner, tourism requires a clear and coordinated European approach, with careful consideration of the potential and challenges that different tourism modalities have to offer us.
The tourist diversity presented by the European Union is so rich that it allows for exponential growth of this sector and of the Union’s competitiveness itself.

An investment in this key sector, which represents 10% of GDP and approximately 12% of employment in the European Union, will enable not only the creation of European added value, but also address the economic crisis in which we find ourselves.
It originates from an ultraperipheral region, Madeira, where tourism is the primary economic activity.

And therefore, the creation of a specific heading for the sector within the financial framework 2014-2020 is indispensable for the cohesive and sustainable growth of tourism, which is essentially comprised of small and medium-sized enterprises.

The realization of a genuine, sustainable, and diversified European tourism policy requires a concrete strategic plan, with a clearly defined timeline, actions, and funding, capable of reinforcing the visibility and quality of the tourism sector within the European Union.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. The absence of an ongoing peace process is jeopardizing fundamental rights and has led to the adoption of unilateral measures by each party, which are not.

contributed in no way to a resolution of tensions in the region and even less to the effective pursuit of a life for the two peoples who have the right to live harmoniously in peace, security, and with dignity.

The time has come for the international community to say enough. The time has come for Europe and the Arab League to drive the search for a lasting solution, with reason, presenting viable solutions, without delay and with deadlines.
It is evident that the United States and Russia are no longer part of the solution.
Let us begin with Jerusalem. Why not reclaim the initial idea of a separate corpus administered by the UN and that functions, obviously, as the capital of the two states?
Borders. Let's begin with those of 1967.
Land parcels should be exchanged whenever feasible and coherent.

Take care of the defense of Israel, a subject obviously unavoidable for the Jewish people, for example, through the deployment of blue helmets with American, European, and Islamic forces alongside the Jordan River.
Refugees number approximately 4.8 million and have the right to their dignity, to a future linked to a homeland, preferably their own.

but they are not exclusively an Israeli or Palestinian problem; they are also ours, those of the neighboring Arab countries, the broader Arab community, but also of Europe and the rest of the international community.
colonates, having to put an end to their expansion, and that is non-negotiable.
Today’s announcement is shameful and betrays hypocrisy and bad faith in an offer of immediate negotiations.

Above all, we desire negotiations in good faith, earnestly pursued, with a deadline for their conclusion, after which the international community, to maintain its credibility, will need to adopt a different stance.

Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, the shameful situation in the refugee camps in Tunisia has already been mentioned here; we all share it, and I strongly echo what my colleagues who just spoke have said.
I will not refer to that, in particular, I am referring to another situation that is more omitted, namely, the citizens who were received into the homes of families in Tunisia.

And that is one of the situations that should leave us even more ashamed, because let us observe, Tunisia, in a situation of crisis, proved to be supportive. Europe has not been able to show solidarity and is not undergoing a transition to democracy, and has not known how to be supportive, has not known how to receive.
I believe it is, in fact, shameful that we can count the number of refugees received in Europe as only a few hundred.
Many of these people, contrary to what has been said, cannot, simply cannot, return to their homes.
and there were children who were enrolled in public schools, which has implications at the infrastructure level, and implications regarding the reception of these children in these countries.
And that is why, Madam Commissioner, I am deeply moved by your appeal, and I do not say this ironically, but seriously. But, please, what about the Commission?
And Europe!
What can be done?
How does Europe live so well with this double standard?
We are so swift in repatriating and so slow in assisting, Commissioner.
It cannot continue like this.

Mr. President, I naturally wanted to congratulate you on this supplement of hope that you have given to all European deputies and, in particular, to the citizens of the European Union whom we represent here.

And having said that, I would like to say that we now expect a very, very determined action from the Commission towards the Council so that this sovereign debt crisis can be resolved in the short term.
We know it’s a marathon, but immediate signals are necessary.

And therefore, without prejudice to our already beginning to consider an amendment to the treaties that would give political translation to the entire project we have brought here today, notwithstanding that, something must be done immediately.

This set of measures, and perhaps an agreement between States, what I have termed a sort of parasocial agreement that goes beyond treaties, and which may, from this moment forward, set in motion all these ideas.
Many congratulations on your courage and your determination.
I believe that we are on the right track and we are leaving here today with renewed determination.

Mr. President, the crisis that the European Union is experiencing has had serious consequences in all Member States, and thousands of workers have been affected by layoffs caused by globalization and the crisis.
We cannot fail to affirm our solidarity with these workers who have lost their jobs and to assert that Europe must assist Member States in maintaining an employment rate and combating unemployment.
A rapid reintegration of workers into the labor market is a priority objective.

An example of the utility of this fund is my country, Portugal, which has accessed it four times, although we are aware that access to this fund could be improved, particularly in the countries most affected by the crisis.

Thanks to the existence of this Globalisation Adjustment Fund, it has been possible to assist thousands of workers through professional training measures, support for business creation, and incentives for recruitment.
This proposal is positive because it will allow Member States to request the intervention of this Fund to support workers dismissed as a direct consequence of the economic and financial crisis.
We support the extension of the deadline and understand that the Member States most affected by the crisis should have greater access and easier access to this Globalization and Crisis Support Fund.
Thank you, Mr. President. I greet the Polish Presidency and also Mr. Commissioner Ali Ren, simply to say that I believe...
And today, following and developing what was presented in the State of the Union address, a very, very significant step was taken to resolve the problems of the Eurozone crisis.
because the Commission has here reaffirmed its commitment to use its power of initiative and to work with the Council to resolve this crisis.
I believe this is an extremely important step and is the only way we have at this moment to resolve the Eurozone crisis.
There is no possibility of resolving this in the short term with an intergovernmental approach alone. And therefore, it is necessary for the States, the governments of the States, to give...
the commission the instruments and the mandate to lead this resolution process, to implement, execute, and develop this roadmap that it presented here.
But I didn't want to fail to say that this is not incompatible with what we do simultaneously, with what we develop simultaneously our capacity to amend treaties.

I am also convinced that, in the medium term, it is necessary to alter the treaties, but also there we will have to do so with the aim of strengthening, in the sense of giving more force and a greater position to the Commission.

It is through the reinforcement of the community method, initially in the short term and subsequently with a revision of the treaties in the long term, that we will achieve greater integration and a solution for the seventeen countries of the Eurozone and for the twenty-seven countries of the European Union.

Thank you, Mr. President. Dr. Durão Barroso came here today to announce that, as one of the measures, banks that do not have sufficient capital requirements must present plans to obtain them, and if they are unable to present them, they must then suspend dividends and bonuses.
I could not help but agree with this presentation delivered by the President.
This week we witnessed what happened with Banco Dexia, and just months ago an administrator of this bank received a prize of 600,000 euros for his exceedingly wonderful management, as we know.
But to be serious, the President of the Commission must call on the governments and present the complete package. And the complete package is what contains the essentials.
The essential point is that taxpayers’ money must be matched by a credit policy for growth.
The essential thing is that banks begin to pay taxes on their profits, which does not happen in many countries, notably in my country, Portugal.
In two years, or rather, in three years, it is the second time we are asked to save the banks with taxpayers’ money, with the money of the unemployed.
Banks that save the economy should also assist in job creation.
Mr. President, Madam High Representative, there are moments when I believe we need to be concise and take stock, and this appears to be one of those moments.
It seems to me that this is because we are always moving to the rhythm of events and responding to event after event, and we lose a little bit of the perspective of the whole.

It is true that each case is unique, and each country we are discussing here is a specific case, but, if you will pardon me, Madam High Representative, it seems to me that it is difficult to scrutinize the criteria that the European Union has been using to act in relation to each of these cases.
We fear that, often, we are held hostage by the interests of the countries of the European Union, by a portion of those countries of the European Union, and not by all of them.
And it is for this reason that we frequently use the expression "two weights and two measures" in this House, and we continue to do so.

Sometimes it is sanctions, sometimes it is not. Sometimes the interference extends to the brink of bombing, as was the case with Libya. Other times it is total silence, as was the case with the invasion of Bahrain by the forces of…

Saudi Arabia. And, Baroness, let me say, I have studied all the files attentively; I have yet to see a single statement from European institutions condemning the invasion of Bahrain by the military forces of Saudi Arabia.

These are death sentences, an endless violence. They are doctors and nurses condemned to up to 30 years in prison by a military tribunal because they were allegedly opposing the regime and not assisting the wounded who needed them.
Regarding the dictatorial monarchy of Bahrain and regarding the dictatorial regime of Yemen, the Saleh regime, we have had far more silences than actions.

I am not in favor of interference, never have been, but I fear we are placing ourselves in an uncomfortable position, the position viewed from the outside, Lady Baroness, which is, instead of assisting development, aspirations...

democratic and revolutionary movements of the peoples in the Arab countries. Instead of helping the First Arab Spring, what we do is prevent it from spreading, whether through excess or deficiency, and I don't think we should bear that sin.
I hope the awarding of the Nobel Prize to a Yamita activist can serve as a sign that our side is the side of the peoples who are in revolution. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Madam President. Commissioner, this is a good report from the honourable member of the House.
Firstly, it is necessary to ask why revisiting VAT in the European Union.
First, the need to reconcile it with the single market.
The more regimes and varieties of VAT, the less fluid the market will be.
A reform of the VAT favors e-commerce, centers competition on the base value and price of goods and services, and not on tax differentials.
combats fraud and ensures the necessary trust, especially in cross-border transactions, improves the economy of SMEs, and reduces administrative burdens.
What other measures concerning Youth are already underway in the single market that could be associated with VAT?
First, a simple, clear, and transparent digital support mechanism, Measure Seven of the single market.
Measure 5, concerning services, the need to review legislation on standardization and the implementation of the directive on…
The new measure, intended to remove fiscal obstacles and explicitly review the VAT system and VAT equalization in online and face-to-face commerce, which we all experience when ordering books.
The pressures for VAT reform stem from two fundamental orders of reasons.
First, the economic crisis
More revenue measures are needed, including, likely in some countries, a reduction of contributions on labor to promote economic development, shifting that burden to VAT.

Secondly, the second major source of pressure is population aging, demographic aging, and the tendency to shift taxes from indirect to direct taxation, due to the reduction in the tax base population.
It is necessary to rethink the balance between direct and indirect taxation.
Finally, we must, in these reforms, reconcile subsidiarity with harmonization.
It is necessary to restrict the variation range in the standard VAT rate so that we can all better understand.
Greater transparency is needed in the definition of the reduced VAT rate and its scope of application, along with a clear and widely publicized list of the reduced rates.
It is necessary to study exemption thresholds for SMEs, fully aware that each exemption brings with it a retinue of small or large frauds.
Finally, to welcome the Commission's recent proposal to create a European VAT.
Madam President, I thank my colleague Rula for the excellent report she prepared.

The advantages of public procurement are certainly well known, but the obstacles are also evident. Conflicts of interest between European legislation and the objectives of Member States hinder competitiveness.
The dichotomy between price quality and the complexity of laws and procedures is evident.
It is fundamental to examine existing best practices, particularly in Portugal, where electronic procurement has functioned well and has facilitated public contracting.
Effective European public procurement represents a privileged means of controlling public deficits and fostering greater growth.
It should, for this purpose, have a stable and predictable legal framework, less bureaucratic procedures to attract SMEs, and defend social and environmental values.

It is for this reason that I express satisfaction with the intentions presented to us here by Mr. Commissioner Barnier for the review of public procurement, still this year, as one of the 12 priorities of the Single Market Act. Thank you.
Congratulate colleague Rula and all those who collaborated with her.
Important in the realm of public contracts is the matter of electronic public procurement.
that, unfortunately, the objectives proposed by the European Union—50% of renunciations via electronic procedure in 2010—failed, existing at an average value of just 5%.
Only a few countries, such as my own, Portugal, have succeeded in this area.

The advantages of electronic public procurement are overwhelmingly evident and have been outlined here. It allows for the replacement of costly access procedures with the simple consultation of the electronic platform, that is, it significantly reduces costs for companies, especially smaller ones.

small and medium-sized enterprises. Internet dissemination and the ease of receiving procedural documents broaden the number of suppliers, increasing competition and enabling better purchasing. It streamlines the allocation process for public contracts...

Easier and more flexible, it simplifies access to European Union public contracts, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises, thereby facilitating their participation in the market for these public contracts, key drivers of the economy.
In this regard, we welcome and encourage the European Commission in reinforcing mechanisms to transform electronic public procurement into an increasingly comprehensive reality. Thank you very much.

We are living decisive hours for the destiny of Europe. And if the situation has swiftly evolved, before the eyes of all, from a problem of the Greeks or the Portuguese to a problem of considerable European scale, the truth is that the inadequacy of the proposed solutions and their delay have not produced any effectiveness in the rapid deterioration of the situation.
The pursuit of solutions directed towards individual States, at the expense of truly European solutions, allowed markets to continue speculating on sovereign debt and imposed deadlines and timelines.
absolutely impossible that some States are seeking to achieve with measures of a brutality previously unimaginable, applied to people, businesses, and the public sector.

A common solution, already found for the risk of European sovereign debt, is absolutely indispensable—one that will deflect market pressure and speculation and provide the time necessary for the essential adjustments to be made.
Without that, what we will have in the end are countries that will continue without the means to pay their creditors, devastated economies, and immense suffering.

I extend my thanks to the colleague rapporteurs Sombra, with whom I had a fruitful collaboration, and I also thank the rapporteurs of the partners from the four commissions involved. These partners represent a valuable contribution to this report.
We received 400 amendments and drafted 47 commitments, all of which were approved.
This demonstrates the importance and the interest aroused by this topic of new skills and jobs.
Ultimately, it concerns preparing Europe's human resources, anticipating the needs of the labor market in the next decade.
The key strategy for preparing the report was to rephrase commonplace ideas to avoid repetitions and ensure the report's coherence.
I believe that objective was achieved.
We all know that the crisis currently affecting us has exposed the vulnerabilities of the European economic and social model, as well as nullified many of the advancements achieved in the past.
Since the initial effects of the crisis began to be felt in labor markets in 2008, Europe has already lost more than 5 million jobs.
Today, there are nearly 23 million people without employment.
Youth unemployment is even more alarming. The youth unemployment rate is nearing 21% and represents more than double the general unemployment rate.
Conversely, in all Member States, unemployment rates vary with levels of qualification.
This means that individuals with higher qualifications find employment more readily.
We also know that in the near future, the need for skills, competencies, and qualifications will increase across all types and levels of profession.
In this context, Europe faces four challenges. First, job creation. Second, the need to develop and remain competitive.
Subsequently, the sustainability of social security systems and, finally, the difficulty in finding people with the appropriate skills to fill job openings.

This report, therefore, has a dual objective. Firstly, to underscore the need for swift action to address skills gaps in Europe. Secondly, to better anticipate the labor market's needs regarding skills.

To this end, several measures are highlighted. First, to ensure the availability of qualified labor, it is necessary to improve basic skills, as well as competencies in science, innovation, information and communication technologies, and foreign languages.
As I have already mentioned, skill needs should be identified early on, with a horizon of at least 10 years.
Today, the potential of a new sustainable economy, the green economy, and the need for investment in ecological qualifications are recognized.
Subsequently, participation in lifelong learning and professional requalification should be increased, as should efforts to reduce school dropout rates.
Another important matter is the mutual recognition of diplomas and professional qualifications, and the urgency of advancing this recognition.
Fourthly, we draw attention to the link that must exist between educational institutions and the needs of the labor market.
Internships should be of high quality and supervised by tutors in order to lead to employment and eliminate any potential abuse of the trainee situation.
Particular emphasis is also given to the role of social partners and social dialogue.
The report also proposes measures to promote demand and job creation.
We have a future ahead of us and we must create jobs.
And small and medium-sized enterprises play a decisive role in achieving that objective.

It is also necessary to reinforce the single market to facilitate the free movement of workers, and from that, the need for coordination of social security systems so that workers can have their acquired rights guaranteed, particularly the portability of pensions.
Finally, the issue of labor market flexibility. To improve the functioning of the labor market, flexicurity rules should be adapted to the socio-economic contexts of each Member State. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I begin by thanking all colleagues who participated in this lively debate.
All colleagues offered very useful interventions and contributed to a highly constructive discussion on an ambitious agenda at a time when we are experiencing a serious crisis.

Incidentally, this discussion is taking place precisely on the eve of an EU Council meeting that will reveal whether or not there is political will to overcome the challenges we are facing and whether there is political will to overcome the challenges we are facing.

a policy for deepening our coordination in economic terms and whether there is genuinely a harmonized and unitary will to carry forward the ambition that is set out in this agenda. In other words, to have

New jobs in the coming decade, new jobs that will lead to unemployed young people today and those currently in training having hope in the labor market, having hope in an inclusive labor market, one that responds to their…

ambition for self-improvement through work and who also have the opportunity to be in a state of permanent dynamism, to keep pace with the challenges of a globalized economy and with a dynamic unlike any seen in recent generations.
Therefore, our ambition is truly to foster job creation and economic growth, not only to respond to those who are unemployed as a result of the crisis, but also to those who will enter the workforce.

responding to the significant challenges that lie ahead with the green economy, with services in the health sector, with services in the transportation sector, and with housing, which require from all of us a different vision, an intelligent vision, and an inclusive vision of the labor market.
Thank you all.

Marisa Matias. Thank you very much, Madam President. What was stated today here in the Council's declaration is that, for technical reasons, democracy would have to be sacrificed in matters concerning the European semester. But what we are discussing is a political issue, and the question I pose is whether political coordination can exist without democracy.
Where, then, is the European Parliament’s scrutiny?
Where does the scrutiny of National Parliaments regarding their major budgetary choices take place?

But, if the question were technical, as has been stated here, then we are talking about a variable technique. Because we know how the Council substantially alleviated the conditions for the four countries on the waiting list, France, Italy, Hungary, and Spain. It did not do the same with respect to the countries under bailout.
Therefore, what model of intergovernmentalism is this that allows Germany to express opinions about Portugal, but does not allow Portugal to express opinions about Germany?
And, Mr. Commissioner, I simply ask that you pay attention to this. No problem of democratic legitimacy is resolved by asking deputies to consult information on the internet.
This is an issue of information exclusion, not a problem of democratic exclusion, which is the one we are discussing here.

Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, colleagues. A first word to congratulate the rapporteur Ardenne on the quality and timeliness of this report and also Commissioner Andor for the initiatives announced.
Poverty is truly a very serious problem that demands effective and rapid action to halt the increase of a phenomenon that, currently, affects more than 80 million Europeans.
The grave crisis we are experiencing has exacerbated this situation and made the times we are living through dramatic, as Commissioner Andor stated.
The number of people unemployed continues to rise, and we all know that a lack of employment is a gateway to poverty and social exclusion.
This panorama demands resources, resolve, and considerable effort from the European Commission and the Member States.
If this does not occur, the objective of lifting 20 million European citizens out of poverty during this decade will not be achieved.
Therefore, I warmly commend the initiative of the Platform against Poverty, which is a very important instrument for ensuring social justice.
However, there is no doubt that the best antidotes to poverty and social exclusion are the creation of jobs and the promotion of economic growth.
Mr. President, internet access should today be considered a fundamental right of citizens and not merely a commercial object.
depend on essential elements such as freedom of expression, access to and sharing of information, access to and sharing of culture and knowledge, as well as democratic and media pluralism.

And that is why this access cannot be subject to speculative tariffs or contracts that block free choice and the possibility of easily changing suppliers, particularly in the world of mobile telecommunications, as we also know.
Active citizenship therefore requires that complete and transparent information be provided.
The blocking of internet usage is not exclusive to political regimes that fear their people.
It can also occur as a result of economic choices, through the offering of privileges to potential clients and a less equitable treatment of clients who are not as profitable.
That is why I support the Parliament by clearly standing alongside the neutrality of the internet and the defense of its character of total openness.
Let us tell the truth.
We have been taking the medication for three years to overcome the crisis, and the situation worsens day by day.
Instead of healing, we created two fatal vicious cycles.
The first between banks and States.
In Europe, the failure of a state is more easily discussed today than that of a large bank, but it is still expected that banks will finance states and that states will save their banks.
This spiral must be broken.
The Commission must proceed with European legislation to protect taxpayers from bank crises.
but it is also vital to protect the debt of States from speculators’ attacks.

And to that end, it is urgent and overdue to prepare coordinated sovereign debt issuances, whether they are called eurobonds or stability bonds, and to guarantee them through robust instruments of a community and not intergovernmental nature.
In sum, we must also review the involvement of the European Central Bank.
But the second vicious circle results from the argument that some States are rich because they are virtuous, while others are poor because they have sinned.
This narrative is politically explosive and technically flawed.

She ignores the essential fact that a single market and a single currency, built by political choice among unequal partners, necessarily exacerbates competitiveness imbalances between the core and the periphery.
And that is what must be targeted in economic governance.
No, Mr. Rompoy, through sanctions that promote the crushing of salaries and income with one country’s control over another.
Previously, Commissioner, through engagement – both of countries with surpluses and of countries with deficits – to converge productivity through investment, education, and science.
The tensions have only generated unemployment, disillusionment, and another form of which we cannot account.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. Integrated maritime policy advocates a coordinated approach to the management and governance of oceans, seas, and coasts from a global perspective and in coherence with all European policies related to the sea.

Having a global perspective and an integrated approach implies the interaction of European maritime policies and calls for improved governance through greater involvement in the European decision-making process.
The success and relevance of this policy have been demonstrated over the past years through the various initiatives funded in the form of preparatory actions and pilot projects.
Consequently, integrated maritime policy should continue to benefit from adequate funding during the coming years of the current financial programming period.
In this regard, I advocate for adequate funding until 2013, not only to consolidate previous projects, and I support the definition of a stable framework regarding the objectives of this program.

Issues of policy, governance, sustainability, and maritime surveillance are, for obvious reasons, topics that particularly interest certain regions of the European Union, such as the outermost regions.

RUPs are regions, with the exception of French Guiana, which are insular and of small size, dependent on a limited number of economic activities and in which activities related to the sea and fishing assume particular importance.
Furthermore, the outermost regions contribute to the European Union having the world’s largest exclusive economic zone.

EEZs represent more than half of the European Union’s exclusive economic zone, approximately 15 million square kilometers out of 25 million, and, together with coastal regions, are fundamental to the economic growth of the European Union and its Member States.
A program such as the constant of integrated maritime policy should benefit these regions, prioritizing transnational coordination of maritime policies and relevant international cooperation.
Therefore, it is necessary to guarantee continuous and sufficient funding, not only for the next two years, but also and especially for the next financial framework starting in 2014.
To fail to seize the opportunity when discussing integrated maritime policy to underscore the immense potential held by the Atlantic and insular dimension for the European Union.

The Atlantic, being the western maritime border of Europe, also establishes its connection to North and South America and to Africa, conferring a strategic dimension for Europe indispensable in the architecture of a maritime policy designed with an eye to the future.

And it is with a view to the future that integrated maritime policy, beyond promoting the coordination of maritime activities, should place the potential of the Atlantic in its three-dimensional dimension—based on science and technology—at the forefront of its priorities.

Investigation of the Mid-Atlantic Ridge, the deep sea, and the seafloor represents a new frontier whose potential exists in biotechnology and mineral resources, and is of incalculable value to the knowledge economy.
The Union should therefore leverage the Azores’ privileged position and the excellence of its oceanographic department to install a Deep Sea Observatory there. Thank you.
Enough of this path.
When the diagnosis is incorrect, the medications are ineffective.
And in the case of the Eurozone, excessive remedies have brought it right to the brink.
The successive miraculous solutions that were proposed were also equally discredited by the markets.
the Financial Stabilization Fund, successive corset-like reinforcements of the Stability and Growth Pact, the revenues from the Troika in countries under programs.
The blind discipline without growth generated a recessive wave among fully interconnected economies, which were thereby contaminated by bankruptcies and unemployment.
And at the mercy of the markets—that is, the rating agencies and speculators—governments are falling one after another, and solvent countries are becoming insolvent.

Altering treaties now is yet another step on this disastrous trajectory, with an aggravating factor. We risk destroying what remains of national sovereignty, placing countries in the hands of the European Court of Justice.
No, it is not necessary to alter the treaties.
It is necessary, in this emergency situation in which we find ourselves, to make two decisions.
First, it is necessary to establish a genuine agenda for sustained growth and cohesion.
Where is the 2020 Agenda?
Where is the relaunch budget?
Where are those so-called Project Bonds for Europe’s structural investments?
Secondly, it is necessary to protect sovereign debt.
Naturally, eurobonds are necessary, but in this emergency in which we find ourselves, it is urgent that the European Central Bank, directly or indirectly, defend sovereign debt against speculators.
not in a hesitant way, but with a definitive, resolute stance, as befits any central bank defending its currency and the economy that supports it.
To this end, it is not necessary to amend the treaties; what is required is political will and European conviction.
We will move the treaty when we have drawn all the lessons from the present crisis. And there are no few lessons to be drawn, but this is certainly not the moment. Thank you very much.
Mr. President and Mr. Commissioner Dali, the first Single Market Forum, an idea stemming from the Greco report, took place in Kraków.
It was rich in content and fruitful in the debate conducted by the Polish Presidency with European, national, regional, and local authorities, and civil society.
We have a roadmap aligned with the Commission's communication of April 12th and the 12 levers.
It needs to be enshrined in law, as well as the strategy for the other thirty-eight priorities identified in the act for the single market.
For a market to exist, trust is necessary.
Now, the trust of citizens and consumers cannot be taken for granted; it requires stimulation, cultivation.

The single market is not merely a matter of buying and selling; it involves horizontal policies such as health, social and consumer protection, labour law, the environment, and sustainable development.
Consequently, the Single Market Forum should become a flagship event of the European Union, with an annual occurrence and a diverse and increasingly participatory audience.
Mr. President, I believe we are at a point of assessing these crisis policies, austerity policies that have affected so many countries, and also the so-called structural reforms.
And it is within this context that I believe we cannot fail to see how they have generated so much social upheaval.
and has generated social confusion not only in the countries facing the greatest difficulties, in the Global South, not only in the so-called PIGS, but also in other contexts throughout Europe.
Last week, Portugal witnessed its largest general strike ever, encompassing both the public and private sectors—a strike that took to the streets.

But if we look at what happened today in the United Kingdom, we see that we witnessed the largest strike ever, especially if we take into account that people also took to the streets as they did in Portugal.
And we anticipate a significant demonstration in Brussels on Friday.

What this demonstrates, Mr. President, and what strikes and people taking to the streets demonstrate, is that the causes and problems we have faced are common, and it is for this reason that the reaction is also common.
The crisis of the European Union is spreading to all Member States, reaching unbelievable proportions.

We are witnessing chaos in the financial markets and a growing inability to secure essential financing for our small and medium-sized enterprises, even those that are healthy, leading them to despair, bankruptcy, and unemployment.
It is a spiral that fuels recession and is destroying the economy and society.

No one denies the need for rigorous budgetary discipline, profound restructurings, and greater economic governance. But these are necessary conditions that, in the short term, are no longer sufficient to counter the ongoing deterioration within the Union.

And if it is true that policies aimed at employment and growth are necessary, without which we will never manage to control sovereign debt, the central question today is to ensure the financing of our companies and our economies, without which the Union will falter.
Therefore, more than ever, more than the revision of treaties, we need today a strong and secure intervention from the European Central Bank.
Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. We are all here today united around a resolution with a set of very important requests in terms of intervention.
We are speaking on World AIDS Day, and this evaluation of the 2009 resolution and communication is essential.
It is fundamental to reiterate precisely things that have already been mentioned.
We repeat because, unfortunately, there is still room for repetition, which means there is much to do.
There are many new cases diagnosed every year in Europe and the European economic area. A 2010 report mentions over 25,000 new cases.
If we consider neighboring countries, we are talking about over one hundred thousand new cases.
And if we think there are things that cannot get worse, they can always get worse.

One of the points I want to make very clear here concerns the disinvestment that has been occurring in the healthcare sector as a result of the economic and financial crisis we are currently experiencing.
and this disinvestment has seriously affected domains that are fundamental to the fight against HIV/AIDS.
That is why, Mr. Commissioner, I believe that here the Commission has a fundamental role to play in requesting that Member States fulfill their obligations in these areas.

A second issue also relates to the increase in discrimination, evidenced by the economic and social crisis, discrimination against workers who have lost their jobs because of being identified as importers of this virus.
And that is why prevention, treatment, and care should be equal for all, regardless of sex, age, or the region where they live.
and I hope that we can implement these measures with the support of the Commissioner. Thank you very much.
Welcome to this Parliament, Mr. Draghi.
We are living through special and dramatic circumstances, and they require determined and urgent measures.

The spiral between state debt and bank debt must be broken, but at this moment the priority is to defend the states, to ensure that the countries of the euro zone and the euro itself are not destroyed by rating agencies and speculators.
In the report we will approve, Tremosa and Vassal propose rethinking the architecture of the Eurozone, creating Eurobonds, and a European Treasury, but all of this takes time.
At this moment, we are discussing an emergency, and in that context, the only solution rests with the European Central Bank.
Technically, the European Central Bank knows what needs to be done.
Today, do not allow your intervention or your actions to be inhibited by limited interpretations of your mandate.
Your mandate is to safeguard the euro, not to deal with inflation.
At a moment like this, there is no room for doubt. Saving the euro and doing what is necessary is what this Parliament and citizens expect from the European Central Bank.
Good luck and courage, Mr. Draghi.
The European neighbourhood policy already explicitly outlined the positions the European Parliament has been adopting.

It was with great satisfaction, therefore, that we observed a significant portion of the principles and proposals that we have been defending in this House incorporated into subsequent communications from the Commission and the Council.

I am, incidentally, grateful for the excellent and ongoing collaboration and coordination that we maintained throughout this time with Vice-President Cathy Ashton and Commissioner Stefan Füle and their respective cabinets.
From the outset by the upgrade achieved in our relationship with neighboring peoples.

By prioritizing relationships with the general population and with civil society organizations in particular, we will be giving greater objectivity and greater effectiveness to our neighborhood policy, which is intended to be exclusively founded on the universal values that we defend and that we share.
I emphasize, however, that the European Union does not intend to impose a model or a pre-defined formula for political reforms in third countries.
But when the matter at hand concerns the money of our taxpayers, we should give more to those who are doing more in aligning themselves with the values we believe in.
This principle means that the faster a country progresses in its internal reforms, the more support it will receive from the European Union.
The principle of more for more, therefore, is correct, fair, and coherent.
What this obviously implies is that we also anticipate the possibility of cases or countries where we will have less for less.
The neighborhood policy now rests on the defense of the pursuit of common values and a commitment to democracy, human rights, the rule of law, and good governance.
But this search implies greater accountability.

Our partners are called upon to assume greater responsibility in the process. Therefore, we advocate for the principles of maximum differentiation, maximum conditionality, and the familiar “more for more.”

By adopting an approach of engagement with our partners from the ground up and crafting bespoke policies—what we term a bottom-up approach and tailor-made policies—we enhance development effectiveness and institutional capacity.

institutional building that we so want to defend and which lies at the foundation of the rule of law and the democratic process, which we want to see implemented as rapidly as possible in the societies, economies, and communities of our neighboring countries.

The idea is to give the floor to citizens, as well as to all civil society movements that identify with our values, providing support to organized movements striving for positive and democratic changes in their countries.
countries, improving the rights of women and children, building and deepening the principles of freedom, whether of expression, of association, of religious belief, of the press, of choice, etc.
etc., with fair elections, with the fight against corruption, a rule of law, greater social justice, respect for minorities, environmental protection, and efficient resource management.
The serious economic and social problems facing our neighbors must also be the target of immediate action.
It is evident that, without our concrete assistance, the democratic processes underway may fail.
These were the ideas that we have always defended for the future European Neighbourhood Policy.
These are the proposals contained in the report that we bring to your vote.
Now is the time to act.
From our side, we will continue to be vigilant and to exercise the new monitoring and supervisory powers now vested in the European Parliament.

To conclude, I would like to thank my colleague, collaborator, and friend, Marek Sivic, to whom I offer a very special word of recognition for his remarkable work on the eastern dimension of the neighborhood policy.
to the Shadow and Opinion rapporteurs, and to all of you, for the immense suggestions proposed in the amendments you presented, which I believe have enriched our work.
A final word to the Commission Secretariat and to the political advisors for the excellent support I benefited from.
European neighborhood policy excluding the outermost regions as active borders of Europe in different parts of the world.
As external borders, the outermost regions transmit our values of democracy, peace, and respect for human rights and fundamental rights to third countries in those regions.
Regions like the French ultraperipheral ones have an absolute need for greater integration within their geographical zones.

distant from the internal market of the Union, this insertion is fundamental for its development and constitutes a significant potential for deepening the neighbourhood policy with third-country neighbours.

The neighborhood policy requires a renewed impetus, an impetus that also leverages the privileged historical-cultural relationships that the outermost regions of the Azores, Madeira, and the Canary Islands maintain with North America and South America.
A more active role in favor of the European Union can and should be played by these regions within the framework of a new European Neighborhood Policy.

Thank you, Mr. President. It was last September that a year passed since, after a thorough debate in which I also participated as the person responsible for this area within the Socialist Group, organizing meetings and discussions with European, national, and regional organizations linked to…

To retailers, industrialists, and farmers, the Parliament approved the Bouvé report, containing an exhaustive set of recommendations to the European Commission with the objective of fair income for farmers and improved functioning of the food supply chain.

Since 2008, indeed, the Commission and the Parliament have been producing communications, reports, and recommendations, and establishing high-level forums and groups to address this serious problem, without anything having changed in practice beyond a greater awareness.

Let us return to the matter, and it must be stated without hesitation. A significant portion of the problems that farmers face stem from highly penalizing behaviors imposed, primarily, by operators of modern distribution.
The problems have been more than identified.
What has been lacking for the Commission and the Member States is a genuine political will to implement the solutions.
Until then, we will continue to bear the losses of both farmers and consumers.
to say that this treaty is useless.
Unfortunately, he is, above all, dangerous.
First, because it reinforces with further penalties and rigid rules a formula that does not work.
The recessive spiral is cast.
Who can trust a doctor who cannot distinguish between weight loss and anorexia?
A physician who, the more the patient weakens, the more insists on the remedy, while openly discussing the probability of their death.
How many more countries must enter a recession for the Commission and the Council to realize that the diagnosis is incorrect?
But it is also dangerous, because we here represent the citizens of Europe.
23 million 700 thousand are unemployed.
Nearly six million young people have no hope of finding employment.
Will the Council and the Commission fail to understand that ignoring this fact, and failing to provide an adequate response, reveals an autism and an insensitivity that are politically explosive?
Let us be clear.
The Great Recession is not a fatality; it is an ideological obsession.
There is an alternative agenda. It must be, however, not of words, but of action.
Where are the Project Bonds to finance European investment?
Where is the reinforcement of the European budget with the tax on speculative financial products?
Where is the barrier that should protect countries from the ruinous interest rates imposed upon them by the markets, leading them to ruin?
Citizens demand options, not words, but competent options. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Madam President. The Commission and the governments now pledge to reprogram structural funds to support SMEs and create employment.

However, it is worthwhile to recall that, at the end of last year, the Commission also decided on the suspension of the allocation of structural funds to countries that did not meet or had not met the deficit or debt targets.
It does not require great genius to realize that either the promise succeeds or the punishment succeeds, but the two cannot occur simultaneously.

And that is why, Mr. Commissioner, that I want to ask you a very direct question. Does the decision to suspend the allocation of structural funds remain in place, has it been frozen, or has it been annulled?

In other words, Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and other countries may still draw on funds to which they are entitled if they fail to meet the objectives being imposed by the Commission and by yourselves?
Answer, Commissioner, please. It's that in Portugal we are very tired of promises, you see?
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. The proposal made by President Barroso to redirect available structural funds to support our SMEs
and to stimulate employment, especially youth employment, could not be more welcome, particularly for economies subjected to stringent austerity measures, such as the Portuguese economy.

With the external intervention agreement and the significant difficulties in financing the economy, and in particular, our small and medium-sized enterprises through the banking system, this proposal takes on special importance for regions such as the Azores, which, despite high absorption and good utilization of funds, are situated within a recessive context.

Here, you can attain a real possibility of stimulating your economy through small and medium-sized enterprises and the indispensable contribution of our generation of young people – the best prepared ever – in providing the optimal response to growth and employment with these funds…
Three options.
What we need to know, Mr. Commissioner, is how, in practice, we will access these funds and how our regions will participate in their reprogramming.

Mr. President, Commissioner, the milk package presented here as an instrument for organizing the sector contains positive and important elements such as the reinforcement of the role of producers' organizations and interprofessional organizations, and contractual aspects that, with the formers, may leave us…

However, it falls considerably short of the instruments the sector needs to thrive in the coming years, within a framework of agriculture that we want to see in Europe have access to a fair distribution of value within the food chain, and that does not transform into an agriculture of large, intensive holdings concentrated in a few Member States.

If improving the condition of self-regulation in the relationship between sector actors is desirable, already thinking that this alone is sufficient is to commit a serious error that could distance thousands of dairy producers, dozens of regions, and even entire countries from dairy activity.
The debate regarding the regulation of the dairy sector from the perspective of an economically, socially, environmentally, and territorially sustainable sector remains, therefore, still to be had.
and we cannot abandon the milk quota system without ensuring genuine instruments for managing supply.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. Since May 2010 until today, we have observed how a problem that seemed manageable has escalated uncontrollably.

It is true that the fight against the crisis opened by the financial markets has worsened the indebtedness of the countries of the euro zone and that the most vulnerable have become particularly susceptible.

However, could it be possible that countries sharing the same currency are left to the whims of attacks from financial operators and those who profit from betting on the probability of euro countries entering bankruptcy?
The terrible consequences of the Commission's failure to respond have generated problems that are now undeniable.
Speculative interest rates levied on individual countries have rendered any strategy for exiting the crisis untenable.
The resulting worsening of the country’s economic problem justifies further interest rate hikes until the total curtailment of credit kills a country’s economy and contagion does the rest.
This Parliament has long advocated for a common form of sovereign debt management, subject to stringent but clear rules.
We welcome the Commission's production of a green paper on the subject, what has been termed…

Today it is clear that without some form of obligation of this type, properly articulated with the European stabilization mechanism, so-called protection barriers, those firewalls for sovereign debt, do not exist. And until they exist, the euro is in danger, and so is Europe.

In the resolution overwhelmingly approved by this Parliament regarding the new Treaty, it became absolutely clear that it is not permissible to continue imposing further rules on fiscal stability, budgetary discipline, and sanctions on euro area countries without taking concrete and urgent steps in the joint management of sovereign debt.
The two processes will need to evolve in parallel.
That is what we expect from the Commission, and it is too late now.

I would like to believe that this House of European Democracy will unanimously repudiate the behavior of President Assad and the Syrian authorities in the assassination of their own people, which we, powerless, witness daily.
It is important that Europe can speak with a single voice regarding the meaning of respect for human life in the face of an indiscriminate and globally orchestrated massacre.
The entire international community must maintain pressure on the Syrian regime through the implementation of new restrictive measures.
The killings must stop, and that is non-negotiable.
Insisting on dialogue, without a doubt.

A democratic Syria requires a period of transition and guarantees for all its minorities. However, the implementation of more restrictive measures against the Syrian regime cannot be sustained if all countries do not row in the same direction. And this has not, clearly and unfortunately, been happening.
Beyond thousands of deaths and its resolutions shamefully rejected in the United Nations Security Council,
We continue to condemn the position of China and Russia, increasingly isolated in relation to their incredible support for the Syrian regime.
Everything else remains. A power regime, desperate and cornered, continues to govern a country, and we, the international community, remain powerless to halt the genocide of a people.
We are already significantly behind in the hardening of action by the European Union and the international community.
We must provide more concrete support to the Arab League in its interventions and in its intentions to send a peacekeeping force to Syria.
We must wholeheartedly support the work of the Red Cross in its efforts to minimize the suffering of populations.
The International Criminal Court must immediately initiate proceedings with a view to prosecuting those responsible for the crimes being perpetrated against humanity.

and as a means of pressure on countries that have maintained support for Assad, also prohibit trade exchanges between the European Union and all Russian or Chinese companies that have commercial relations.
and commissioner yesterday.
Thank you, Mr. President. Welcome, Commissioner, to discuss this matter of such importance.
In fact, we are discussing central issues relating to data protection and, above all, in a context where there may be conflict between two different jurisdictions.

And the protection of data is, in fact, one of the sensitive domains that has generated so much controversy and, in my view, should continue to generate. Because we are talking about what could be the clash between…

rights and guarantees, the safeguarding of European citizens who are protected by European legislation and subsequently find themselves superseded when the legislation of other countries takes precedence over European legislation.
It is sensitive for several reasons.
It is sensitive because there is a rupture and a doubt regarding what is, for all intents and purposes, a contract that exists between European citizens and European institutions.

These individuals, when they provide their personal data, do so under the understanding that it will be protected by European entities and institutions and that it will not be distributed for other purposes.

Therefore, there is a breach of trust here, and this is a complex factor to manage. Furthermore, it is a serious and precarious situation because the European Union ultimately transfers personal data to third countries, thereby breaking this seal of trust that is generated.

between European citizens and European institutions. And therefore, if citizens accept that European institutions can be guardians of their personal data in so many different domains, from health issues, to other issues as were mentioned concerning companies.

which require data, and I am speaking specifically, for example, in the case of the United States, which systematically requests data from the European Union, which is what we are doing when citizens operate under the assumption that they are consenting, and, as I said, in order for the European Union to be the guardian of their data, it constitutes a breach of trust.
Therefore, I also want to say to you, Madam Commissioner, that these issues have often been problematic, for different reasons, but I will always stand on the side of the demonstrations of citizens.

We wish to safeguard the protection of your personal data. And if there are demonstrations that you understand are happening because European institutions are not complying with it, I believe we should stand alongside citizens and not on the opposite side.

It is almost a form of betrayal that takes place. And that is why the question we pose to you, the issues we raise, Madam Commissioner, are so that you may clarify, once and for all, because no community is built upon or with the foundation of destruction.

a weakening of the bonds of trust that exist between its citizens and its institutions. And in this sense, Madam Commissioner, please answer us: to what extent can we guarantee that European legislation prevails over the legislation of third countries?
Because it is certain that European legislation supersedes the legislation of the 27 Member States of the European Union, and this is what citizens relinquish.

Within this space of sovereignty, at many moments, why should we accept that other countries, such as the United States, subsequently override European legislation that overrides national legislation?
It is necessary that this be clarified because it is, in fact, very sensitive, serious, and a matter we should consider.

And finally, Commissioner, I would like to ask you, please, to tell us what the Commission is doing to ensure this does not happen again, to prevent it from recurring, and to protect the personal data of all citizens and of all citizens.

The data from companies and various sectors referenced in these matters are, in fact, data that people can trust, protected by what we safeguard. And by this, I mean that I do not even share the view that all information that is stored should be stored, but that is another debate.

Regarding this matter, as it is a serious issue and a pivotal one concerning the rights of citizens, I would appreciate it if you could provide those clarifications so that we may all feel more reassured. Thank you very much.

Mr. President, I would essentially like to say that from the next Council, we expect a significant decision at the economic level for the countries under assistance, closely linked to the issue of structural funds.
It is necessary to make the structural funds more flexible.
Many remain unused, a significant portion of them having been used only and solely for large-scale infrastructure projects.
They must be oriented towards competitiveness, towards small and medium-sized enterprises, and towards the relaunch of the economy.
The only investment that countries like Greece, like Portugal, like Ireland, and like others can have is that which results, at this moment, from these structural funds.
He also left a political note for all politicians of the Union, those who are in good faith within the European process.
When discussing these topics, it is necessary to respect, to exercise great care with regard to national identities and Member States.
politicians, sometimes many of them with good intentions, but not all have been equal to the challenge of strict respect for the national identity of each Member State.
Thank you, Mr. President, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner. I greet the rapporteurs and the... But I would like to say that enough is enough with pious speeches about employment and growth.

Today, with the initial results regarding macroeconomic imbalances in Europe, the veil begins to lift on why, within the European Union and, in particular, the Eurozone, some countries prosper while others inevitably falter.
Europe is losing competitiveness in external markets, and this agenda must be revised because much of the insufficient internal growth hinges on it. But, focused on the internal market,
Four countries, among which Germany, accumulate surpluses successively year after year, while twenty other countries, I repeat, twenty, accumulate deficits also year after year.
As deficits accumulate, the external debt of these countries increases unsustainably.
Of course, this process must be controlled.
Of course, discipline is required.
But it is important to ask today, within this framework, is the solution of crushing the most vulnerable with recessionary policies the only possible solution?
Is fiscal competition by certain winners within the domestic market still being tolerated?

Could Europe’s largest economy continue to develop common policies that favor it and internal economic policies that, while certain for its economy, capture the majority of the domestic market's gains for its own benefit?
Could the Commission and the Council continue to impose recessionary policies that tighten the economy for the most vulnerable, discussing
openly raised the possibility of the bankruptcy of sovereign states within the Eurozone, when they know that these firebreaks never left the file of intentions?
Do the Commission and the Council fully appreciate the explosive political and economic risk this discourse poses to Europe?
Yes, it is necessary to revise the formulas in a radical way.
but for that to happen, there must be political will.
While that will does not exist, out of respect for the citizens, let us cease saying that we defend growth and employment, because it is not true.
and citizens cannot continue to be deceived.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I begin by greeting the rapporteurs.
To say that we are living through the most severe financial, economic, and social crisis since the creation of our modern international financial model is now commonplace.
It is never excessive to emphasize that unemployment rates in the European Union have reached historic records, underscoring the need to make the fight against unemployment the highest priority.
Youth unemployment is dramatic. In my country, Portugal, more than one in three young people are seeking employment and have no prospects of finding it.
Our citizens are disillusioned.
It is urgent to restore trust.
After years of imprudent management of public finances, it is time to adopt budgetary consolidation reforms and to put public accounts in order.
But we do not lose our heads; austerity without economic growth is no more than a partial solution.
The creation of more jobs and better jobs is the great European objective.
Measures to ensure that young people do not go more than four months without receiving a job or training offer, as well as to reduce the risk of poverty and social exclusion, must become a reality.
A year ago, we witnessed the tragic combination of an earthquake, a tsunami, and a nuclear industrial accident, all in sequence.
Today, we pay a heartfelt tribute to the many thousands of victims of Fukushima.
To honor the victims is to tell them that we have learned the lesson; we must learn to deal with natural disasters, and with nuclear ones, we have the obligation to avoid them.
But, unfortunately, that does not appear to be the truth.
A year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be built.
A year after Fukushima, and new nuclear power plants continue to be planned.
Japan has, unfortunately, the memory of tragedies that endure: Hiroshima, Nagasaki, and we, Europeans, also have the memory of an enduring tragedy, Chernobyl.
Fukushima obliges us, for all of this, to reopen a debate that should never have been closed, the debate about nuclear energy.
A year ago, nuclear energy was unquestionable for the Japanese. Today, two-thirds of the Japanese do not want it.
They know it costs lives, they know that this cost is priceless. On the contrary, it is a cost that increases from generation to generation.
The stubborn policy favoring nuclear power is a policy of arrogance.
Here in Europe as well, there is a majority of public opinion against nuclear power, and despite this, nothing seems to change.
There are currently 320,000 refugees in Japan. Of these, 100,000 will never be able to return home.

What was once familiar is now perilous.
What was once comfort is now ruin.

It is the ruin of a building or a house with radioactive vegetation.
It is the ruin of contaminated soil or water.

And Fukushima cannot be visited as other ruins are, for example, a Mayan ruin or a Roman ruin. But, nonetheless, like these, Fukushima also portrays a civilization, and the ruin of Fukushima portrays our civilization.
that which chose to include in its development model a lethal technology.
An earthquake and a tsunami have no culprits, but a nuclear disaster has those responsible.
In Japan, as in Europe, many citizens decided to create farewell-to-nuclear movements.
They know better than anyone that safe nuclear energy is a nonexistent thing. They know better than anyone that there are no stress tests that…
We can simulate what happened in Fukushima. And that’s why we know that energy policies are national.
As has been mentioned, diabetes affects more than 30 million people in Europe.
And these are, indeed, figures from an epidemic.
And that is why I understand that a specific resolution regarding diabetes is also justified, especially since this is the first time this Parliament has addressed this topic.
It is the result of a collective effort and a work that does not negate the work done thus far on chronic diseases; on the contrary, it reinforces this capacity we have to intervene jointly.

We have approximately 325,000 annual deaths associated with diabetes, because we know that diabetes is the leading cause of, for example, heart attacks, blindness, amputations, and failure of vital organs.
And in light of this data, we have two options, in my opinion.
The first is to say that it's not so serious, that we can live well with this, and that each government deals with it.
The second is to say that the absence of a European strategy in this area is part of the problem.
I understand that, from this side, we have much to do.
and we have much to do in early diagnosis, in coordination, in investment in research.
And that is why this resolution holds the value of a beginning and of collaborative work in this regard. Thank you very much.
Thank you, Mr. President. What I primarily wanted to do was to congratulate you on the Council’s results.
not because the measures are ideal, but because they are the possible measures.
There is no doubt that today we have come much further and can be more optimistic than we were three months ago and six months ago.
Many States have been making a substantial effort to stabilize and consolidate their public finances, and this effort has been undertaken in only some States at the inducement of the European Union.
It is essential for them to regain their credibility in international markets and is essential for them to grow in the long term.
With the assurances that States have been providing, among which the Portuguese State stands out, in its commitment to fiscal consolidation and budgetary consolidation, I am…
convinced, also by the new treaty signed between the 25, that we will be in a position to seriously relaunch growth in the next steps of the European Council.
But it is only with this confidence, which is being generated little by little, that this growth must occur.
And therefore, I say, solidarity of the wealthiest with the poorest is important, but solidarity of the poorest with the wealthiest is also important, providing these guarantees.
Mr. President, I would basically like to say that we are greatly pleased to see that steps have been taken to integrate Serbia into the European Union.

This is very important because the experience of countries like Portugal, like Spain, or like Greece – countries that lived under dictatorships and faced a set of very serious problems – is the experience that European integration was the way to consolidate democracy.
And therefore, Serbia also deserves that opportunity.
I would, in any case, like to offer here a note somewhat different from those given by my colleagues.

I am aware and welcome the great concern for minorities, but it is necessary not to forget the Serbian majority. It is fundamental that the Serbs themselves have a place in the European Union and a place of full right.
This cannot be forgotten.

There will be no peace in the Balkans without Serbia. And therefore, however much we emphasize the rights of minorities—and they must be respected—we cannot forget the Serbian majority, its identity, and its full right to be European citizens, equal to all others, with its own state and national pride.
Thank you, Mr. President. Portugal voted on the treaty—better said, the budgetary ultimatum—which, indeed, is not a European treaty. It is good to mention this.

The favorable vote of the governing parties reflects the accumulation of decades and decades of stupidity and a typical attitude of the good student, a grade-chaser, who does not think and obeys bad teachers.
The position of the PS and its leader was to shift from a perilous, violent abstention to a searching vote in favor.

This alliance transforms our Assembly of the Republic, the Portuguese Parliament, into the first to accept the humiliation of amputating itself from one of its most important functions – being elected by the people to decide the country’s budget annually.
This is yet another blow from the European Union, another one. It is a maneuver in which the power of money becomes increasingly beyond the reach of the citizens' vote.
And I ask, Mr. President, is it democratic for someone to vote in order that they may no longer be able to vote? Thank you.
Fiscal consolidation is imposing virtually unbearable demands on some European citizens.
However, fewer and fewer are those who have to bear a greater burden.
The tax burden falls on workers, small and medium-sized enterprises, and consumers, while at the same time, we are witnessing completely disproportionate tax flight and evasion.

The Group of the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament wanted to know how much this tax evasion and avoidance was worth in the 27 countries and it amounts to one trillion euros, in English, one trillion euros.
This is more than the countries of the European Union spend on healthcare.

This signifies a volume so substantial that, were we to allocate merely one-fifth of this amount to investment, investment would rise in Europe from 2.7% of GDP to 3.5%. We are, therefore, discussing an exceptionally high figure.

The purpose of the resolution we are about to approve, initiated by this Parliament, is precisely a very clear demand to the Commission and the Council to expedite concrete action to combat tax evasion and fraud.

This means, in particular, concrete initiatives for fiscal cooperation within the European Union, for fiscal cooperation with our neighboring countries, particularly Switzerland, but negotiated by the Commission and not country by country on a bilateral basis.
This means reforming and harmonizing accounting rules, increasing transparency and reporting.
This clearly means reactivating the fundamental issue of combating fraud and tax evasion through tax havens.
Europe is not a minor partner.
Europe is a major partner in the international context.
Europe has an obligation, within the scope of the G20, to clearly advocate for a common fight against fraud and tax evasion.

Without this, we lose credibility with our citizens, and therefore, my final words in this debate are to encourage the Commission and the Council to initiate an effective fight against fraud and tax evasion. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating my colleague Nibler on the excellent work and noting the coincidence that on Europe Day, which we celebrate today, we are debating and tomorrow will approve measures that align with the legitimate aspirations of our citizens.

The purpose of this regulation is to impose limits on mobile phone tariffs charged to European consumers when roaming, with its primary objective being to end roaming within the European space starting in 2016.
Our citizens will now benefit from a significant decrease in prices for calls, SMS messages, and data.
Currently, there are operators charging 3 euros per megabyte, but starting in July, the maximum price they can charge will be 70 cents per megabyte, decreasing to 20 cents in 2014.
Regarding incoming calls, the maximum charge will be 8 cents this year and 5 cents in 2014.
In July 2012, a family with two mobile phone users will save, as the Commissioner stated, 200 euros on their bill.
Second benefit: enhanced information quality for consumers.
