From as early as the summer, operators will be obliged to inform consumers of the rates applied when they also travel outside the European Union.
Until now, the obligation has been solely within the European space.
A third advantage is the possibility of more operators entering the market, which means increased competition that will stimulate improved services and better prices.

Finally, in the near future, the consumer may, if they so desire, have two contracts, one for services within the national territory and another for services abroad, maintaining the same mobile phone number and receiving only one invoice.
The consumer, our citizen, will also be afforded the possibility of contracting with any European operator that offers them the best price.
This report is the perfect example of Europe of the citizens, Europe of free movement and free establishment. Thank you very much.
Madam President, in February 2009, this Parliament approved a report supporting the European Commission’s proposal to revitalize the European economy.

There were projects involving clean energy, transportation, new technologies, and innovation, and at that time, the role of the European Investment Bank and structural funds was already being mobilized.
More than three years later, we were able to produce the Six-Pack, the Europlus-Pact, the Fiscal Pact, and the Two-Pack, all replete with reinforced discipline and sanctions.

However, meanwhile, as unemployment, particularly among young people, reaches alarming levels, the European economy enters a recession and more than seven of its member states are experiencing negative growth.
And meanwhile, while Greece is no more than a first stone threatening to bring down the castle, the relaunch agenda seems to have been forgotten.
At this moment, that agenda is clear.
What matters at this moment is no longer assigning it a character of urgency, but a character of emergency in a situation that threatens to explode.
It is necessary to intervene urgently in a set of pillars.
First, it is necessary that the European Marshall Plan be established with investment promoting growth, employment, and convergence.
Project Bonds are one possible source.
Secondly, it is necessary to stabilize the interest rates at which countries finance themselves.
Let us, at the very least, prepare to coordinate sovereign debt issuance and manage the accumulated debt in common.
Thirdly, the European Stability Mechanism and the European Central Bank must prepare to function effectively as genuine firebreaks in the defense of European sovereign debt.
Fourthly, the credit that was massively transferred by the European Central Bank to commercial banks must reach businesses.
It is a billion euros that remains trapped within the banking system, while thousands of viable businesses die every day due to lack of funding.
Fifth point, investment makes no sense without demand.
The most vulnerable economies are crushed by austerity plans.
It is the strongest economies that must free up domestic demand.

It is that nearly 80% of transactions today take place within Europe. And it falls to the Commission, Mr. Commissioner Olli Rehn, to make recommendations directed not only to the most fragile economies, but also to the most dynamic ones.
And finally, I conclude, Mr. President, it is necessary to place a limit on the prescriptions imposed by the troika.

It is necessary to say enough to the punitive style, without dialogue and without accountability, with which senior officials determine the fate of millions of European citizens and the democratic institutions of member states. Thank you very much, Mr. President.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Commissioners. What I wanted to say is very clear. Naturally, the Portuguese deputies of the EPP fully support all measures that may contribute to growth. There is no possibility of…

If we exit this crisis without promoting growth, particularly in those states most affected by the financial crisis. But, sometimes, when I hear some colleagues here, I get the feeling that they think growth can continue with excessive deficits and more public debt.

Now, we must continue to insist on reducing expenditure and implementing structural reforms. We can do everything on the growth side, but we cannot abandon the path of restraint and reduction of public spending.

of structural reforms. More growth cannot be more lax, more rest. More growth and more growth policies must go hand in hand with great rigor in public accounts and with great rigor in structural reforms.
If we only start talking about growth and thinking that there are magical growth solutions, we will end up once again with unsustainable public debt and we will continue without structural reforms.

Having said that, I would like to draw attention to the fact that, at this morning’s Summit, not only will the long-term or medium-term question of growth be at stake, but also the urgent question of Greece. And I believe it is fundamental that European states stand by Greece, in some way.
We are responsible for finding a solution to the Greek problem. And I wanted to repudiate here the statement by the British Member of Parliament who spoke of the Portugalization of Europe.
Portugalization of Europe, at least in the realm of values, need not be a negative thing. And therefore, I reject this idea of attempting, ultimately, to demean or to diminish any people.
We are all Europe and we all have a place in it.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, you came here to tell us that every additional euro spent on debt is one euro less for job creation. Then explain to us why we continue with this obsession.

He also came here to tell us that one of the priorities of the Summit is to keep Greece in the euro zone. And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, do we believe you, or do we believe Dr. Durão Barroso, or Mr. Trichet, who were saying exactly the opposite just a few days ago?
He spoke about the maintenance of the eurozone, I ask, in which euro?

in the euro we currently live in, in this zone we currently live in, or in the euro announced yesterday by Deutsche Bank in a study referring to a G euro, a second-tier euro, should the left win the June elections in Greece.
This is a trap, Mr. Commissioner, it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by governments and it is the trap of a Europe held hostage by financial interests.
Let us not allow people to live under fear, because it is not a way to live. Europe can be something else. You know, there is no lack of money, there is a lack of shame.

Mr. President, Mr. Vaman Minister, the first thing I wish to declare is that it is regrettable that, in a debate of this importance, the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative, Ms. Ashton, are not present.
In any case, we are pleased to work once again with Mr. Minister Vaman, who made a statement here with which I wholeheartedly concur.

I would like, first of all, to offer a word of comfort and solidarity to the people of Guinea, who have essentially been the people of Guinea-Bissau, a people systematically decimated by democratic instability, political instability, and pervasive insecurity.
It was no longer enough that he was surrounded by poverty; he has been systematically affected by these ills.

I wanted to say, on the other hand, that the PPE, during its presidency, has followed this issue from the beginning, and it is regrettable that the European Parliament only manages to hold a debate on this matter after a month.
This concerns the invisibility of the Bissau-Guinean people and the Bissau-Guinean question.

And this invisibility is solely due to the fact that, unlike other matters, even very serious ones, large-scale economic interests are not at stake here, interests that would motivate European, American, and global powers to debate the situation of the Guinean people.
But I must say, if an external reason is needed, if poverty and political instability are not sufficient for us to have a global humanitarian and political action, there is an external reason.
less than the situation of drug trafficking that plagues Guinea and directly affects both European and American peoples would be reason enough for us to commit ourselves to this.
And therefore, I ask the European Union to be stronger.

There is no doubt that Resolution 2048, there is no doubt that decisions from the European Union, the Community of Portuguese-Speaking Countries, the African Union, but perhaps not from the Economic Community of West African States, are moving in the right direction.
But resolutions are not enough; action is required.
We must be firmer, we must be more effective with the States that have the capacity to intervene in Guinea-Bissau.
That is our responsibility.

And I believe that the European Union, at this moment, is responding well in terms of principles, but is not responding as it should in terms of practical instruments, of operations on the ground, and that is what I am asking of the Council and asking of the Commission.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, globalization has brought with it a disproportionate growth of the financial sector, whose transactions are today, as is well known, seventy times greater than global wealth.

Opacity, extremely frequent transactions, high remuneration, and exceedingly high risk ultimately came not only to characterize the world in which we live today, but also to be fundamental reasons for the crisis we are experiencing.
However, this crisis demanded accountability and required far greater efforts from ordinary citizens than from the sector that had caused it.
Thus, today, this moment is important.

It is important, and I would personally like to achieve a situation in which the tax were generalized across all countries of the European Union and, subsequently, extended to the rest of the world through active participation by the Commission and the European Union as a whole within the context of the G20.
I would like it to cover all products without exceptions.
I would like it to serve as a basis for the necessary strengthening of the European Union’s own resources.
In the short term, commitments must be accepted, but one must not lose sight of the direction in which we need to proceed.
and that can only be achieved with a clear identification of these objectives by this Parliament, by the Commission, and with a strong spirit of compromise also by the Council.

This is what European citizens expect from us today, and I can only, here today, thank the role not only of Ani Podimata, who was tireless in this process, but of all those who managed to overcome the divergences to reach a common position.

Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, colleague Podimata. Today, we are discussing here for the first time the tax on financial transactions, and its approval is the first sign that speculation will not go entirely unpunished in this crisis in which we are living.
This House and the European institutions must be accountable to people, not to financial markets.
For decades, the financial markets' lobbies have managed to govern the world without opposition and without any issue.
It was obvious to us that during 2008 and 2012 the crisis of the speculative financial market was at the root of most of the problems we experienced.
And yet, these speculative financial markets managed not only to prevent any action from being taken, but also to ensure a direct transfer from the pockets of citizens to these very markets.

For many years we have been fighting for this, Mr. President, but it was only when the peoples, across Europe, began to say enough that there was finally some initiative from the institutions that govern the European Union.
And therefore, that is the answer we must give to citizens. It is a first sign we must give.
The citizens of Europe, who have paid for everything, do not deserve to be treated with disrespect.
And therefore, this proposal is not complete, it is not perfect, and it will not solve the entire problem of financial speculation, but it is an important signal.
We have been walking, we haven't, European leaders have been apologizing to financial markets.
should apologize to the people they have affected.
And, quoting, to conclude, Mr. President, a currently famous politician, is speaking of these markets, these markets that govern us without ever having been elected.

I sincerely hope that governments will give a signal of confidence to the people and I sincerely hope that, with this approval and with the positive vote of my colleagues, we begin to speak of justice and solidarity in Europe.
Colleagues, muster your courage; let’s get this project approved.
Thank you, Mr. President. The financial transactions tax should function as a means of controlling and discouraging high-risk speculative activities within the financial sector.
It aims to reduce speculation and broaden healthy competition, the foundation of the single market, and also to generate revenue.
The Podimata report sought to align the initial Commission proposal with the well-known UK Stamp Tax. This made the proposal more appealing to reluctant Member States.
It is expected that the Council will also understand the message.

If in the Commission’s proposal the tax applied to transactions of financial institutions located within the territory of the European Union, the current intention is to also tax transactions of European assets, even when conducted by non-Europeans.
This measure will broaden the tax base and reduce tax evasion.
It is expected that tax revenues will be considered as a source of own resources for the Union or the Member States, reducing the taxes of the Member States—a matter still to be decided.
Concluding, Mr. President, I commend the rapporteur for the quality of her work, and I hope this symbolic text...
Thank you, Madam President. We received another request this weekend to save the private banking sector.

They continue to offer the same argument, which is to avoid contagion to the Eurozone. And what I ask is whether we have learned nothing. Greece, Portugal, Ireland, and now Spain, and yet, the contagion persists.
But what root of contagion control is this that is destroying us?

This policy doesn't work; we should already know that. It's the same governing officials who say there's no money for culture, education, healthcare, public goods, yet when banks request it from the markets, it suddenly appears, almost miraculously.
This economic policy is not a remedy; it is a fatal poison for growth, for employment, for the European economy, for social Europe.
The markets dictate, and governments obey and blackmail the people. And that is what governments are doing to Greece at this moment, during an election period.

I sincerely hope, and it is well for us all, that the Greek people will not be blackmailed next Sunday and that they will give us a lesson, because this formula, Madam President, is a recipe for disaster. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. Dear colleagues, unfortunately, the proposals we have discussed here today confirm the prohibition of anti-crisis policies within the Eurozone and further solidify the logic of the Fiscal Treaty.

There are some statements of intent, but they are very timid. I refer, for example, to the roadmap for a day when one might begin to consider ways of defining possible legislation for the hypothetical introduction of eurobonds.
The problem is that this day is only when all the problems of the Eurozone are resolved, and it is far off, very far off indeed.
We support certain aspects of this proposal, but at this rate, it will be too little and too late.
Placing a country under legal protection implies maintaining rates and amounts, as well as prioritizing new loans. That is to say, it is required of...
Member states that honour their debt are deprived of all and every instrument that might enable them to grow and find the resources to do so.

Let’s be frank with one another. The only legal protection that exists in these proposals and is stipulated is for creators, but even they will not be resolved, because it is not effective even for them.

As we have seen in Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and now Spain, this means condemning countries to recession, unemployment, and insolvency. And I conclude, Mr. President, by saying that the worsening of these situations and their spread to other economies brings us closer to a point of no return.

Faced with the complete failure of austerity, the European Commission or the German Government propose the same policy to us, but in an overdose regime. It is neoliberal fanaticism that is killing the euro.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Given the extremely limited time conditions we have, I wish to say to the Commission at this moment alone that you can count on—as you have always counted on—this…
Parliament in effective work promoting the solidity of the Eurozone and of Europe, but that only is achieved when initiatives concentrate on discipline.

We have managed to add the conditions for a balanced sharing of gains and sacrifices between the different Member States and between the different citizens, and a hope, a hope that we will emerge from the crisis we are experiencing.
For this hope to exist, other initiatives are necessary, and these are what this Parliament is attempting to address—an initiative focused on investment, growth, and control.
of sovereign debt that has been the Achilles' heel of those evident that reflects the fragility of the economic systems of some of the member countries.
Mr. Commissioner, you can count on us, Council, Madam President, you can count on us, but the agenda must be a comprehensive agenda; it cannot be an agenda that simply does.
of the discipline or the condition for everything else to follow, nor does it make discipline the alpha and omega of our European proposals.

Our citizens expect this from us, they can count on the Parliament, and I want to thank my colleagues once again, the rapporteurs, Mr. Gozés, who is the other rapporteur, and all colleagues who, as shadow rapporteurs or merely active elements in the construction of this project, were able to contribute.

for a more balanced, more solid project from Parliament, and one that I hope will merit the respect, the capacity for dialogue, and the spirit of construction and compromise that it has possessed until now.
Thank you. Thank you, Mr. President. Thank you, Madam President. Thank you, Commissioner.

Thank you very much, Madam President. Beyond expressing my gratitude to everyone who contributed to this outcome, I would like to request that the final vote be postponed so that we can immediately negotiate at the working level.
We are confronted today with three agendas: the growth agenda, the agenda concerning bank management, and the agenda concerning sovereign debt management.
And treating the European Semester involves including these three dimensions.
Regarding the issue of growth, I believe that at this moment it is important to emphasize that the Commission’s recommendations cannot focus solely on…
Countries with deficits. They must also focus on the countries that have surpluses. And if some must curb their internal demand, others must release it.

I also believe that, at the level of growth, it is essential that the Commission controls the recommendations of the so-called Troika, because when a country enters a recession, it cannot continue to crush its public investment, to crush public expenditure, as if nothing had happened.
The troikas must have their formula reviewed and adjusted according to the results. And I want to tell you, Mr. Commissioner, that we today approved it here in Parliament.
Parliament, the necessity of launching an instrument for growth and countercyclical activity of the order of 1% of the European Union’s GDP over 10 years.
A second fundamental dimension is that of what is now termed the Banking Union. We requested this in Parliament two years ago, in a report from June 2010. It remains unfulfilled to date.

A third dimension is the dimension of sovereign debt. Without it, there is no stability in Europe. And I want to say that today we approved here the Tupac, but we introduced into the Tupac, beyond austerity,

some other dimension that has been lacking, and it is the immediate establishment of a redemption fund, using German terminology, so that sovereign debt, which exceeds sixty percent, can be managed collectively.

This is legislative text, and we anticipate the Commission’s positive support for this initiative from Parliament, so that we may control the entirely threatening spiral that is currently destroying the European Union. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues. As we now intend to discuss a growth pact, it is essential not to forget citizenship and consumers, fundamentally, the human and social dimension.

that gives it substance and which was the subject of one of the three reports on the Single Market Act of 2001. Because any growth pact should take into account the sacrifices and social benefits associated with it.

As important as an internal market test will be to conduct a social impact assessment of all measures taken to realize the single market. A test, yes, an examination that allows us to measure the progress achieved for the benefit of the citizens of the European Union.
Since 2008, Europe has already lost over 6 million jobs.
In my country, Portugal, the economy is experiencing a contraction unprecedented in its scale, and unemployment among men, women, and young people has reached historic highs.
According to forecasts from the Bank of Portugal, the situation will worsen over the next two years.
It is within this context that we support and welcome the initiative of the new employment package and congratulate Commissioner Andor.
Insisting now and always on the basic premise of the need for economic growth, Member States will truly have to concentrate their efforts on job creation.

The means to achieve this should involve subsidies for hiring that create new jobs, a reduction in the tax burden on labor, and support for the creation of new businesses and entrepreneurship, but also for small and medium-sized enterprises that maintain existing jobs.
National employment policies must take into account that the areas with the greatest potential for job creation are healthcare, information and communication technologies, and the green economy.
It is imperative, as stated in the communication, to reduce the gap between the qualifications provided by education and the competencies demanded by the labor market.
On the other hand, one of the solutions to combating unemployment involves worker mobility.

It is also crucial that the utilization of structural funds for job creation and the practical importance of the Euros portal as an instrument, par excellence, for recruitment and job offers in Europe are considered.
Finally, social governance must be on the agenda because our citizens are anxiously awaiting concrete results. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner. It is true that six months have passed since this scandal involving GDP occurred, and the most unbelievable thing is that a private company could have managed to…
to operate in the market and have introduced silicone implants that were intended for the construction and manufacture of mattresses and were used in women in 71 countries.
This has affected several hundred thousand women, as previously mentioned, with estimates suggesting approximately 500,000.

Now, we are discussing estimates because there were failures and serious failures in this process. We know that what happened with this company is a criminal case, it is fraud, it is a court case, but we also know…

There is a fraud here that must be controlled by the courts, and the courts will deal with it. But there is a legal failing, a legal gap, and that is what we must address. We have responsibilities in this matter.

For 10 years, we were unable to identify what the criminals managed to identify. And therefore, there was a void in terms of control, in terms of traceability, in terms of the files, in terms of the records. Everything failed. But these gentlemen at this company managed to put into practice what we were unable to control.

This process is not merely a matter of a lack of information, which is, in fact, very important—the lack of information in all matters concerning breast implants—but also the humiliation of thousands of women and, in particular, the humiliation of those women who have had to undergo testing to determine whether or not they received appropriate implants.

We are discussing a matter of public health, and we cannot be lax when it comes to public health. We regulate so many unnecessary things; we even regulate the authenticity of replacement parts in automobiles, and just recently we approved a directive on that very subject.

We must control what is fundamental to people's lives. The revision of the Medical Devices Directive is good news. It was the best news that we wouldn't have to do it. But now, since we are going to do it, let us apply it with…

conditions, with traceability, transparency, control, sanctions, because, unfortunately, the sanctions, even if applied, will not be applied to women who have suffered from this problem and States must assume full responsibility.
Mr. President, I wanted to state very clearly here that for us, the Council to be held at the end of June is fundamental, and that what is essential is to seek a European solution to this crisis.
From our perspective, the problem thus far has been that we have been addressing each of the issues as they arise in isolation and individually.

The time has come for us to have a global solution for Europe, a solution that passes, as President Dole very clearly indicated, through greater integration, greater cooperation, a closer alignment of European policies, and a renewed appreciation for the Community method.
It is fundamental that alongside stability there be growth, but that we do not abandon concerns regarding stability.
We therefore count on a global European response and not on a divided response for each State or for each region experiencing difficulties.

Productive questions and increased production possibilities have caused considerable increases in milk production, creating critical situations, surpluses, and low prices in the milk and dairy market.

In many regions with strong productive potential, these surpluses were sold at bargain prices in the markets of other countries, resulting in even greater downward pressure on the prices paid to producers in those countries.

This happened, for example, with French milk sold in France at twice the price it was sold in Galicia. And producers, with the significant rise in the cost of raw materials and factors of production, have today seen their capacity to withstand low prices drastically reduced.

This is a poor prognosis for many explorations and many productive territories in Europe and appears to be also a clear indication of what the future may hold without quotas and without appropriate supply regulation instruments.

It therefore demands that a detailed audit be conducted on the territorial impacts of thousands of explorations throughout the European Union of the abolition of these instruments that we currently have to regulate supply.
Thank you, Mr. President. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur colleague on this report.
This is a matter of extreme importance to Europe.

At a time when we are living through a severe economic, financial, and social crisis, protecting intellectual property rights, by combating counterfeit products, is fundamental to the European economy.
This protection should enhance research performance and promote innovation. It should safeguard scientific and technological knowledge, contributing to the development of new products and services.
All of this with the aim of generating growth and creating quality jobs.

Unfortunately, in recent years, we have witnessed a significant increase in the violation of intellectual property rights in Europe, which represent annual losses, as previously mentioned here, of €250 billion for companies and the destruction of 185,000 jobs within the European space.

However, beyond these negative effects on the European economy, the violation of these rights also constitutes a serious threat to the health and safety of European consumers, since many counterfeit products, such as food, cosmetics, medicines, etc.,
etc., are produced in unregulated environments.
Therefore, the customs authorities of the European Union play a crucial role in preventing counterfeit products from entering the internal market.
With the revision of this regulation, the aim is to strengthen the control of the application of the legislation in question, reinforce the legitimacy of its intervention, increase the...
legal clarity, adapting the provisions of the Regulation to new realities and new developments, thereby contributing to better protection of the European economy and consumers.
Intellectual property rights are, therefore, a crucial priority for achieving the objectives of the 2020 Strategy in terms of attaining smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Indeed, the election of the new Egyptian President in the post-Mubarak era is good news. But we cannot deceive ourselves, and these presidential elections do not in any way close the transition process that is underway in Egypt.

It has been rightly pointed out that the dissolution of Parliament days before the presidential elections places several risks on the table. And, in this case, the power that is concentrated in the Superior Council of...

The Armed Forces was a considerable exaggeration. They possess legislative power, diminished the President’s authority, and furthermore, they still hold the power to define changes to the Constitution.

Now, all of this raises some concerns for us and should raise some concerns, because Egyptians risk being held hostage by military power and a return to the past, lacking a fundamental element: a democratically elected Parliament.
It is not for us to make the change in Egypt; it is for the Egyptians.
but I think we, Europeans, will have to stand by all changes that propose the restoration of what constitutes democratic legitimacy and a democratically elected Parliament. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Madam President, dear colleagues, Commissioner. I begin by congratulating the rapporteur, Lara Come, for the excellent work developed in this report, which is of vital importance for the future of Europe.
In a world and society undergoing rapid transformation, Europe needs a comprehensive, integrative, effective, and up-to-date standardization system.
A system that ensures the proper functioning of the internal market, that improves consumer protection and their lives, but also that protects the environment, is essential.

as innovation and social inclusion are also very important, as is the interaction and communication of networks and systems, particularly in the domain, as has already been emphasized here, of new information and communication technologies.
As Professor Monti noted in his report, a new strategy for the single market—European standardization—is essential for the governance of the internal market, as emphasized.
the necessity of revising the European standardization process, which maintains the advantages of the current system and finds the fair balance between the European and national dimensions.

In this sense, the report we are now discussing follows and defends these objectives, which are the correct and appropriate ones. To eliminate the slowness and fragmentation that exist and that cause companies to incur costs.

to transaction costs and higher unit costs, to strengthen the participation of SMEs in standardization activities, particularly at the national level, as well as to facilitate their access to those standards, also to strengthen

On the other hand, the participation of parties representing the interests of society, such as consumers, environmentalists, workers, and people with disabilities, should be ensured, while maintaining financial support for European organizations created to represent public interests.

I conclude by stating that the approval of this report will contribute to the relaunch of the European project, to European innovation, and to the strengthening and competitiveness of our companies. Thank you very much.
Thank you very much, Mr. President, Madam Commissioner. The future common fisheries policy must prioritize its environmental, economic, and social sectors.
In a synergistic and non-hierarchical manner, in pursuit of sustainable development and in line with the objectives of intelligent, sustainable, and inclusive growth of the EU 2020 Strategy.
As rapporteur for the REGI opinion, I would like to highlight the particularity of certain regions, such as the outermost regions, whose economies are strongly dependent on the sector...

In these regions, the reform of the common fisheries policy should seek to ensure the survival and future prosperity of their artisanal and small-scale fishing fleets, thereby safeguarding and defending the employment that depends on them.

I concur with the European Commission's position regarding the need for an adjustment of this policy and specific measures that should take into account the disparate realities of the fisheries and aquaculture sector in various coastal regions.

I argue that this policy should prioritize regionalization as a form of governance, through enhanced engagement of various stakeholders, to enable a more suitable response in the future to the demands and sensitivities of each maritime basin.
We are approaching the decisive moments in which we will shape the new fisheries policy in Europe and we cannot fail.

The need and urgency of achieving sustainable re-equilibriums in our solar resources, but also in the revitalization of our coastal fishing communities and the promotion of their socioeconomic level, in the modernization of the sector, and in the provision of quality food, demand, as never before, boldness and courageous measures.
Therefore, we must make choices and prioritize objectives.

I proposed protection for the fragility of my region, suggesting that the exploitation of its resources be undertaken considering scientific data and giving priority to our coastal communities in their exploitation, while restricting external access beyond 100 nautical miles to existing fishing banks.
I proposed safeguarding the fishing capacity of our important fishing communities, rejecting proposals for transferable quotas.

I proposed that our communities have improved involvement in the management of their affairs, including fishing, through the creation of a regional advisory council specifically tailored for ultraperipheral regions. I hope that in this way, we can have a better future.

Considering what we know about the implementation of the third package, and given that part of this issue has already been discussed today, regarding the delay in transposing its directives, it appears that the latest information I have is that…

18 Member States were notified, likely this information is already outdated due to a lack of transposition. The question I pose is how you view the possibility of, in the legislation being prepared, notably the networks.
trans-European, if it includes a device, an incentive that conditions a conditionality for the submission of PCIs, projects of common interest.

condition compliance by Member States with obligations arising from the third package or, conversely, considers this to be an extravagant mechanism and that it should be left to the regular mechanisms of competition, Article 101.
and their substitutes, all intervention in this matter. Thank you very much.
of the Commission and the tolerance, the spirit of tolerance that has existed in that matter. But the question is whether, with legislation being prepared that may…
Do you introduce an additional and much stronger conditionality, do you consider that conditionality to be an abusive instrument, or do you think that conditionality would be acceptable?
I confess that I share much of the concern that was initially presented here, regarding the democratic legitimacy and democratic control related to this proposal from the European Union.

Banking Union and Banking Supervision, because an essential question remains to be clarified and resolved—a question that is the Parliament's role, the only institution elected democratically by citizens, directly.

But there is another concern that I also have, a fundamental concern, and it relates to the following. The instruments of monetary policy are controlled by the European Union. Monetary policy is the responsibility of the European Union.

Banking supervision also becomes the responsibility of the European Union. And yet, if everything goes wrong, if banks fail, the responsibility for paying that failure continues to rest with the national taxpayers, it remains a national responsibility.

This is not a matter of superficial importance; it is a fundamental problem that remains unresolved. And finally, I simply want to mention that the fact that we continue to tie monetary policy to what is a secondary issue in the context in which we live – namely, inflation – and not to job creation and growth, as it should be, also remains unresolved. Thank you very much.

Thank you very much, Mr. President. European leaders continue to insist on budgetary discipline, and I ask, budgetary discipline—so let’s address it. Because what exactly are we talking about when we speak of budgetary discipline?

In my view, budgetary discipline is respecting contracts with pensioners and not abandoning the State’s commitments midway. In my view, budgetary discipline is respecting the contracts of those who work and not inventing extraordinary taxes or cutting subsidies.

Budgetary responsibility entails honoring commitments in healthcare, education, and culture, and refraining from closing services or terminating and cancelling projects mid-stream. Discipline means bringing the banks into order and not extracting funds from taxpayers to hand over to speculators to save their banks.
This is the budgetary area that I would like to see implemented in the European Union and not continue with this market-driven spree.

If an example is needed, the budget being discussed in Portugal under the guidance of the Troika is a perfect example. It violates all the commitments any State should have with its citizens to not violate agreements made behind closed doors that are bringing together Europe and its countries.

Thank you very much, Mr. President, President of the Council, President of the Commission. Firstly, I would naturally congratulate you on the Council’s results, although it seems to me that it is somewhat delayed in time, that the final decision comes a little late.
The truth is that there is progress.

Now, precisely because I see myself reflected in everything my colleague Cassolides has said, I would like to pose just one question to the President of the Council. The countries that are under assistance…
Countries facing difficulties have strongly advocated for the retroactive application of bank debts in their separation from state debt.
This was apparently not accepted.
But we heard yesterday statements from the highest German authorities and the highest French authorities saying that they would treat Ireland with a special situation.
What I am asking is whether the Council approved any discriminatory treatment decision for Ireland different from that reserved for countries such as Portugal, Greece, Spain, and others.
Mr. President, dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner, it is a privilege to present the report on the 20 concerns of citizens and businesses.
Regarding the functioning of the single market, precisely in this debate with Commissioner Barnier, where the twentieth anniversary of this market is being marked.

A first word to express my gratitude to colleagues from all political groups and, in particular, to the rapporteurs and shadow rapporteurs, for their so constructive contributions and their such positive attitude.
It was a pleasure working with everyone, and the report greatly benefited from our combined effort.

We are well aware of and proud that, over these 20 years, the single market has been a driver of significant economic and employment opportunities in Europe, transforming the lives of European citizens and European businesses.
To travel, reside, and work in the territory of the Union are freedoms available to all citizens of the 27 Member States.
For European consumers, the single market means greater choice and lower prices.
For our businesses, the single market means more business opportunities, with access to 500 million consumers, which translates to greater economic growth and increased job creation.
To illustrate the progress that the single market has made in Europe since its creation in 1992 until the onset of the crisis,
2008, it suffices to note the 2.7 million jobs created and the additional 2.13% growth in GDP.
Today, making or receiving a phone call while traveling in Europe is 13% cheaper than it was in 2005.
The freedom of movement of people finds its most eloquent expression in the Erasmus program.
More than 2.5 million students have benefited from this European Education and Mobility Exchange Programme.
Over the past five years, companies have also benefited from a 25% reduction in administrative positions due to single market legislation.
But a question arises. Is everything well in the single market?
No, not everything works well.
The economic and financial crisis affecting us has had negative repercussions on the functioning of this market.

Our citizens, in some countries experiencing the drama of unemployment and confronted with austerity measures, have developed a skeptical view of Europe and a negative perception of the internal market.
People still do not know or sufficiently understand their rights, nor do they know where to find information or assistance.
On the other hand, many Member States unduly delay the transposition of European directives and legislation on the single market, thereby hindering its full potential.

In certain areas of citizens' daily lives, things as simple as, for example, the reimbursement of medical expenses following a temporary stay in another EU country, the opening of a bank account by a student in the program…

Erasmus, the change of energy supplier, the transfer of pension benefits relating to retirement, the recognition of qualifications, and the registration of a vehicle in another Member State remain very complex, difficult, or costly procedures.
It is important to address these problems.
That was my concern as rapporteur.
Therefore, the message presented in the report is very clear. Greater political will is needed, much greater political will from the Member States and the European institutions.
Council, especially Council and Commission, to govern better and jointly. It is necessary to regain the trust of people and businesses and to facilitate the exercise of their rights.

Finally, I would like to welcome the European Commission, represented by Mr. Commissioner Barnier, for the presentation of the Act for the Single Market 2, 12 priority actions for new growth, which marks, I am certain, a new milestone for the future. Thank you very much.
Madam President, Mr. Barnier, dear colleague Regina Bastos, my congratulations on your already very successful efforts.
When Jacques Delors presided over the European Commission, the Single Market of the Union was created in 1992.
Delors then synthesized the three basic principles of the single market: competition that stimulates, cooperation that strengthens, and solidarity that unites.
Twenty years later, the economic and financial crisis rekindled the threat of national protectionism, and it became clear that the domestic market is not a completed work.

And the celebration of these 20 years must be leveraged for a relaunch of the single market, with the concern of placing the market at the service of the citizen and not the citizen at the service of the market.
To that end, it is necessary to define priorities, and I would like to speak about one priority in particular.
A common policy is essential to produce and distribute energy at affordable prices for consumers, with a high level of energy efficiency.
through the European energy market, served by cross-border infrastructures, with the possibility of leveraging community investment, representing added European value.
In energy as well, Madam President, will subjugate the common market.
one of the European Union’s greatest achievements, which undoubtedly represents one of the strongest pillars of the Union’s, its Member States’, and its regions’ development.
However, for it to be effective and equitable, it is necessary to orient its policies towards equal opportunities for citizens and all regions, promoting the internal cohesion of the Union.

In this context, it is essential to recognize that we can only achieve greater development in our most remote regions, such as ultraperipheral regions, through their greater integration into the single market.

Regions like the Azores need to continue increasing their competitiveness by improving their competitive conditions. But we will never achieve this if we do not better resolve our accessibility problems in the area of transportation.
We can achieve this through specific instruments that best address the problems raised by our distancing.
We therefore argue that the Commission should consider a specific program of the type POSEI Transportes as an essential instrument for the training of this type of regions in the internal market.
Thank you very much, Madam President. I begin by saying thank you very much for this excellent debate.
It was a very constructive debate and a debate that demonstrated that the single market is truly a great achievement of the European project.
I greet the presence of Mr. Minister Mavroianis and his participation in this debate. I thank all my colleagues for their constructive approach, and some for a skeptical one, which is understandable.

and to say thank you very much to Mr. Commissioner Barnier for the commitment and enthusiasm he brings to the discussion of these issues, these internal market problems, and the political will to resolve them.
We still have much to respond to regarding the citizens.
Citizens are dissatisfied, disillusioned, and expect more from us, expect more from the Council, expect more from the Commission, expect more from the Member States.
This assessment is very useful; this assessment of 20 years is important, but, as many have said here, it is important to open the door to a future perspective.
And the forward-looking perspective involves many of the issues raised here and many of the measures already announced by the European Commission.
The digital single market, citizen mobility, the reform of the EURES portal, and the European energy market are examples.
eloquent reminders that we still have a significant path to forge in the future, and that this path is crucial and vital to responding to this era of crisis in which we live.
Citizens are suffering; citizens expect a great deal from politicians and the responses politicians can provide to the adverse conditions they are enduring.
Therefore, it is important that the single market be one of the responses to the major challenge of competitiveness, employment, and economic growth.
I am certain that all of us, after this celebration of 20 years, are better positioned to provide the answers our citizens require. Thank you very much.

The Gozes report, along with the report we will prepare on the Union’s annual growth prospects at the end of this year and which will precede the Spring Council, are two essential components of the so-called European Semester.
This report addresses the recommendations made to each of the member countries by the Council under proposal from the Commission. And these recommendations frame, as was just stated, with...
SIXPEC and the future TUPEC, an extraordinarily strong body that reinforces European control over the economic and budgetary policies of member states.

Finding the balance between this control and national-level autonomy and legitimacy is not easy, and it has tipped toward a level of imposition—particularly regarding discipline—and, ultimately, may even give rise to a serious package of sanctions.

Regarding Tupac, I would like to briefly comment that it is important for the Council, which is absent here today, to grant its negotiators a mandate compatible with the ambition of swiftly concluding this package, this Tupac.

But further European coordination, returning to the subject, means less control by countries over their own destiny, which requires a subtle balance, but also an increased demand for the quality of the recommendations made to countries in at least three or four dimensions.

First, it is important to ensure coherence between medium- and long-term objectives, which include growth, employment, and real convergence, and short-term recommendations, focused primarily on discipline and nominal convergence. Second, there must be coherence

Drawing on the conclusions to be derived from the analysis of macroeconomic imbalances, particularly concerning the asymmetric impact of common policies and negative externalities, the spillover effects of certain national policies on other countries.

Thirdly, it is necessary that we agree that there is a minimum threshold of social, economic, and labor rights that cannot be exceeded by these recommendations. And finally, it is important that the quality of the recommendations be assessed based on the results achieved, which is far from being the case so far.

I conclude now, Mr. President. I would simply like to thank Mr. Gozes for his spirit of collaboration and hope that he takes an even further step in this spirit, so as to broaden the base of consensus surrounding his report, and that this spirit endures with respect to the next one as well.
It is true, and has been referred to here many times, that there are many things we do not know about shale gas extraction.
but there are also many that we already know and it is advisable not to forget.
We know, for example, that each shale gas extraction operation utilizes over 19 million liters of potable water, enough to supply a thousand European citizens for a year based on their needs.
We also know that each shale gas extraction, in each of the operations, pumps 300, I apologize, tons of chemicals into the ground, approximately 80% of which remain there and do not leave.

We also know that with each shale gas extraction, radioactive elements and heavy metals are released into the subsurface, and together with the evaporation of toxic waste resulting from the process, they constitute a tangible threat to public health.
This is a danger of contamination of potable water resources, and it is a contamination that is real and imminent.

Knowing this, we know that shale gas extraction is also a response that appears easy, that only considers the immediate, the industry, and profit, ignoring the populations, the future, and the environment.

But this is also the Europe that knows, within this House, that water is an essential, vital, and important resource, that knows how to protect the health of citizens and must protect it, that seeks to make agreements to avoid emissions and to promote energy efficiency, because we know that environmental standards are important, environmental standards and those of health.
Therefore, when one does not know everything, being prudent is the least one can do.
And they may even want to do it, but do not do it in our name or in the name of the citizens who are here to represent us.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. Esteemed colleagues, in fact, the last few years have shown us how the Economic and Monetary Union did not withstand the crisis.
They also showed us that we had a European institutional architecture riddled with loopholes, particularly the institutional architecture of the euro.
And it is for this reason that the report presented here and the proposal presented embody such significantly greater ambition than what is put forth by governments.

But also, as the rapporteur stated, we are on ground where political choices must be made, and that is why I would like to clarify the reasons why we have some problems and cannot support this report.
The first concerns issues related to conditions.

What we see is a persistent narrative suggesting solidarity between different countries can only occur once all requirements are met regarding the stability and growth plan, the intergovernmental agreement, and the pact for…
The euro plus is a set of measures that impose nothing other than massive doses of austerity on the peripheries and also a set of recessive measures that, as we have already seen, are not working.
A second reason relates to the Banking Union.

The rapporteur presents the mechanism of banking supervision very well, but it is so necessary that we cannot shy away from the essential. And the essential is slipping away to the extent that we continue to add the…

aggregated national systems, which means we are all together in banking policy, we are all together in banking supervision, but we are all separate when something goes wrong and, therefore, taxpayers will continue to pay.
A third point concerns the issue of common debt and the issuance of eurobonds.
Here, once again, the possibility of common debt issuance is considered, but only when it is too late.

because we need debt as it currently exists, not just when deficits and excessive debts have been corrected, because with the policies we are following, they will never be corrected; on the contrary, they will be increasingly aggravated to the despair of an entire population.

Therefore, Mr. President, I want to conclude by saying that, despite all efforts, I believe we have here a very clear example of that, working together, we could still rise, but divided, we will surely fall. And that is why it was important to have gone even further.
There are always margins for progress, but for Portugal, the support of the European Union has been fundamental in recent years.
Portugal has transformed from a country whose competitiveness was based on cheap labor into a country of highly skilled and highly sophisticated labor.
But when a country exports, it is necessary to have conditions for what?

And that is why it is important that some countries with surpluses open their doors to the re-qualified exports of countries that started from a specialization profile that was absolutely unsustainable.

A final note to state that immigration cannot be the solution, that retrained labor, where support from the European Union was utilized, should not now be lost through a massive export of the most qualified individuals to countries that have the capacity to welcome them.
This is dramatic and completely undermines our future. Thank you very much.

Thank you, Mr. President. Small-scale fisheries deserve specific protection under the common fisheries policy, not only because they promote socio-economic cohesion and guarantee the livelihood of many families, but also because they constitute a factor in securing these communities along coastal areas.
Their economic and social sustainability should constitute an objective, ensuring them a differentiated fishing regime that prioritizes access to resources.
allows for proximity management and protects the fishing rights that benefit fishing professionals in those communities against transferable fishing rights.
It is equally important, for its sustainability, to consider the water access regime, particularly in waters or regions with biogeographic basins.
Marine areas with limited continental shelves and sparse resources concentrated on seamounts and fishing grounds that must have protected access.

Within a context of liberalization and a crisis impacting vulnerable regions, it must also be ensured that products originating from international trade comply with the same requirements as products that the Union imports.
Mr. President, President of the Board of Directors, Commissioner, I will be very brief because I believe that what is at issue here is essentially a political point.
A financial point. And the question at hand is this: do we want the European Union to make a difference in the context of the crisis, or do we want to exacerbate the crisis?

Most European countries are currently making an enormous effort, from the perspective of their public finances, to overcome the crisis in a competitive manner, in a way that can position their countries...

European Union, on a global scale, possesses a considerable capacity for competitiveness and competition, but it is obvious that without investment, there can be no growth and this crisis cannot be overcome.
If the European Union insists on these radical cuts, particularly in cohesion policy and the common agricultural policy, what this will mean is that the countries that are making a tremendous…
effort, they will not be able to grow, and this plan that we have accepted in all countries for the European Union will fail. Sound accounts with prospects for growth and competitiveness.

The sole and principal instrument for this is precisely this multiannual financial framework. And therefore, if we want the European Union to succeed and this policy to be an exemplary one for other countries, we must invest in the budget for the financial perspectives.
